1007.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is subjected to a force $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})=-\nabla V(\mathbf{r})$ such that the wave function $\varphi(\mathbf{p}, t)$ satisfies the momentum-space Schrödinger equation

$$
\left(\mathbf{p}^{2} / 2 m-a \nabla_{p}^{2}\right) \varphi(\mathbf{p}, t)=i \partial \varphi(\mathbf{p}, t) / \partial t
$$

where $\hbar=1$, a is some real constant and

$$
\nabla_{p}^{2}=\partial^{2} / \partial p_{x}^{2}+\partial^{2} / \partial p_{y}^{2}+\partial^{2} / \partial p_{z}^{2}
$$

Find the force $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})$.
1007.Solution:
The coordinate and momentum representations of a wave function are related by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=\left(\frac{1}{2 \pi}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}} \int \varphi(\mathbf{k}, t) e^{i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}} d \mathbf{k} \\
&\varphi(\mathbf{k}, t)=\left(\frac{1}{2 \pi}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}} \int \psi(\mathbf{r}, t) e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}} d \mathbf{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbf{k}=\frac{\mathbf{p}}{\hbar}$. Thus (with $\hbar=1$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{p}^{2} \varphi(\mathbf{p}, t) \rightarrow-\nabla^{2} \psi(\mathbf{r}, t) \\
&\nabla_{p}^{2} \varphi(\mathbf{p}, t) \rightarrow-r^{2} \psi(\mathbf{r}, t)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Schrödinger equation becomes, in coordinate space,

$$
\left(\frac{-\nabla^{2}}{2 m}+a r^{2}\right) \varphi(\mathbf{r}, t)=i \frac{\partial \varphi(\mathbf{r}, t)}{\partial t} .
$$

Hence the potential is

$$
V(\mathbf{r})=a r^{2},
$$

and the force is

$$
F(\mathbf{r})=-\nabla V(\mathbf{r})=-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{r} \frac{d}{d r} V(r)=-2 a \mathbf{r}
$$
1007.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1010.a.Problem Statement:
$\psi(x, t)$ is a solution of the Schrödinger equation for a free particle of mass $m$ in one dimension, and

$$
\psi(x, 0)=A \exp \left(-x^{2} / a^{2}\right)
$$

At time $t=0$ find the probability amplitude in momentum space.
1010.a.Solution:
At time $t=0$ the probability amplitude in momentum space is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(p, 0) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi \hbar}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-i p x / \hbar} \psi(x, 0) d x \\
&=\frac{A}{\sqrt{2 \pi \hbar}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-x^{2} / a^{2}-i p x / \hbar\right) d x \\
&=\frac{A a}{\sqrt{2 \hbar}} \exp \left(-a^{2} p^{2} / 4 \hbar^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
1010.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1010.b.Problem Statement:
$\psi(x, t)$ is a solution of the Schrödinger equation for a free particle of mass $m$ in one dimension, and

$$
\psi(x, 0)=A \exp \left(-x^{2} / a^{2}\right)
$$

Find $\psi(x, t)$
1010.b.Solution:
At time $t=0$ the probability amplitude in momentum space is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(p, 0) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi \hbar}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-i p x / \hbar} \psi(x, 0) d x \\
&=\frac{A}{\sqrt{2 \pi \hbar}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left(-x^{2} / a^{2}-i p x / \hbar\right) d x \\
&=\frac{A a}{\sqrt{2 \hbar}} \exp \left(-a^{2} p^{2} / 4 \hbar^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$The Schrödinger equation in momentum space for a free particle,

$$
i \hbar \partial \psi(p, t) / \partial t=\hat{H} \psi(p, t)=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m} \psi(p, t)
$$

gives

$$
\psi(p, t)=B \exp \left(\frac{-i p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}\right)
$$

At time $t=0$, we have $B=\psi(p, 0)$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi(p, t)=\frac{A a}{\sqrt{2 \hbar}} \exp \left[-\frac{a^{2} p^{2}}{4 \hbar^{2}}-\frac{i p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}\right] \\
& \psi(x, t)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{1 / 2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[\frac{i p x}{\hbar}\right] \psi(p, t) d p \\
& =\frac{A a}{\sqrt{a^{2}+\frac{2 i \hbar t}{m}}} \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{\left(a^{2}+\frac{2 i \hbar t}{m}\right)}\right] \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

We can also expand the wave function as a linear superposition of plane waves and get 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& \frac{1}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{1 / 2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi(p, 0) e^{i(k x-\omega t)} d p \\
=& \frac{1}{(2 \pi \hbar)^{1 / 2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{A a}{\sqrt{2 \hbar}} \exp \left[-\frac{a^{2} p^{2}}{4 \hbar^{2}}\right] \\
& \times \exp \left[i\left(\frac{p}{\hbar} x-\frac{p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}\right)\right] d p \\
=& \frac{A a}{2 \hbar \sqrt{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{a^{2} p^{2}}{4 \hbar^{2}}-\frac{i p^{2} t}{2 m \hbar}+\frac{i p x}{\hbar}\right] d p \\
=& \frac{A a}{\sqrt{a^{2}+\frac{2 i \hbar t}{m}}} \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{\left(a^{2}+\frac{2 i \hbar t}{m}\right)}\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

which agrees with the previous result.
1010.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1011.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is confined to a one-dimensional region $0 \leq x \leq a$ as shown in Fig. 1.2. At $t=0$ its normalized wave function is

$$
\psi(x, t=0)=\sqrt{8 / 5 a}\left[1+\cos \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right)\right] \sin (\pi x / a) \text {. }
$$

What is the wave function at a later time $t=t_{0}$ ?
1011.a.Solution:
The time-independent Schrödinger equation for $0<x<a$ is

$$
\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \psi}{d x^{2}}+E \psi=0
$$

It has solution $\psi(x)=A \sin k x$, where $k$ is given by $k^{2}=\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}$, satisfying $\psi(0)=0$. The boundary condition $\psi(a)=0$ then requires $k a=n \pi$. Hence the normalized eigenfunctions are 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-025.jpg?height=374&width=513&top_left_y=158&top_left_x=456)

Fig. $1.2$

$$
\psi_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{a}\right),
$$

and the energy eigenvalues are

$$
E_{n}=\frac{n^{2} \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 m a^{2}}, \quad n=1,2,3, \ldots
$$

Any wave function $\psi(x, t)$ can be expanded in $\psi_{n}$ :

$$
\psi(x, t)=\sum_{n} A_{n}(t) \psi_{n}(x, 0)
$$

with

$$
A_{n}(t)=A_{n}(0) \exp \left(-\frac{i E_{n} t}{\hbar}\right) .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, 0) &=\sqrt{\frac{8}{5 a}}\left(1+\cos \frac{\pi x}{a}\right) \sin \frac{\pi x}{a} \\
&=\sqrt{\frac{8}{5 a}} \sin \frac{\pi x}{a}+\sqrt{\frac{2}{5 a}} \sin \frac{2 \pi x}{a}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
A_{1}(0)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}, \quad A_{2}(0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}, \quad A_{n}(0)=0 \quad \text { for } n \neq 1,2 .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi\left(x, t_{0}\right)=& \sqrt{\frac{8}{5 a}} \exp \left(-\frac{i \pi^{2} \hbar t_{0}}{2 m a^{2}}\right) \sin \frac{\pi x}{a} \\
&+\sqrt{\frac{2}{5 a}} \exp \left(-\frac{i 2 \pi^{2} \hbar t_{0}}{m a^{2}}\right) \sin \frac{2 \pi x}{a} \\
=& \sqrt{\frac{8}{5 a}}\left[\exp \left(\frac{-i \pi^{2} \hbar t_{0}}{2 m a^{2}}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+\exp \left(\frac{-i 2 \pi^{2} \hbar t_{0}}{m a^{2}}\right) \cos \frac{\pi x}{a}\right] \sin \frac{\pi x}{a}
\end{aligned}
$$

1013.a.Problem Statement:
A rigid body with moment of inertia of $I_{z}$ rotates freely in the $x-y$ plane. Let $\phi$ be the angle between the $x$-axis and the rotator axis.

Find the energy eigenvalues and the corresponding eigenfunctions.
1013.a.Solution:
The Hamiltonian of a plane rotator is

$$
H=-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}\right) d^{2} / d \phi^{2}
$$

and so the Schrödinger equation is

$$
-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}\right) d^{2} \psi / d \phi^{2}=E \psi \text {. }
$$

Setting $\alpha^{2}=2 I_{z} E / \hbar^{2}$, we write the solution as

$$
\psi=A e^{i \alpha \phi}+B e^{-i \alpha \phi},
$$

where $A, B$ are arbitrary constants. For the wave function to be singlevalued, i.e. $\psi(\phi)=\psi(\phi+2 \pi)$, we require

$$
\alpha \equiv m=0, \quad \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots .
$$

The eigenvalues of energy are then

$$
E_{m}=m^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 I_{z}, \quad m=0, \pm 1, \ldots
$$

and the corresponding eigenfunctions are

$$
\psi_{m}(\phi)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{i m \phi}, \quad m=0, \pm 1, \ldots,
$$

after normalization $\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \psi_{m}^{*} \psi_{m} d \phi=1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(0) &=A \sin ^{2} \phi=\frac{A}{2}(1-\cos 2 \phi) \\
&=A / 2-\frac{A}{4}\left(e^{i 2 \phi}+e^{-i 2 \phi}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which corresponds to $m=0$ and $m=\pm 2$. The angular speed is given by $E_{m}=\frac{1}{2} I_{z} \dot{\phi}^{2}$, or $\dot{\phi}=\frac{m \hbar}{I_{z}}$. Hence we have for time $t$ 

$$
\psi(t)=\frac{A}{2}-\frac{A}{4}\left[e^{i 2\left(\phi-\hbar t / I_{z}\right)}+e^{-i 2\left(\phi+\hbar t / I_{z}\right)}\right]
$$
1013.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1017.Problem Statement: The dynamics of a particle moving one-dimensionally in a potential $V(x)$ is governed by the Hamiltonian $H_{0}=p^{2} / 2 m+V(x)$, where $p=-i \hbar d / d x$ is the momentum operator. Let $E_{n}^{(0)}, n=1,2,3, \ldots$, be the eigenvalues of $H_{0}$. Now consider a new Hamiltonian $H=H_{0}+\lambda p / m$, where $\lambda$ is a given parameter. Given $\lambda, m$ and $E_{n}^{(0)}$, find the eigenvalues of $H$.
1017.Solution:
The new Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=H_{0}+\lambda p / m=p^{2} / 2 m+\lambda p / m+V(x) \\
&=(p+\lambda)^{2} / 2 m+V(x)-\lambda^{2} / 2 m
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
H^{\prime}=\frac{p^{\prime^{2}}}{2 m}+V(x)
$$

where $H^{\prime}=H+\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2 m}, p^{\prime}=p+\lambda$.

The eigenfunctions and eigenvalues of $H^{\prime}$ are respectively $E_{n}^{(0)}$ and $\psi_{n}^{(0)}$. As the wave number is $k^{\prime}=\frac{p^{\prime}}{\hbar}=\frac{1}{\hbar}(p+\lambda)$, the new eigenfunctions are

$$
\psi=\psi^{(0)} e^{-i \lambda x / \hbar}
$$

and the corresponding eigenvalues are

$$
E_{n}=E_{n}^{(0)}-\lambda^{2} / 2 m
$$
1017.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1018.a.Problem Statement:
Consider the one-dimensional wave function

$$
\psi(x)=A\left(x / x_{0}\right)^{n} e^{-x / x_{0}}
$$

where $A, n$ and $x_{0}$ are constants.

Using Schrödinger's equation, find the potential $V(x)$ and energy $E$ for which this wave function is an eigenfunction.
1018.a.Solution:
Differentiating the given wave function,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{d x} \psi(x)=& A \frac{n}{x_{0}}\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)^{n-1} e^{-x / x_{0}}+A\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)^{n}\left(-\frac{1}{x_{0}}\right) e^{-x / x_{0}}, \\
\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi(x)=& A \frac{n(n-1)}{x_{0}^{2}}\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)^{n-2} e^{-x / x_{0}} \\
&-2 A \frac{n}{x_{0}^{2}}\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)^{n-1} e^{-x / x_{0}}+A \frac{1}{x_{0}^{2}}\left(\frac{x}{x_{0}}\right)^{n} e^{-x / x_{0}} \\
=& {\left[\frac{n(n-1)}{x^{2}}-2 \frac{n}{x_{0} x}+\frac{1}{x_{0}^{2}}\right] \psi(x) }
\end{aligned}
$$

and substituting it in the time-independent Schrödinger equation

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} d^{2} / d x^{2}+V(x)\right) \psi(x)=E \psi(x)
$$

we have

$$
E-V(x)=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left[\frac{n(n-1)}{x^{2}}-\frac{2 n}{x_{0} x}+\frac{1}{x_{0}^{2}}\right] .
$$

As $V(x) \rightarrow 0$ when $x \rightarrow \infty$, we have $E=-\hbar^{2} / 2 m x_{0}^{2}$ and hence

$$
V(x)=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left[\frac{n(n-1)}{x^{2}}-2 n / x_{0} x\right] \text {. }
$$
1018.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1022.Problem Statement: A particle of mass $m$ moves non-relativistically in one dimension in a potential given by $V(x)=-a \delta(x)$, where $\delta(x)$ is the usual Dirac delta function. The particle is bound. Find the value of $x_{0}$ such that the probability of finding the particle with $|x|<x_{0}$ is exactly equal to $1 / 2$.
1022.Solution:
For bound states, $E<0$. The Schrödinger equation

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-a \delta(x)\right] \psi(x)=E \psi(x)
$$

has for $x \neq 0$ the solutions finite at $x=\pm \infty$ as follows,

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}A e^{k x} & \text { for } x<0 \\ A e^{-k x} & \text { for } x>0\end{cases}
$$

where $k=\frac{\sqrt{-2 m E}}{\hbar}$ and $A$ is an arbitrary constant. Applying $\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}}$ $\int_{-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon} d x$ to the Schrödinger equation gives

$$
\psi^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)-\psi^{\prime}\left(0^{-}\right)=-\frac{2 m a}{\hbar^{2}} \psi(0)
$$

since

$$
\int_{-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon} \psi(x) \delta(x) d x=\psi(0), \quad \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \int_{-\varepsilon}^{\varepsilon} \psi(x) d x=0
$$

for finite $\psi(0)$. Substitution of $\psi(x)$ in (1) gives

$$
k=\frac{m a}{\hbar^{2}} .
$$

Hence

$$
\psi(x)=A \exp \left(-\frac{m a|x|}{\hbar^{2}}\right)
$$

On account of symmetry, the probabilities are

$$
\begin{aligned}
P\left(|x|<x_{0}\right) &=2|A|^{2} \int_{0}^{x_{0}} e^{-2 k x} d x=\frac{|A|^{2}}{k}\left(1-e^{-2 k x_{0}}\right), \\
P(-\infty<x<\infty) &=2|A|^{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-2 k x} d x=\frac{|A|^{2}}{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

As it is given

$$
1-e^{-2 k x_{0}}=\frac{1}{2},
$$

we have

$$
x_{0}=\frac{1}{2 k} \ln 2=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m a} \ln 2 .
$$
1022.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1023.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moving in one dimension is confined to the region $0<x<L$ by an infinite square well potential. In addition, the particle experiences a delta function potential of strength $\lambda$ located at the center of the well (Fig. 1.11). The Schrödinger equation which describes this system is, within the well,

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2} \psi(x)}{\partial x^{2}}+\lambda \delta(x-L / 2) \psi(x)=E \psi(x), \quad 0<x<L
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-043.jpg?height=299&width=404&top_left_y=1302&top_left_x=468)

Fig. 1.11

Find a transcendental equation for the energy eigenvalues $E$ in terms of the mass $m$, the potential strength $\lambda$, and the size $L$ of the system.
1023.Solution:
Applying $\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \int_{L / 2-\varepsilon}^{L / 2+\varepsilon} d x$ to both sides of the Schrödinger equation, we get

$$
\psi^{\prime}(L / 2+\varepsilon)-\psi^{\prime}(L / 2-\varepsilon)=\left(2 m \lambda / \hbar^{2}\right) \psi(L / 2)
$$

since

$$
\int_{\frac{L}{2}-\varepsilon}^{\frac{L}{2}+\varepsilon} \psi(x) \delta\left(x-\frac{L}{2}\right) d x=\psi\left(\frac{L}{2}\right), \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \int_{\frac{L}{2}-\varepsilon}^{\frac{L}{2}+\varepsilon} \psi(x) d x=0 .
$$

Subject to the boundary conditions $\psi(0)=\psi(L)=0$, the Schrödinger equation has solutions for $x \neq \frac{L}{2}$ :

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}A_{1} \sin (k x), & 0 \leq x \leq L / 2-\varepsilon \\ A_{2} \sin [k(x-L)], & L / 2+\varepsilon \leq x \leq L,\end{cases}
$$

where $k=\frac{\sqrt{2 m E}}{\hbar}$ and $\varepsilon$ is an arbitrarily small positive number. The continuity of the wave function at $L / 2$ requires $A_{1} \sin (k L / 2)=-A_{2}$ $\sin (k L / 2)$, or $A_{1}=-A_{2}$. Substituting the wave function in (1), we get

$$
A_{2} k \cos (k L / 2)-A_{1} k \cos (k L / 2)=\left(2 m \lambda A_{1} / \hbar^{2}\right) \sin (k L / 2),
$$

whence $\tan \frac{k L}{2}=-\frac{k \hbar^{2}}{m \lambda}$, or $\tan \frac{\sqrt{2 m E} L}{2 \hbar}=-\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{m}} \frac{\hbar}{\lambda}$, which is the transcendental equation for the energy eigenvalue $E$.
1023.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1027.Problem Statement:
The wave function of the ground state of a harmonic oscillator of force constant $k$ and mass $m$ is

$$
\psi_{0}(x)=(\alpha / \pi)^{1 / 4} e^{-\alpha x^{2} / 2}, \quad \alpha=m \omega_{0} / \hbar, \quad \omega_{0}^{2}=k / m .
$$

Obtain an expression for the probability of finding the particle outside the classical region.
1027.Solution:
The particle is said to be outside the classical region if $E<V(x)$. For the ground state, $E=\hbar \omega_{0} / 2$ and the nonclassical region is $\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega_{0}<$ $\frac{1}{2} m \omega_{0}^{2} x^{2}$, i.e.,

$$
x^{2}>\frac{\hbar}{\omega_{0} m}=\frac{1}{\alpha}, \quad \text { or }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x>\sqrt{\frac{1}{\alpha}}, \\
x<-\sqrt{\frac{1}{\alpha}} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

The probability of finding the particle in this nonclassical region is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\int_{|x|>\sqrt{\frac{1}{a}}} \psi_{0}^{2}(x) d x \\
&=\int_{-\infty}^{-\sqrt{1 / \alpha}} \sqrt{\frac{\alpha}{\pi}} e^{-\alpha x^{2}} d x+\int_{\sqrt{1 / \alpha}}^{\infty} \sqrt{\frac{\alpha}{\pi}} e^{-\alpha x^{2}} d x \\
&=2 \int_{\sqrt{1 / \alpha}}^{\infty} \sqrt{\frac{\alpha}{\pi}} e^{-\alpha x^{2}} d x \\
&=2 \int_{1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}} e^{-t^{2}} d t \simeq 16 \%
\end{aligned}
$$
1027.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1030.Problem Statement:
An electron is confined in the ground state of a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator such that $\sqrt{\left\langle(x-\langle x\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle}=10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}$. Find the energy (in $\mathrm{eV})$ required to excite it to its first excited state.

[Hint: The virial theorem can help.]
1030.Solution:
The virial theorem for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator states that $\langle T\rangle=\langle V\rangle$. Thus $E_{0}=\langle H\rangle=\langle T\rangle+\langle V\rangle=2\langle V\rangle=m_{e} \omega^{2}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle$, or, for the ground state,

$$
\frac{\hbar \omega}{2}=m_{e} \omega^{2}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle,
$$

giving

$$
\omega=\frac{\hbar}{2 m_{e}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle} .
$$

As $\langle x\rangle=0$ for a harmonic oscillator, we have

$$
\sqrt{\left\langle(x-\langle x\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle}=\sqrt{\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle-\langle x\rangle^{2}}=\sqrt{\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle}=10^{-10} \mathrm{~m} .
$$

The energy required to excite the electron to its first excited state is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E=\hbar \omega &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m_{e}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle}=\frac{\hbar^{2} c^{2}}{2 m_{e} c^{2}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle} \\
&=\frac{\left(6.58 \times 10^{-16}\right)^{2} \times\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 0.51 \times 10^{-20}}=3.8 \mathrm{eV} .
\end{aligned}
$$
1030.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1031.c.Problem Statement:
The wave function at time $t=0$ for a particle in a harmonic oscillator potential $V=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}$, is of the form

$$
\psi(x, 0)=A e^{-(\alpha x)^{2} / 2}\left[\cos \beta H_{0}(\alpha x)+\frac{\sin \beta}{2 \sqrt{2}} H_{2}(\alpha x)\right]
$$

where $\beta$ and $A$ are real constants, $\alpha^{2} \equiv \sqrt{m k} / \hbar$, and the Hermite polynomials are normalized so that

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\alpha^{2} x^{2}}\left[H_{x}(\alpha x)\right]^{2} d x=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{\alpha} 2^{n} n !
$$

What is $\langle x\rangle$ at $t=0$ ? How does $\langle x\rangle$ change with time?
1031.c.Solution:
The Schrödinger equation for the system is

$$
i \hbar \partial_{t} \psi(x, t)=\hat{H} \psi(x, t)
$$

where $\psi(x, t)$ takes the given value $\psi(x, 0)$ at $t=0$. As $\hat{H}$ does not depend on $t$ explicitly,

$$
\psi_{n}(x, t)=\psi_{n}(x) e^{-i E_{n} t / \hbar}
$$

where $\psi_{n}(x)$ is the energy eigenfunction satisfying

$$
\hat{H} \psi_{n}(x)=E_{n} \psi_{n}(x) .
$$

Expanding $\psi(x, 0)$ in terms of $\psi_{n}(x)$ :

$$
\psi(x, 0)=\sum_{n} a_{n} \psi_{n}(x)
$$

where

$$
a_{n}=\int \psi_{n}^{*}(x) \psi(x, 0) d x
$$

Thus

$$
\psi(x, t)=\sum_{n} a_{n} \psi_{n}(x, t)=\sum_{n} a_{n} \psi_{n}(x) e^{-i E_{n} t / \hbar}
$$

For a harmonic oscillator,

$$
\psi_{n}(x)=N_{n} e^{-\alpha^{2} x^{2} / 2} H_{n}(\alpha x),
$$

so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{n}=& \int N_{n} e^{-\alpha^{2} x^{2} / 2} H_{n}(\alpha x) \cdot A e^{-\alpha^{2} x^{2} / 2} \\
& \times\left[\cos \beta H_{0}(\alpha x)+\frac{\sin \beta}{2 \sqrt{2}} H_{2}(\alpha x)\right] d x .
\end{aligned}
$$

As the functions $\exp \left(-\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\right) H_{n}(x)$ are orthogonal, all $a_{n}=0$ except

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a_{0}=A N_{0} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{\alpha^{2}}} \cos \beta, \\
&a_{2}=A N_{2} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{\alpha^{2}}} 2 \sqrt{2} \sin \beta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t)=& A \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{\alpha^{2}}}\left[N_{0} \cos \beta \psi_{0}(x) e^{-i E_{0} t / \hbar}\right.\\
&\left.+2 \sqrt{2} N_{2} \sin \beta \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i E_{2} t / \hbar}\right] \\
=& A\left(\frac{\pi}{\alpha^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}\left[\cos \beta \psi_{0}(x) e^{-i \frac{E_{0} t}{\hbar}}+\sin \beta \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \frac{E_{2} t}{\hbar}}\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

as $N_{n}$ are given by $\int\left[\psi_{n}(x)\right]^{2} d x=1$ to be $N_{0}=\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}}{\pi}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}, N_{2}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}}{\pi}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}$.

The observable energy values for this state are $E_{0}=\hbar \omega / 2$ and $E_{2}=5 \hbar \omega / 2$, and the relative probability of getting these values is

$$
P_{0} / P_{2}=\cos ^{2} \beta / \sin ^{2} \beta=\cot ^{2} \beta .
$$

As $\psi(x, 0)$ is a linear combination of only $\psi_{0}(x)$ and $\psi_{2}(x)$ which have even parity,

$$
\psi(-x, 0)=\psi(x, 0)
$$

Hence for $t=0$

$$
\langle x\rangle=\int \psi(x, 0) x \psi(x, 0) d x=0 .
$$

It follows that the average value of $x$ does not change with time.
1031.c.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1033.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a particle of mass $m$ in the one-dimensional potential

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2, & |x|>b \\
V(x)=V_{0}, & |x|<b
\end{array}
$$

where $V_{0} \gg \hbar^{2} / m b^{2} \gg \hbar \omega$, i.e. a harmonic oscillator potential with a high, thin, nearly impenetrable barrier at $x=0$ (see Fig 1.16).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-058.jpg?height=304&width=339&top_left_y=947&top_left_x=489)

Fig. $1.16$

What is the low-lying energy spectrum under the approximation that the barrier is completely impenetrable?
1033.a.Solution: For the low-lying energy spectrum, as the barrier is completely impenetrable, the potential is equivalent to two separate halves of a harmonic oscillator potential and the low-lying eigenfunctions must satisfy the condition $\psi(x)=0$ at $x=0$. The low-lying energy spectrum thus corresponds to that of a normal harmonic oscillator with odd quantum numbers $2 n+1$, for which $\psi_{n}(x)=0$, at $x=0$ and $E_{n}=(2 n+3 / 2) \hbar \omega, n=0,1,2, \ldots$ with a degeneracy of 2 . Thus only the odd-parity wave functions are allowed for the low-lying levels.

One unnormalized energy eigenfunction is

1035.a.Problem Statement:
At time $t=0$ a particle in the potential $V(x)=m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2$ is described by the wave function

$$
\psi(x, 0)=A \sum_{n}(1 / \sqrt{2})^{n} \psi_{n}(x)
$$

where $\psi_{n}(x)$ are eigenstates of the energy with eigenvalues $E_{n}=(n+$ 1/2) $\hbar \omega$. You are given that $\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{n^{\prime}}\right)=\delta_{n n^{\prime}}$.

Find the normalization constant $A$.
1035.a.Solution:
The normalization condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\psi(x, 0), \psi(x, 0)) &=|A|^{2} \sum_{m, n}(1 / 2)^{(m+n) / 2}\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{m}\right) \\
&=|A|^{2} \sum_{m}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{m}=2|A|^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

gives $A=1 / \sqrt{2}$, taking $A$ as positive real.
1035.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1035.d.Problem Statement:
At time $t=0$ a particle in the potential $V(x)=m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2$ is described by the wave function

$$
\psi(x, 0)=A \sum_{n}(1 / \sqrt{2})^{n} \psi_{n}(x)
$$

where $\psi_{n}(x)$ are eigenstates of the energy with eigenvalues $E_{n}=(n+$ 1/2) $\hbar \omega$. You are given that $\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{n^{\prime}}\right)=\delta_{n n^{\prime}}$.

Find the expectation value of the energy at $t=0$.
1035.d.Solution:
The normalization condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\psi(x, 0), \psi(x, 0)) &=|A|^{2} \sum_{m, n}(1 / 2)^{(m+n) / 2}\left(\psi_{n}, \psi_{m}\right) \\
&=|A|^{2} \sum_{m}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{m}=2|A|^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

gives $A=1 / \sqrt{2}$, taking $A$ as positive real.The time-dependent wave function is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(x, t) &=e^{-i \hat{H} t / \hbar} \psi(x, 0) \\
&=\sum_{n}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{n+1} e^{-i \omega t\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right)} \psi_{n}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

The probability density is

$$
|\psi(x, t)|^{2}=\sum_{m n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1} e^{-i \omega t(n-m)} \psi_{n}(x) \psi_{m}^{*}(x)
$$

Note that the time factor $\exp [-i \omega(n-m) t]$ is a function with period $\frac{2 \pi}{(n-m) \omega}$, the maximum period being $2 \pi / \omega$.

The expectation value of energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H} &=(\psi(x, 0), \hat{H} \psi(x, 0))=\sum_{m, n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1}\left(\psi_{n}, \hat{H} \psi_{m}\right) \\
&=\sum_{m, n}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{m+n}{2}+1}\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega \delta_{n m} \\
&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n+1}}\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^{n}}=\frac{x}{x-1}
$$

or, by differentiation,

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{-n}{x^{n+1}}=\frac{-1}{(x-1)^{2}}
$$

we have

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{n}{2^{n+1}}=1
$$

and hence $\bar{H}=3 \hbar \omega / 2$.
1035.d.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1038.b.Problem Statement:
The wave function for a particle of mass $M$ in a one-dimensional potential $V(x)$ is given by the expression

$$
\begin{array}{rll}
\psi(x, t) & =\alpha x \exp (-\beta x) \exp (i \gamma t / \hbar), & x>0 \\
& =0, & x<0
\end{array}
$$

where $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are all positive constants.

What is the probability density $\rho(E)$ for a measurement of the total energy $E$ of the particle?
1038.b.Solution:
The particle is in a bound state because the wave function $\psi(x, t)$ satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\lim _{x \rightarrow-\infty} \psi(x, t)=0, \\
&\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} \psi(x, t)=\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} \alpha x e^{-\beta x} e^{i \gamma t / \hbar}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$
1038.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1038.c.Problem Statement:
The wave function for a particle of mass $M$ in a one-dimensional potential $V(x)$ is given by the expression

$$
\begin{array}{rll}
\psi(x, t) & =\alpha x \exp (-\beta x) \exp (i \gamma t / \hbar), & x>0 \\
& =0, & x<0
\end{array}
$$

where $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are all positive constants.

Find the lowest energy eigenvalue of $V(x)$ in terms of the given quantities.
1038.c.Solution:
The particle is in a bound state because the wave function $\psi(x, t)$ satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\lim _{x \rightarrow-\infty} \psi(x, t)=0, \\
&\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} \psi(x, t)=\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} \alpha x e^{-\beta x} e^{i \gamma t / \hbar}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$Substituting the wave function for $x>0$ in the Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(x, t)=\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+V(x)\right] \psi(x, t)
$$

gives

$$
-\gamma x=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\beta^{2} x-2 \beta\right)+V(x) x,
$$

whence the potential for $x>0$ :

$$
V(x)=-\gamma+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\beta^{2}-2 \beta / x\right) .
$$

As the stationary wave function of the particle in $V(x)$ satisfies

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-\beta^{2}+2 \beta / x\right) \psi_{E}(x)=(E+\gamma) \psi_{E}(x), \quad(x>0)
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi_{E}(x)+\frac{2 M}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E^{\prime}+e^{2} / x\right) \psi_{E}(x)=0
$$

by setting

$$
E^{\prime}=E+\gamma-\beta^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 M, \quad e^{2}=\beta \hbar^{2} / M,
$$

and $\psi_{E}(x) \stackrel{x \rightarrow 0}{\longrightarrow 0}$, we see that the above equation is the same as that satisfied by the radial wave function of a hydrogen atom with $l=0$. The corresponding Bohr radius is $a=\hbar^{2} / M e^{2}=1 / \beta$, while the energy levels are

$$
E_{n}^{\prime}=-M e^{4} / 2 \hbar^{2} n^{2}=-\beta^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 M n^{2}, \quad n=1,2, \ldots
$$

Hence

$$
E_{n}=-\gamma+\left(\beta^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 M\right)\left(1-1 / n^{2}\right), \quad n=1,2, \ldots,
$$

and consequently the lowest energy eigenvalue is $E_{1}=-\gamma$ with the wave function

$$
\psi(x, t)=\alpha x \exp (-\beta x) \exp (i \gamma t / \hbar) \propto \psi_{E 1}(x) \exp \left(-i E_{1} t / \hbar\right)
$$

The probability density $\rho(E)=\psi^{*} \psi=\psi_{E 1}^{*} \psi_{E 1}$ is therefore

$$
\rho(E)= \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } E=-\gamma \\ 0 & \text { for } E \neq-\gamma\end{cases}
$$

1039.d.Solution:
Thus

The normalized wave function at $t=0$ is $\psi(x, 0)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \frac{\pi x}{a}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\hat{H}\rangle_{t=0} &=-V_{0}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{2}{a} \int_{0}^{a} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right) \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m a}-V_{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$$\langle\hat{H}\rangle$ is a constant for $t>0$ since $\partial\langle\hat{H}\rangle / \partial t=0$.

It is not a state of definite energy, because the wave function of the initial state is the eigenfunction of an infinitely deep square well potential with width $a$, and not of the given potential. It is a superposition state of the different energy eigenstates of the given potential. Therefore different measurements of the energy in this state will not give the same value, but a group of energies according to their probabilities.

The shape of the wave function is time dependent since the solution satisfying the given conditions is a superposition state:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi(x, 0)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right)=\sum_{n} c_{n} \psi_{n}(x) \\
&\psi(x, t)=\sum_{n} c_{n} \psi_{n}(x) e^{-i E_{n} t / \hbar}
\end{aligned}
$$

The shape of $\psi(x, t)$ will change with time because $E_{n}$ changes with $n$.

1045.a.Problem Statement:
The radioactive isotope ${ }_{83} \mathrm{Bi}^{212}$ decays to ${ }_{81} \mathrm{Tl}^{208}$ by emitting an alpha particle with the energy $E=6.0 \mathrm{MeV}$.

In an attempt to calculate the lifetime, first consider the finite potential barrier shown in Fig. 1.20. Calculate the transition probability $T$ for a particle of mass $m$ incident from the left with energy $E$ in the limit $T \ll 1$

$(C U S)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-082.jpg?height=274&width=455&top_left_y=1207&top_left_x=437)

Fig. $1.20$
1045.a.Solution:
If $T \ll 1$, the incident wave is reflected at $x=0$ as if the potential barrier were infinitely thick. We thus have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi(x)=e^{i k x}+\left(t_{1}-1\right) e^{-i k x}, & x<0 \\
\psi(x)=t_{1} e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & 0<x<b
\end{array}
$$

where $t_{1}$ is the amplitude transmission coefficient and

$$
k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

The continuity of $\psi^{\prime}(x)$ at $x=0$ gives

$$
i k\left(2-t_{1}\right)=-k^{\prime} t_{1}, \quad \text { or } \quad t_{1}=\frac{2 k}{k+i k^{\prime}}
$$

Consider the reflection at $b$. We have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi(x)=t_{1} e^{-k^{\prime} b}\left[e^{-k^{\prime}(x-b)}+\left(t_{2}-1\right) e^{k^{\prime}(x-b)}\right], & 0<x<b \\
\psi(x)=t_{1} t_{2} e^{-k^{\prime} b} e^{i k(x-b)}, & x>b
\end{array}
$$

and so

$$
-k^{\prime}\left(2-t_{2}\right)=i k t_{2}, \quad \text { or } \quad t_{2}=2 i k^{\prime} /\left(k+i k^{\prime}\right) .
$$

Hence the transition probability is given by

$$
T=t_{1} t_{2} e^{-k^{\prime} b}
$$

to be

$$
|T|^{2}=\frac{16 k^{2} k^{\prime 2}}{\left(k^{2}+k^{\prime 2}\right)^{2}} e^{-2 k^{\prime} b}=\frac{16 E\left(V_{0}-E\right)}{V_{0}^{2}} e^{-2 k^{\prime} b} .
$$

1047.Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional square-well potential (see Fig 1.23)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=0, & x<0 \\
V(x)=-V_{0}, & 0<x<a, \\
V(x)=0, & x>a,
\end{array}
$$

where $V_{0}$ is positive. If a particle with mass $m$ is incident from the left with nonrelativistic kinetic energy $E$, what is its probability for transmission through the potential? For what values of $E$ will this probability be unity?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-086.jpg?height=383&width=557&top_left_y=391&top_left_x=407)

Fig. 1.23
1047.Solution:
Let the wave function be

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi(x)=e^{i k x}+R e^{-i k x}, & x<0 \\
\psi(x)=S e^{i k x}, & x>a \\
\psi(x)=A e^{i k^{\prime} x}+B e^{-i k^{\prime} x}, & 0<x<a
\end{array}
$$

where

$$
k=\frac{\sqrt{2 m E}}{\hbar}, \quad k^{\prime}=\frac{\sqrt{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}}{\hbar} .
$$

The constants $R, S, A, B$ are to be determined from the boundary conditions that $\psi(x)$ and $\psi^{\prime}(x)$ are both continuous at $x=0$ and $x=a$, which give

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
1+R=A+B \\
k(1-R)=k^{\prime}(A-B) \\
A e^{i k^{\prime} a}+B e^{-i k^{\prime} a}=S e^{i k a} \\
k^{\prime}\left(A e^{i k^{\prime} a}-B e^{-i k^{\prime} a}\right)=k S e^{i k a}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence

$$
S=\frac{4 k k^{\prime} e^{-i k a}}{\left(k+k^{\prime}\right)^{2} e^{-i k^{\prime} a}-\left(k-k^{\prime}\right)^{2} e^{i k^{\prime} a}}
$$

and the probability for transmission is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\frac{j_{t}}{j_{i}}=|S|^{2} \\
&=\frac{4 k^{2} k^{2}}{4\left(k k^{\prime} \cos k^{\prime} a\right)^{2}+\left(k^{2}-k^{\prime 2}\right)^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(k^{\prime} a\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Resonance transmission occurs when $k^{\prime} a=n \pi$, i.e., when the kinetic energy $E$ of the incident particle is

$$
E=n^{2} \pi^{2} \hbar^{2} / 2 m a^{2}-V_{0} .
$$

The probability for transmission, $P$, then becomes unity.

1048.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional square-well potential (see Fig. 1.24):

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-087.jpg?height=433&width=464&top_left_y=896&top_left_x=442)

Fig. 1.24

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=\infty, & x<0 \\
V(x)=-V_{0}, & 0<x<a \\
V(x)=0, & x>a .
\end{array}
$$

For $E<0$, find the wave function of a particle bound in this potential. Write an equation which determines the allowed values of $E$.
1048.a.Solution:
The Schrödinger equations for the different regions are

$$
\begin{gathered}
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-V_{0}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad 0<x<a,} \\
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad x>a .}
\end{gathered}
$$

$E<0$

<i> Consider first the case of $V_{0}<-E$, for which the wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sinh (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(-V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m(-E)}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

The continuity conditions of the wave function give

$$
\begin{aligned}
A \sinh (k a) &=B e^{-k^{\prime} a} \\
A k \cosh (k a) &=-B k^{\prime} e^{-k^{\prime} a}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
k \operatorname{coth}(k a)=-k^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

As $\operatorname{coth} x>0$ for $x>0$, there is no solution for this case.

<ii For $V_{0}>-E, i k \rightarrow k, k=\sqrt{2 m\left(V_{0}+E\right)} / \hbar$, and the equation determining the energy becomes $k \cot (k a)=-k^{\prime}$. The wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sin (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

From the continuity and normalization of the wave function we get

$$
A=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2}
$$

$$
B=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2} e^{k^{\prime} a} \sin (k a) .
$$
1048.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics
1048.a.Final Answer: $$\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2} e^{k^{\prime} a} \sin (k a)$$

1048.b.Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional square-well potential (see Fig. 1.24):

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-087.jpg?height=433&width=464&top_left_y=896&top_left_x=442)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=\infty, & x<0 \\
V(x)=-V_{0}, & 0<x<a \\
V(x)=0, & x>a .
\end{array}
$$

Suppose a particle with energy $E>0$ is incident upon this potential. Find the phase relation between the incident and the outgoing wave.
1048.b.Solution:
The Schrödinger equations for the different regions are

$$
\begin{gathered}
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-V_{0}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad 0<x<a,} \\
{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}-E\right] \psi(x)=0, \quad x>a .}
\end{gathered}
$$

$E<0$

<i> Consider first the case of $V_{0}<-E$, for which the wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sinh (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(-V_{0}-E\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m(-E)}{\hbar^{2}}} .
$$

The continuity conditions of the wave function give

$$
\begin{aligned}
A \sinh (k a) &=B e^{-k^{\prime} a} \\
A k \cosh (k a) &=-B k^{\prime} e^{-k^{\prime} a}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
k \operatorname{coth}(k a)=-k^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

As $\operatorname{coth} x>0$ for $x>0$, there is no solution for this case.

<ii For $V_{0}>-E, i k \rightarrow k, k=\sqrt{2 m\left(V_{0}+E\right)} / \hbar$, and the equation determining the energy becomes $k \cot (k a)=-k^{\prime}$. The wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sin (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B e^{-k^{\prime} x}, & x>a\end{cases}
$$

From the continuity and normalization of the wave function we get

$$
A=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2}
$$

$$
B=\left[\frac{2}{\frac{1}{k^{\prime}} \sin ^{2}(k a)+a-\frac{1}{2 k} \sin (2 k a)}\right]^{1 / 2} e^{k^{\prime} a} \sin (k a) .
$$$E>0$. The wave function is

$$
\psi(x)= \begin{cases}0, & x<0 \\ A \sin (k x), & 0<x<a \\ B \sin \left(k^{\prime} x+\varphi\right), & x>a\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k=\sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}{\hbar^{2}}}, \quad k^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 m E / \hbar^{2}} .
$$

As $\partial \ln \psi / \partial \ln x$ is continuous at $x=a$,

$$
(k a) \cot (k a)=\left(k^{\prime} a\right) \cot \left(k^{\prime} a+\varphi\right)
$$

whence

$$
\varphi=\operatorname{arccot}\left(\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \cot (k a)\right)-k^{\prime} a .
$$

For $x>a$,

$$
\psi(x)=\frac{B}{2 i} e^{-i k^{\prime} x-i \varphi}-\frac{B}{2 i} e^{i k^{\prime} x+i \varphi}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\varphi_{\mathrm{inc}}(x) \propto e^{-i k^{\prime} x-i \varphi} \\
&\varphi_{\text {out }}(x) \propto e^{i k^{\prime} x+i \varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the phase shift of the outgoing wave in relation to the incident wave is

$$
\delta=2 \varphi=2\left[\operatorname{arccot}\left(\frac{k}{k^{\prime}} \cot (k a)\right)-k^{\prime} a\right] .
$$

1051.Problem Statement:
Find the reflection and transmission coefficients for the one-dimensional potential step shown in Fig. $1.27$ if the particles are incident from the right.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-093.jpg?height=335&width=510&top_left_y=951&top_left_x=423)

Fig. $1.27$
1051.Solution:
As the particles are incident from the right we must have $E>V_{0}$. And there are both incident and reflected waves in the region $x>0$. The Schrödinger equation for $x>0$,

$$
\psi^{\prime \prime}(x)+k_{1}^{2} \psi(x)=0
$$

where $k_{1}=\sqrt{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)} / \hbar$, has solutions of the form

$$
\psi=\exp \left(-i k_{1} x\right)+R \exp \left(i k_{1} x\right)
$$

There are only transmitted waves in the region $x<0$, where the Schrödinger equation is

$$
\psi^{\prime \prime}(x)+k_{2}^{2} \psi(x)=0
$$

with $k_{2}=\sqrt{2 m E} / \hbar$, and has the solution

$$
\psi(x)=S \exp \left(-i k_{2} x\right)
$$

Using the continuity conditions of the wave function at $x=0$, we get $1+R=S$. From the continuity of the first derivative of the wave function, we get $k_{1}(1-R)=k_{2} S$. Hence $R=\left(k_{1}-k_{2}\right) /\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right)$, giving the reflection coefficient

$$
|R|^{2}=\left|\frac{k_{1}-k_{2}}{k_{1}+k_{2}}\right|^{2}=\frac{V_{0}^{2}}{\left(\sqrt{E}+\sqrt{E-V_{0}}\right)^{4}},
$$

and the transmission coefficient

$$
|S|^{2}=1-|R|^{2}=1-\frac{V_{0}^{2}}{\left(\sqrt{E}+\sqrt{\left.E-V_{0}\right)^{4}}\right.} .
$$

1055.a.Problem Statement:
A Schrödinger equation in one dimension reads

$$
\left(-\partial^{2} / \partial x^{2}-2 \operatorname{sech}^{2} x\right) \psi=\varepsilon \psi
$$

$(\hbar=1, m=1 / 2)$

Show that $\exp (i k x)(\tanh x+$ const) is a solution for a particular value of the constant. Calculate the S-matrix (transmission and reflection coefficients) for this problem.
1055.a.Solution:
Letting the constant in the given solution $\psi$ be $K$ and substituting $\psi$ in the Schrödinger equation, we obtain

$$
k^{2}(\tanh x+K)-2(i k+K) \operatorname{sech}^{2} x=\varepsilon(\tanh x+K)
$$

This equation is satisfied if we set $K=-i k$ and $\varepsilon=k^{2}$. Hence

$$
\psi(x)=e^{i k x}(\tanh x-i k)
$$

is a solution of the equation and the corresponding energy is $k^{2}$. Then as $\tanh x \rightarrow 1$ for $x \rightarrow \infty$ and $\tanh (-x)=-\tanh x$ we have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\psi=(1-i k) e^{i k x} \quad \text { as } \quad & x \rightarrow \infty \\
\psi=-(1+i k) e^{i k x} & \text { as } \quad x \rightarrow-\infty
\end{array}
$$

Since $V(x) \leq 0, \varepsilon>0$, the transmission coefficient is $T=1$ and the reflection coefficient is $R=0$ as the particle travels through $V(x)$. So the $S$-matrix is

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & -(1-i k) /(1+i k) \\
-(1-i k) /(1+i k) & 0
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

\psi(x)=e^{i k x}(\tanh x-i k)
$$

is a solution of the equation and the corresponding energy is $k^{2}$. Then as $\tanh x \rightarrow 1$ for $x \rightarrow \infty$ and $\tanh (-x)=-\tanh x$ we have

1057.Problem Statement:
Find the wave function for a particle moving in one dimension in a constant imaginary potential $-i V$ where $V \ll E$.

Calculate the probability current and show that an imaginary potential represents absorption of particles. Find an expression for the absorption coefficient in terms of $V$.
1057.Solution:
The Schrödinger equation is

$$
i \hbar \partial \psi / \partial t=\left(\hat{p}^{2} / 2 m-i V\right) \psi
$$

Supposing $\psi=\exp (-i E t / \hbar) \exp (i k x)$, we have $k^{2}=\left(2 m E / \hbar^{2}\right)(1+$ $i V / E)$. As $V \ll E$

$$
k \approx \pm \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}}\left(1+i \frac{V}{2 E}\right)
$$

and hence

$$
\psi_{\pm}(x, t)=\exp \left(\mp \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{2 E} x\right) \cdot \exp \left(\pm i \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} x\right) \exp \left(-\frac{i E t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

where $\psi_{+}$and $\psi_{-}$refer to the exponentially attenuated right- and lefttraveling waves respectively. The probability current is

$$
\begin{aligned}
j=& \operatorname{Re}\left(\psi^{*} \frac{\hat{p}}{m} \psi\right)=\operatorname{Re}\left(\psi^{*} \frac{\hbar k}{m} \psi\right)=\operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{\hbar k}{m} \exp \left(\mp \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{E} x\right)\right] \\
& \approx \pm \frac{\hbar}{m} \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \exp \left(\mp \sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{E} x\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

These are the exponentially attenuated currents in the respective directions. The absorption coefficient is then

$$
\mu=\left|-\frac{1}{j} \frac{d j}{d x}\right|=\left|-\frac{d \ln j}{d x}\right|=\sqrt{\frac{2 m E}{\hbar^{2}}} \frac{V}{E} .
$$

The imaginary potential $i V$ is responsible for the absorption of the particle, since the exponent in $j$ would be imaginary. Hence there would be no absorption if $V$ were real.

1058.b.Problem Statement:
Let the solution to the one-dimensional free-particle time-dependent Schrödinger equation of definite wavelength $\lambda$ be $\psi(x, t)$ as described by some observer $O$ in a frame with coordinates $(x, t)$. Now consider the same particle as described by wave function $\psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ according to observer $O^{\prime}$ with coordinates $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ related to $(x, t)$ by the Galilean transformation

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{\prime} &=x-v t, \\
t^{\prime} &=t .
\end{aligned}
$$

What is the relationship between $\psi(x, t)$ and $\psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ if both satisfy the Schrödinger equation in their respective coordinates?
1058.b.Solution:
The one-dimensional time-dependent Schrödinger equation for a free particle

$$
i \hbar \partial_{t} \psi(x, t)=\left(-\hbar^{2} / 2 m\right) \partial_{x}^{2} \psi(x, t)
$$

has a solution corresponding to a definite wavelength $\lambda$

$$
\psi_{\lambda}(x, t)=\exp [i(k x-\omega t)]
$$

with

$$
\lambda=2 \pi / k=2 \pi \hbar / p, \quad \omega=\hbar k^{2} / 2 m .
$$

As the particle momentum $p$ is different in the two reference frames, the wavelength $\lambda$ is also different.

Applying the Galilean transformation and making use of the Schrödinger equation in the $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ frame we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
i \hbar \partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) &=i \hbar \partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t) \\
&=i \hbar\left[\partial_{t}^{\prime} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)-v \partial_{x}^{\prime} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right] \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{\prime 2} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)-i \hbar v \partial_{x}^{\prime} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{2} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)-i \hbar v \partial_{x} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)
\end{aligned}
$$

Considering

$$
\begin{aligned}
&i \hbar \partial_{t}\left[e^{i(k x-\omega t)} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right] \\
&\quad=i \hbar e^{i(k x-\omega t)}\left(\partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}-i \omega \psi^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{2}\left[e^{i(k x-\omega t)} \psi^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right] \\
&\quad=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} e^{i(k x-\omega t)}\left(-k^{2} \psi^{\prime}+2 i k \partial_{x} \psi^{\prime}+\partial_{x}^{2} \psi^{\prime}\right) \\
&\quad=i \hbar e^{i(k x-\omega t)}\left(\partial_{t} \psi^{\prime}-i \omega \psi^{\prime}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

making use of Eq.
(1) and the definitions of $k$ and $\omega$, we see that

$$
\begin{array}{r}
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \partial_{x}^{2}\left[e^{i m v x / \hbar} e^{-i m v^{2} t / 2 \hbar} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)\right] \\
=i \hbar \partial_{t}\left[e^{i m v x / \hbar} e^{-i m v^{2} t / 2 \hbar} \psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t)\right]
\end{array}
$$

This is just the Schrödinger equation that $\psi(x, t)$ satisfies. Hence, accurate to a phase factor, we have the relation

$$
\psi(x, t)=\psi^{\prime}(x-v t, t) \exp \left\{\frac{i}{\hbar}\left[m v x-\frac{m v^{2}}{2} t\right]\right\}
$$
1058.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics
1058.b.Final Answer: $$\psi^{\prime}(x-v t t) \exp \left\{\frac{i}{\hbar}\left[m v x-\frac{m v^{2}}{2} t\right]\right\}$$

1059.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ bound in a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential of frequency $\omega$ and in the ground state is subjected to an impulsive force $p \delta(t)$.

Find the probability it remains in its ground state.
1059.Solution:
The particle receives an instantaneous momentum $p$ at $t=0$ and its velocity changes to $p / m$ instantaneously. The duration of the impulse is, however, too short for the wave function to change. Hence, in the view of a frame $K^{\prime}$ moving with the particle, the latter is still in the ground state of the harmonic oscillator $\psi_{0}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$. But in the view of a stationary frame $K$, it is in the state $\psi_{0}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \exp (-i p x / \hbar)$. We may reasonably treat the position of the particle as constant during the process, so that at the end of the impulse the coordinate of the particle is the same for both $K$ and $K^{\prime}$. Hence the initial wave function in $K$ is

$$
\psi_{0}^{\prime}=\psi_{0}(x) \exp (-i p x / \hbar)
$$

Thus, the probability that the particle remains in its ground state after the impulse is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{0} &=\left|\left\langle\psi_{0}\left|\exp \left(-i \frac{p x}{\hbar}\right)\right| \psi_{0}\right\rangle\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{\alpha^{2}}{\pi}\left|\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{-\alpha^{2} x^{2}-i \frac{p x}{\hbar}} d x\right|^{2} \\
&=\exp \left(-\frac{p^{2}}{2 \alpha^{2} \hbar^{2}}\right)\left|\frac{\alpha}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\alpha^{2}\left(x+\frac{i p}{2 \alpha^{2} \hbar}\right)^{2}\right] d x\right|^{2} \\
&=\exp \left(\frac{-p^{2}}{2 m \omega \hbar}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha=\sqrt{m \omega / \hbar}$.
1059.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1060.a.Problem Statement:
An idealized ping pong ball of mass $m$ is bouncing in its ground state on a recoilless table in a one-dimensional world with only a vertical direction.

Prove that the energy depends on $m, g, h$ according to: $\varepsilon=K m g$ $\left(m^{2} g / h^{2}\right)^{\alpha}$ and determine $\alpha$.
1060.a.Solution:
By the method of dimensional analysis, if we have

$$
[\varepsilon]=\frac{[m]^{1+2 \alpha}[g]^{1+\alpha}}{[h]^{2 \alpha}}
$$

or

$$
\frac{[m][L]^{2}}{[T]^{2}}=\frac{[m][L]^{1-3 \alpha}}{[T]^{2}}
$$

then $\alpha=-\frac{1}{3}$. Thus, provided $\alpha=-\frac{1}{3}$, the expression gives the energy of the ball.
1060.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1060.b.Problem Statement:
An idealized ping pong ball of mass $m$ is bouncing in its ground state on a recoilless table in a one-dimensional world with only a vertical direction.

By a variational calculation estimate the constant $K$ and evaluate $\varepsilon$ for $m=1$ gram in ergs.
1060.b.Solution:
By the method of dimensional analysis, if we have

$$
[\varepsilon]=\frac{[m]^{1+2 \alpha}[g]^{1+\alpha}}{[h]^{2 \alpha}}
$$

or

$$
\frac{[m][L]^{2}}{[T]^{2}}=\frac{[m][L]^{1-3 \alpha}}{[T]^{2}}
$$

then $\alpha=-\frac{1}{3}$. Thus, provided $\alpha=-\frac{1}{3}$, the expression gives the energy of the ball.Take the $x$ coordinate in the vertical up direction with origin at the table. The Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}+m g x=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+m g x
$$

taking the table surface as the reference point of gravitational potential. Try a ground state wave function of the form $\psi=x \exp \left(-\lambda x^{2} / 2\right)$, where $\lambda$ is to be determined. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle H\rangle &=\frac{\int \psi^{*} H \psi d x}{\int \psi^{*} \psi d x} \\
&=\frac{\int_{0}^{\infty} x e^{-\lambda x^{2} / 2}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+m g x\right) x e^{-\lambda x^{2} / 2} d x}{\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{2} e^{-\lambda x^{2}} d x} \\
&=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{4 m} \lambda+\frac{2 m g}{\sqrt{\pi} \lambda^{1 / 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

To minimize $\langle H\rangle$, take $\frac{d\langle H\rangle}{d \lambda}=0$ and obtain $\lambda=\left(\frac{4 m^{2} g}{3 \sqrt{\pi} \hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}$.

The ground state energy is then

$$
\langle H\rangle=3(3 / 4 \pi)^{1 / 3} m g\left(m^{2} g / \hbar^{2}\right)^{-1 / 3} .
$$

giving

$$
K=3(3 / 4 \pi)^{1 / 3} .
$$

Numerically

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varepsilon &=3 m g\left(\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{4 \pi m^{2} g}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \\
&=3 \times 980 \times\left(\frac{3 \times 1.054^{2} \times 10^{-54}}{4 \pi \times 980}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \\
&=1.9 \times 10^{-16} \mathrm{erg} .
\end{aligned}
$$
1060.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1061.a.Problem Statement:
The following theorem concerns the energy eigenvalues $E_{n}\left(E_{1}<E_{2}<\right.$ $E_{3}<\ldots$ ) of the Schrödinger equation in one dimension:

Theorem: If the potential $V_{1}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{1 n}$ and the potential $V_{2}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{2 n}$ and $V_{1}(x) \leq V_{2}(x)$ for all $x$, then $E_{1 n} \leq E_{2 n}$.

Prove this theorem. Hint: Consider a potential $V(\lambda, x)$, where $V(0, x)=V_{1}(x)$ and $V(1, x)$ $=V_{2}(x)$ and $\partial V / \partial \lambda \geq 0$ (for all $x$ ), and calculate $\partial E_{n} / \partial \lambda$.

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
U(x)=k x^{2} / 2, & |x|<a, \\
U(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x| \geq a .
\end{array}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-109.jpg?height=300&width=540&top_left_y=551&top_left_x=408)

Fig. $1.31$

We want to determine the number of bound states that this potential can hold. Assume this number $N$ is $\gg 1$. It may be helpful to draw a qualitative picture of the wave function for the highest bound state.

Choose a solvable comparison potential and use the theorem above to determine either a rigorous upper bound to $N$ or a rigorous lower bound to $N$.
(Both can be done but you are asked for only one.)

(Berkeley)
1061.a.Solution:
Define $V(\lambda, x)=\lambda V_{2}(x)+(1-\lambda) V_{1}(x)$. Obviously $V(0, x)=$ $V_{1}(x), V(1, x)=V_{2}(x), \partial V / \partial \lambda=V_{2}(x)-V_{1}(x) \geq 0$. The Hamiltonian is then

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)=\hat{p}^{2} / 2 m+V(\lambda, x),
$$

and the eigenequation is

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle=E_{n}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle
$$

where $E_{n}(\lambda)=\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle$. As 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial E_{n}(\lambda) / \partial \lambda &=\frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda}[\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle] \\
&=\langle n \lambda|\partial V(\lambda) / \partial \lambda| n \lambda\rangle \\
&=\int \frac{\partial V}{\partial \lambda}\left|\psi_{n}(x, \lambda)\right|^{2} d x \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $E_{1 n}=E_{n}(0) \leq E_{n}(1)=E_{2 n}$, and the theorem is proved. Note that we have used $\langle n \lambda \mid n \lambda\rangle=1$.
1061.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1061.b.Problem Statement:
The following theorem concerns the energy eigenvalues $E_{n}\left(E_{1}<E_{2}<\right.$ $E_{3}<\ldots$ ) of the Schrödinger equation in one dimension:

Theorem: If the potential $V_{1}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{1 n}$ and the potential $V_{2}(x)$ gives the eigenvalues $E_{2 n}$ and $V_{1}(x) \leq V_{2}(x)$ for all $x$, then $E_{1 n} \leq E_{2 n}$.

Now consider the potential (Fig. 1.31)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
U(x)=k x^{2} / 2, & |x|<a, \\
U(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x| \geq a .
\end{array}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-109.jpg?height=300&width=540&top_left_y=551&top_left_x=408)

Fig. $1.31$

We want to determine the number of bound states that this potential can hold. Assume this number $N$ is $\gg 1$. It may be helpful to draw a qualitative picture of the wave function for the highest bound state.

Choose a solvable comparison potential and use the theorem above to determine either a rigorous upper bound to $N$ or a rigorous lower bound to $N$.
(Both can be done but you are asked for only one.)

(Berkeley)
1061.b.Solution:
Define $V(\lambda, x)=\lambda V_{2}(x)+(1-\lambda) V_{1}(x)$. Obviously $V(0, x)=$ $V_{1}(x), V(1, x)=V_{2}(x), \partial V / \partial \lambda=V_{2}(x)-V_{1}(x) \geq 0$. The Hamiltonian is then

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)=\hat{p}^{2} / 2 m+V(\lambda, x),
$$

and the eigenequation is

$$
\hat{H}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle=E_{n}(\lambda)|n, \lambda\rangle
$$

where $E_{n}(\lambda)=\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle$. As 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial E_{n}(\lambda) / \partial \lambda &=\frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda}[\langle n, \lambda|\hat{H}(\lambda)| n, \lambda\rangle] \\
&=\langle n \lambda|\partial V(\lambda) / \partial \lambda| n \lambda\rangle \\
&=\int \frac{\partial V}{\partial \lambda}\left|\psi_{n}(x, \lambda)\right|^{2} d x \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $E_{1 n}=E_{n}(0) \leq E_{n}(1)=E_{2 n}$, and the theorem is proved. Note that we have used $\langle n \lambda \mid n \lambda\rangle=1$.Let $V(x)=k x^{2} / 2$. Then $V(x) \geq U(x)$. If $E_{n}$ is an energy level for the potential $U(x)$, then $E_{n} \leq(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega$, where $\omega=\sqrt{k / m}$. For a bound state, $E_{n} \leq k a^{2} / 2$. Solving $(N+1 / 2) \hbar \omega \leq k a^{2} / 2$, we find

$$
N \leq \frac{m \omega a^{2}}{2 \hbar}-\frac{1}{2}=\left[\frac{m \omega a^{2}}{2 \hbar}\right]
$$

where $[A]$ indicates the maximum integer that is less than $A$.

We now choose for $V(x)$ a square well of finite depth,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
V(x)=k a^{2} / 2, & |x|>a, \\
V(x)=0, & |x| \leq a .
\end{array}
$$

The number of bound states of $U(x)$ is less than that of $V(x)$, which for the latter is $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]+1$. We can take the upper bound to the number of bound states of $U(x)$ as $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]$ as for $N \gg 1$ the term 1 can be neglected. Taken together, we get that the number of bound states is between $\left[m \omega a^{2} / 2 \hbar\right]$ and $\left[2 m \omega a^{2} / \pi \hbar\right]$.
1061.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1062.Problem Statement:
For electronic states in a one-dimensional system, a simple model Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\sum_{n=1}^{N} E_{0}|n\rangle\langle n|+\sum_{n=1}^{N} W\{|n\rangle\langle n+1|+| n+1\rangle\langle n|\}
$$

where $|n\rangle$ are an orthonormal basis, $\left\langle n \mid n^{\prime}\right\rangle=\delta_{n n^{\prime}} ; E_{0}$ and $W$ are parameters. Assume periodic boundary conditions so that $|N+j\rangle=|j\rangle$. Calculate the energy levels and wave functions.
1062.Solution:
From the fact that $|n\rangle$ form a complete set of orthonormal functions, where $n=1,2,3, \ldots, N$, and

$$
\hat{H}=\sum_{n=1}^{N} E_{0}|n\rangle\langle n|+\sum_{n=1}^{N} W\{|n\rangle\langle n+1|+| n+1\rangle\langle n|\}
$$

or

$$
\hat{H}=E_{0}+W\left(A+A^{+}\right),
$$

with

$$
A \equiv \sum_{n=1}^{N}|n\rangle\left\langle n+1\left|, A^{+} \equiv \sum_{n=1}^{N}\right| n+1\right\rangle\langle n|
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
&A|n\rangle=|n-1\rangle, A^{+}|n\rangle=|n+1\rangle, \\
&A A^{+}=A^{+} A=1, \quad \text { or } \quad A^{+}=A^{-1},
\end{aligned}
$$

we know that $\hat{H}, A$ and $A^{+}$have the same eigenvectors. Hence we only need to find the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of the operator $A^{+}$to solve the problem. As

$$
A_{k^{\prime} k}=\left\langle k^{\prime}|A| k\right\rangle=\delta_{k^{\prime}, k-1}
$$

We have

$$
A=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}
0 & 1 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & \cdot & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & 0 & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & 0
\end{array}\right)_{N \times N}
$$

and so

$$
A-\lambda I=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}
-\lambda & 1 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & -\lambda & 1 & . & \cdot & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -\lambda & 1 & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot & \cdot \\
\cdot & . & \cdot & \cdot & -\lambda & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 0 & \cdot & \cdot & -\lambda
\end{array}\right)_{N \times N}
$$

i.e.,

$$
\operatorname{det}(A-\lambda I)=(-\lambda)^{N}+(-1)^{N+1}=(-1)^{N}\left(\lambda^{N}-1\right)=0
$$

giving

$$
\lambda_{j}=e^{i \theta_{j}}, \theta_{j}=\frac{2 \pi}{N} j, j=0,1,2, \ldots, N-1 .
$$

If $|E\rangle$ are the same eigenvectors of the operators $A$ and $A^{+}$, i.e.,

$$
A\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=\lambda_{j}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle, A^{+}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\lambda_{j}}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle
$$

then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H}\left|E_{j}\right\rangle &=\left[E_{0}+W\left(\lambda_{j}+\frac{1}{\lambda_{j}}\right)\right]\left|E_{j}\right\rangle \\
&=\left(E_{0}+2 W \cos \theta_{j}\right)\left|E_{j}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the eigenvalues of $\hat{H}$ are

$$
E_{j}=E_{0}+2 W \cos \theta_{j}, \quad \text { with } \quad \theta_{j}=\frac{2 \pi}{N} j, \quad(j=0,1,2, \ldots, N-1) .
$$

The corresponding eigenfunctions can be obtained from the matrix equations

$$
\left(A-\lambda_{j}\right)\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=0 .
$$

Thus

$$
\left|E_{i}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
e^{i \theta_{j}} \\
e^{i 2 \theta_{j}} \\
\vdots \\
e^{i(N-1) \theta_{j}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\left|E_{j}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{n=1}^{N} e^{i(n-1) \theta_{j}}|n\rangle
$$
1062.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

1065.d.Problem Statement:
We wish to study particle-wave propagation in a one-dimensional periodic potential constructed by iterating a "single-potential" $V(x)$ at intervals of length $l$. $V(x)$ vanishes for $|x| \geq l / 2$ and is symmetric in $x$ (i.e., $V(x)=V(-x))$. The scattering properties of $V(x)$ can be summarized as follows:

If a wave is incident from the left, $\psi_{+}(x)=\exp (i k x)$ for $x<-l / 2$, it produces a transmitted wave $\psi_{+}(x)=\exp (i k x)$ for $x>l / 2$ and a reflected wave $\psi_{-}(x)=\exp (-i k x)$ for $x<-l / 2$. Transmitted and reflected coefficients are given by

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
T(x)=\frac{\psi_{+}(|x|)}{\psi_{+}(-|x|)}=\frac{1}{2} e^{2 i k|x|}\left[e^{2 i \delta_{e}}+e^{2 i \delta_{0}}\right], & |x| \geq \frac{l}{2}, \\
R(x)=\frac{\psi_{-}(-|x|)}{\psi_{+}(-|x|)} \approx \frac{1}{2} e^{2 i k|x|}\left[e^{2 i \delta_{e}}-e^{2 i \delta_{0}}\right], & |x| \geq \frac{l}{2},
\end{array}
$$

and $\delta_{e}$ and $\delta_{0}$ are the phase shifts due to the potential $V(x)$. Take these results as given. Do not derive them.

Now consider an infinite periodic potential $V_{\infty}(x)$ constructed by iterating the potential $V(x)$ with centers separated by a distance $l$ (Fig. 1.32). Call the points at which $V_{\infty}(x)=0$ "interpotential points". We shall attempt to construct waves propagating in the potential $V_{\infty}(x)$ as superpositions of left- and right-moving waves $\phi_{+}$and $\phi_{-}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-117.jpg?height=352&width=800&top_left_y=525&top_left_x=272)

Fig. 1.32

Find the condition on $k, \delta_{e}$ and $\delta_{0}$ such that traveling waves are allowed.
1065.d.Solution:
For the wave incident from the left, the potential being $V(x)$, let

$$
\begin{gathered}
\psi_{t+}=t \phi_{+} e^{i k x}, \quad t=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i 2 \delta_{e}}+e^{i 2 \delta_{0}}\right) \\
\psi_{r-}=r \phi_{-} e^{-i k x}, \quad r=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i 2 \delta_{e}}-e^{i 2 \delta_{0}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

For the wave incident from the right, let the transmission and reflection coefficients be $t^{\prime}$ and $r^{\prime}$ respectively. It can be shown that $t^{\prime}=t, r^{\prime}=$ $-r^{*} t / t^{*}$. In the periodic potential, the transmission and reflection coefficients at adjacent interpotential points have relations $t_{n}=t_{n-1}$ and $r_{n}=r_{n-1} \exp (i 2 k l)$. So the transmission coefficient can be denoted by a single notation $t$.

The waves at adjacent interpotential points are as shown in Fig. 1.33. Obviously, only the reflection term of $\phi_{-}^{n}$ and the transmission term of $\phi_{+}^{n-1}$ contribute to $\phi_{+}^{n}$ :

$$
\phi_{+}^{n}=r_{n-1}^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n}+t \phi_{+}^{n-1} .
$$

Similarly,

$$
\phi_{-}^{n}=r_{n} \phi_{+}^{n}+t^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n+1}
$$

Thus we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{+}^{n} &=e^{i 2 k l} r_{n}^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n}+t \phi_{+}^{n-1} \\
\phi_{-}^{n} &=r_{n} \phi_{+}^{n}+t \phi_{-}^{n+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
\phi_{+}^{n-1} & \phi_{+}^{n} & \phi_{+}^{n+1} \\
\rightarrow & \rightarrow & \rightarrow \\
\leftarrow & \leftarrow & \leftarrow \\
\phi_{-}^{n-1} & \phi_{-}^{n} & \phi_{-}^{n+1}
\end{array}
$$

Fig. 1.33

With $n$ replaced by $n+1, \mathrm{Eq}$.
(1) gives

$$
\phi_{+}^{n+1}=r_{n}^{\prime} \phi_{-}^{n+1}+t \phi_{+}^{n}
$$

Equations (3),
(4),
(5) then give

$$
\phi_{+}^{n}=\frac{t\left(\phi_{+}^{n-1}+e^{i 2 k l} \phi_{+}^{n+1}\right)}{1+t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}} .
$$

Let $r_{0}=r$. Then $r_{n}=r \exp (i 2 n k l)$. Assume $r_{n}^{\prime}=-r_{n}^{*} t / t^{*}$. Then $r_{n}^{\prime}=r^{\prime} \exp (-i 2 n k l)$. Hence

$$
\phi_{+}^{n}=\frac{t\left(\phi_{+}^{n-1}+e^{i 2 k l} \phi_{+}^{n+1}\right)}{1+t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}}
$$

Similarly,

$$
\phi_{-}^{n}=\frac{t\left(\phi_{-}^{n+1}+e^{i 2 k l} \phi_{-}^{n-1}\right)}{1+t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}} .
$$

As the period of the potential is $l$, if $\psi(x)$ is the wave function in the region $\left[x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right]$, then $\psi(x-l) \exp (i \delta)$ is the wave function in the region $\left[x_{n}, x_{n+1}\right]$. Thus

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\phi_{+}^{n+1}=e^{i(\delta-k l)} \phi_{+}^{n} \\
\phi_{-}^{n+1}=e^{i(\delta+k l)} \phi_{-}^{n} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Let $c_{n}=\phi_{+}^{n} / \phi_{-}^{n}$. From (4) and (5) we obtain respectively

$$
\begin{gathered}
1=r_{n} c_{n}+t \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}, \\
\frac{\phi_{+}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}=r_{n}^{\prime} \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}+t c_{n} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Using (7),
(9) can be written as

$$
c_{n} e^{-i 2 k l} \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}=r_{n}^{\prime} \frac{\phi_{-}^{n+1}}{\phi_{-}^{n}}+t c_{n}
$$

or, using (8),

$$
c_{n} e^{-i 2 k l}\left(1-r_{n} c_{n}\right)=r_{n}^{\prime}\left(1-r_{n} c_{n}\right)+t^{2} c_{n}
$$

i.e.,

$$
r_{n} c_{n}^{2}+\left(t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}-1\right) c_{n}+r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}=0
$$

Solving for $c_{n}$ we have

$$
c_{n}=\frac{\left(1+r r^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}-t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}\right) \pm \sqrt{\Delta}}{2 r_{n}}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta &=\left(t^{2} e^{i 2 k l}-r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l}-1\right)^{2}-4 r_{n} r_{n}^{\prime} e^{i 2 k l} \\

1067.a.Problem Statement:
If $\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle$ is any eigenstate of the electric charge operator $Q$ corresponding to eigenvalue $q$, that is to say,

$$
Q\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=q\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle
$$

the "charge conjugation" operator $C$ applied to $\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle$ leads to an eigenstate $\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle$ of $Q$ corresponding to eigenvalue $-q$ :

$$
C\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle .
$$

Find the eigenvalues of the operator $C Q+Q C$.
1067.a.Solution:
Let

$$
|\psi\rangle=\sum_{q} c_{q}\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle
$$

Then

$$
(C Q+Q C)\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle=q C\left|\psi_{q}\right\rangle+Q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle=q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle-q\left|\psi_{-q}\right\rangle=0
$$

Thus the eigenvalue of the operator $C Q+Q C$ is zero.

1068.a.Problem Statement:
A quantum-mechanical system is known to possess only two energy eigenstates denoted $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$. The system also includes three other observables (besides the energy), known as $P, Q$ and $R$. The states $|1\rangle$ and |2) are normalized but they are not necessarily eigenstates of $P, Q$ or $R$. Determine as many of the eigenvalues of $P, Q$ and $R$ as possible on the basis of the following sets of "experimental data". [Warning: one data set is unphysical.]

$\langle 1|P| 1\rangle=1 / 2, \quad\left\langle 1\left|P^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=1 / 4$.
1068.a.Solution:
We are given three observables $P, Q, R$, which satisfy the Hermiticity $\langle n|P| m\rangle=\langle m|P| n\rangle^{*}$, and that the mechanical system has a complete set of energy eigenstates $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$. give

The completeness of the two states and the "experimental data",

$$
P|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle+\alpha|2\rangle,
$$

where $\alpha$ is a constant to be determined. The orthogonality of the eigenstates and the Hermiticity of $P$ give

$$
\langle 1|P| 2\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\langle 1 \mid 2\rangle+\alpha^{2}\langle 2 \mid 2\rangle=\alpha^{*} .
$$

So we have

$$
P|2\rangle=\alpha^{*}|1\rangle+\beta|2\rangle,
$$

where $\beta$ is to be determined. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
P^{2}|1\rangle &=P(P|1\rangle) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} P|1\rangle+\alpha P|2\rangle=\left(1 / 4+\alpha^{*} \alpha\right)|1\rangle+(\alpha / 2+\alpha \beta)|2\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $P^{2}|1\rangle=\frac{1}{4}$ according to experiment, $\alpha^{*} \alpha=0$ and hence $\alpha=0$. Therefore,

$$
P|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle,
$$

i.e., at least one of the eigenvalues of $P$ is $1 / 2$.

1068.c.Problem Statement:
A quantum-mechanical system is known to possess only two energy eigenstates denoted $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$. The system also includes three other observables (besides the energy), known as $P, Q$ and $R$. The states $|1\rangle$ and |2) are normalized but they are not necessarily eigenstates of $P, Q$ or $R$. Determine as many of the eigenvalues of $P, Q$ and $R$ as possible on the basis of the following sets of "experimental data". [Warning: one data set is unphysical.]

$\langle 1|R| 1\rangle=1, \quad\left\langle 1\left|R^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=5 / 4,\left\langle 1\left|R^{3}\right| 1\right\rangle=7 / 4$.
1068.c.Solution:
We are given three observables $P, Q, R$, which satisfy the Hermiticity $\langle n|P| m\rangle=\langle m|P| n\rangle^{*}$, and that the mechanical system has a complete set of energy eigenstates $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$. give

The completeness of the two states and the "experimental data",

$$
P|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle+\alpha|2\rangle,
$$

where $\alpha$ is a constant to be determined. The orthogonality of the eigenstates and the Hermiticity of $P$ give

$$
\langle 1|P| 2\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\langle 1 \mid 2\rangle+\alpha^{2}\langle 2 \mid 2\rangle=\alpha^{*} .
$$

So we have

$$
P|2\rangle=\alpha^{*}|1\rangle+\beta|2\rangle,
$$

where $\beta$ is to be determined. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
P^{2}|1\rangle &=P(P|1\rangle) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} P|1\rangle+\alpha P|2\rangle=\left(1 / 4+\alpha^{*} \alpha\right)|1\rangle+(\alpha / 2+\alpha \beta)|2\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $P^{2}|1\rangle=\frac{1}{4}$ according to experiment, $\alpha^{*} \alpha=0$ and hence $\alpha=0$. Therefore,

$$
P|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle,
$$

i.e., at least one of the eigenvalues of $P$ is $1 / 2$.Let

$$
Q|1\rangle=\frac{1}{2}|1\rangle+\gamma|2\rangle,
$$

where $\gamma$ is to be determined. By a similar procedure, we get $\gamma^{*} \gamma=1 / 6-$ $1 / 4<0$. So this data set is unphysical and the eigenvalue of $Q$ could not be determined.As $\langle 1|R| 1\rangle=1$, we can write

$$
R|1\rangle=|1\rangle+\lambda|2\rangle,
$$

where $\lambda$ is to be determined. Then

$$
\langle 1|R| 2\rangle=\langle 1 \mid 2\rangle+\lambda^{*}\langle 2 \mid 2\rangle=\lambda^{*}
$$

showing that

$$
R|2\rangle=\lambda^{*}|1\rangle+\eta|2\rangle .
$$

where $\eta$ is to be determined. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
R^{2}|1\rangle &=R|1\rangle+\lambda R|2\rangle \\
&=|1\rangle+\lambda|2\rangle+\lambda \lambda^{*}|1\rangle+\lambda \eta|2\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then as

$$
\left\langle 1\left|R^{2}\right| 1\right\rangle=1+\lambda \lambda^{*}=\frac{5}{4},
$$

we have

$$
\lambda \lambda^{*}=\frac{1}{4},
$$

and so

$$
\lambda=\frac{1}{2} \exp (i \delta),
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
R|1\rangle &=|1\rangle+\frac{1}{2} e^{i \delta}|2\rangle \\
R|2\rangle &=\frac{1}{2} e^{-i \delta}|1\rangle+\eta|2\rangle \\
R^{2}|1\rangle &=\frac{5}{4}|1\rangle+\frac{1}{2}(1+\eta) e^{i \delta}|2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows also

$$
\begin{aligned}
R^{3}|1\rangle=& \frac{5}{4} R|1\rangle+\frac{1}{2}(1+\eta) e^{i \delta} R|2\rangle \\
=& \frac{5}{4}|1\rangle+\frac{5}{8} e^{i \delta}|2\rangle+\frac{1}{4}(1+\eta)|1\rangle \\
&+\frac{1}{2}(1+\eta) \eta e^{i \delta}|2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Experimentally $\left\langle 1\left|R^{3}\right| 1\right\rangle=\frac{7}{4}$. Thus $\frac{5}{4}+\frac{1}{4}(1+\eta)=\frac{7}{4}$, giving $\eta=1$. Hence on the bases $|1\rangle$ and $|2\rangle$ the matrix of $R$ is

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \frac{1}{2} e^{-i \delta} \\
\frac{1}{2} e^{i \delta} & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

To find the eigenvalues of $R$, solve

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
1-\lambda & \frac{1}{2} e^{-i \delta} \\
\frac{1}{2} e^{i \delta} & 1-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

i.e., $(1-\lambda)^{2}-\frac{1}{4}=\left(1-\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(1-\lambda+\frac{1}{2}\right)=0$, and obtain the eigenvalues of $R=\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{2}$.

1069.Problem Statement:
For a charged particle in a magnetic field, find the commutation rules for the operators corresponding to the components of the velocity.

(Berkeley)
1069.Solution:
Suppose the magnetic field arises from a vector potential A. Then the velocity components of the particle are

$$
\hat{v}_{i}=\hat{P}_{i} / m-q A_{i} / m c .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\hat{v}_{i}, \hat{v}_{j}\right] } &=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\left[\hat{P}_{i}-\frac{q}{c} A_{i}, \hat{P}_{j}-\frac{q}{c} A_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{q}{m^{2} c}\left\{\left[\hat{p}_{j}, A_{i}\right]-\left[\hat{p}_{i}, A_{j}\right]\right\}=\frac{i \hbar q}{m c^{2}}\left(\frac{\partial A_{j}}{\partial x_{i}}-\frac{\partial A_{i}}{\partial x_{j}}\right) \\
&=\frac{i \hbar q}{m^{2} c} \sum_{k=1}^{3} \varepsilon_{i j k} B_{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\varepsilon_{i j k}$ is the Levi-Civita density, use having been made of the correspondence rule $\hat{p}_{i} \rightarrow \frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}$.

1072.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional oscillator with the Hamiltonian

$$
H=p^{2} / 2 m+m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2 .
$$

Find the time dependence of the expectation values of the "initial position" and "initial momentum" operators

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{0}=x \cos \omega t-(p / m \omega) \sin \omega t \\
&p_{0}=p \cos \omega t+m \omega x \sin \omega t
\end{aligned}
$$
1072.a.Solution:
Making use of the relation

$$
\frac{d f}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[f, H]+\frac{\partial f}{\partial t},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle x_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m \omega} \sin \omega t, H\right]-\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m} \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{m \omega} \frac{1}{i \hbar} \frac{1}{[p, H]} \sin \omega t-\frac{1}{m}\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle p_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\langle p\rangle \omega \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{1}{i \hbar}[m \omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t, H]+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[p, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle p\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{m \omega}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \sin \omega t+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the expectation values of these operators are independent of time.

1072.c.Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional oscillator with the Hamiltonian

$$
H=p^{2} / 2 m+m \omega^{2} x^{2} / 2 .
$$

Do you find your results for (a) and (b) to be compatible? Discuss.
1072.c.Solution:
Making use of the relation

$$
\frac{d f}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[f, H]+\frac{\partial f}{\partial t},
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle x_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m \omega} \sin \omega t, H\right]-\frac{\langle p\rangle}{m} \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&-\frac{1}{m \omega} \frac{1}{i \hbar} \frac{1}{[p, H]} \sin \omega t-\frac{1}{m}\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d\left\langle p_{0}\right\rangle}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\langle p\rangle \cos \omega t, H]-\langle p\rangle \omega \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{1}{i \hbar}[m \omega\langle x\rangle \sin \omega t, H]+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t \\
=& \frac{1}{i \hbar} \overline{[p, H]} \cos \omega t-\omega\langle p\rangle \sin \omega t \\
&+\frac{m \omega}{i \hbar} \overline{[x, H]} \sin \omega t+m \omega^{2}\langle x\rangle \cos \omega t=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the expectation values of these operators are independent of time.Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[x_{0}, H\right] } &=[x, H] \cos \omega t-\frac{[p, H]}{m \omega} \sin \omega t \\
&=\frac{i \hbar p}{m} \cos \omega t+i \hbar \omega x \sin \omega t \\
{\left[p_{0}, H\right] } &=[p, H] \cos \omega t+m \omega[x, H] \sin \omega t \\

&\frac{d p_{0}}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[p_{0}, H\right]+\frac{\partial p_{0}}{\partial t}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

showing that they are actually conserved.

$$

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[p_{0}, x_{0}\right]=} & {\left[p \cos \omega t+m \omega x \sin \omega t, x_{0}\right] } \\

\Delta A \cdot \Delta B \geq \frac{\hbar}{2} .

2002.Problem Statement: A 'quark' (mass $=m_{p} / 3$ ) is confined in a cubical box with sides of length 2 fermis $=2 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{~m}$. Find the excitation energy from the ground state to the first excited state in $\mathrm{MeV}$.
2002.Solution:
The energy levels in the cubical box are given by

$$
E_{n_{1} n_{2} n_{3}}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m a^{2}}\left(n_{1}^{2}+n_{2}^{2}+n_{3}^{2}\right), \quad n_{i}=1,2, \ldots
$$

Thus the energy of the ground state is $E_{111}=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a^{2}$, that of the first excited state is $E_{211}=6 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a^{2}=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / m a^{2}$. Hence the excitation energy from the ground state to the first excited state is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=3 \hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m a^{2}=\frac{1.5 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2} c^{2}}{m c^{2} a^{2}} \\
&=\frac{1.5 \pi^{2}\left(6.58 \times 10^{-22}\right)^{2} \times\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}{\left(\frac{938}{3}\right) \times\left(2 \times 10^{-15}\right)^{2}}=461 \mathrm{MeV}
\end{aligned}
$$

2004.Problem Statement: An electron is confined to the interior of a hollow spherical cavity of radius $R$ with impenetrable walls. Find an expression for the pressure exerted on the walls of the cavity by the electron in its ground state.
2004.Solution:
For the ground state, $l=0$, and if we set the radial wave function as $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$, then $\chi(r)$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d^{2} \chi}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 \mu E}{\hbar^{2}} \chi=0 & \text { for } r<R, \\
\chi=0 & \text { for } r \geq R,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mu$ is the electron rest mass. $R(r)$ is finite at $r=0$, so that $\chi(0)=0$. The solutions satisfying this condition are

$$
\chi_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{R}} \sin \frac{n \pi r}{R}, \quad(n=1,2,3, \ldots)
$$

for which

$$
E_{n}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 \mu R^{2}} n^{2} .
$$

The average force $F$ acting radially on the walls by the electron is given by

$$
F=\left\langle-\frac{\partial \hat{V}}{\partial R}\right\rangle=-\left\langle\frac{\partial \hat{H}}{\partial R}\right\rangle=-\frac{\partial}{\partial R}\langle\hat{H}\rangle=-\frac{\partial E}{\partial R} .
$$

As the electron is in the ground state, $n=1$ and

$$
F=-\partial E_{1} / \partial R=\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} / \mu R^{3} \text {. }
$$

The pressure exerted on the walls is

$$
p=F / 4 \pi R^{2}=\pi \hbar^{2} / 4 \mu R^{5} .
$$

2005.Problem Statement: A particle of mass $m$ is constrained to move between two concentric impermeable spheres of radii $r=a$ and $r=b$. There is no other potential. Find the ground state energy and normalized wave function.
2005.Solution:
Let the radial wave function of the particle be $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$. Then $\chi(r)$ satisfies the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d^{2} \chi(r)}{d r^{2}}+\left\{\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}[E-V(r)]-\frac{l(l+1)}{r^{2}}\right\} \chi(r)=0 . \\
& (a \leq r \leq b)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the ground state, $l=0$, so that only the radial wave function is non-trivial. Since $V(r)=0$, letting $K^{2}=2 m E / \hbar^{2}$, we reduce the equation to

$$
\chi^{\prime \prime}+K^{2} \chi=0
$$

with

$$
\left.\chi\right|_{r=a}=\left.\chi\right|_{r=b}=0 .
$$

$\chi(a)=0$ requires the solution to have the form

$$
\chi(r)=A \sin [K(r-a)]
$$

Then from $\chi(b)=0$, we get the possible values of $K$ :

$$
K=n \pi /(b-a), \quad(n=1,2, \ldots)
$$

For the particle in the ground state, i.e., $n=1$, we obtain the energy

$$
E=\hbar^{2} K^{2} / 2 m=\hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / 2 m(b-a)^{2} .
$$

From the normalization condition

$$
\int_{a}^{b} R^{2}(r) r^{2} d r=\int_{a}^{b} \chi^{2}(r) d r=1
$$

we get $A=\sqrt{2 /(b-a)}$. Hence for the ground state, the normalized radial wave function is

$$
R(r)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{b-a}} \frac{1}{r} \sin \frac{\pi(r-a)}{b-a},
$$

and the normalized wave function is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}} \sqrt{\frac{2}{b-a}} \frac{1}{r} \sin \frac{\pi(r-a)}{b-a} .
$$
