2006.b.Problem Statement:
The wave function of the state where the uncertainty principle minimum is realized is a Gaussian function $\exp \left(-\alpha x^{2}\right)$. Making use of this fact, but without solving any differential equation, find the value of $\alpha$.

(Berkeley)
2006.b.Solution:
The ground state of the harmonic oscillator has even parity, so that

$$
\bar{x}=\langle 0|x| 0\rangle=0, \quad \bar{p}=\langle 0|p| 0\rangle=0 ;
$$

and so

$$
\overline{\Delta p^{2}}=\overline{p^{2}}, \quad \overline{\Delta x^{2}}=\overline{x^{2}} .
$$

The uncertainty principle requires

$$
\overline{\Delta p^{2}} \cdot \overline{\Delta x^{2}} \geq \frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} .
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{E} &=\frac{\overline{p^{2}}}{2 m}+\frac{k}{2} \overline{x^{2}} \\
& \geq \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \sqrt{\overline{p^{2}} \cdot \overline{x^{2}}} \\
& \geq \frac{\hbar}{2} \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}=\hbar \omega / 2=E_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}=\omega$. Thus the energy of the ground state has the lowest value compatible with the uncertainty principle.

Using the given wave function we calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\overline{x^{2}}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2 \alpha x^{2}} x^{2} d x / \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2 \alpha x^{2}} d x=1 / 4 \alpha, \\
&\overline{p^{2}}=-\hbar^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\alpha x^{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} e^{-\alpha x^{2}} d x / \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-2 \alpha x^{2}} d x=\hbar^{2} \alpha,
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \alpha+\frac{k}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{4 \alpha} .
$$

From $\frac{d E}{d \alpha}=0$ we see that when $\alpha=\sqrt{k m} / 2 \hbar=m \omega / 2 \hbar$ the energy is minimum. Therefore $\alpha=m \omega / 2 \hbar$.

2009.a.Problem Statement:
A nonrelativistic particle of mass $m$ moves in the potential

$$
V(x, y, z)=A\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+2 \lambda x y\right)+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)
$$

where $A>0, B>0,|\lambda|<1, \mu$ is arbitrary. Find the energy eigenvalues.
2009.a.Solution:
We choose two new variables $\mu, t$ defined by

or

$$
\mu=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x+y), \quad t=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x-y),
$$

and write the potential as

$$
x=(\mu+t) / \sqrt{2}, \quad y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\mu-t),
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
V(x, y, z)=& A\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}+t^{2}+2 \mu t\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}+t^{2}-2 \mu t\right)\right.\\
&\left.+2 \lambda \cdot \frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}-t^{2}\right)\right]+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right) \\
=& A\left[(1+\lambda) \mu^{2}+(1-\lambda) t^{2}\right]+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the differentials as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial x}=& \frac{\partial}{\partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}=&\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu \partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
&+\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t \partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial y}=& \frac{\partial}{\partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y^{2}}=&\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu \partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
&-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t \partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \\
\nabla^{2}=& \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then Schrödinger equation becomes

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}}\right) \phi(\mu, t, z)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}[E-V(\mu, t, z)] \phi(\mu, t, z)=0 \text {. }
$$

Let $\phi(\mu, t, z)=U(\mu) T(t) Z(z)$. The above equation can be separated into

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} U(\mu)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{1}-A(1+\lambda) \mu^{2}\right] U(\mu)=0 \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} T(t)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{2}-A(1-\lambda) t^{2}\right] T(t)=0 \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}} Z(z)+\left(2 m / \hbar^{2}\right)\left[E_{3}-B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)\right] Z(z)=0
\end{array}
$$

with

$$
E_{1}+E_{2}+E_{3}=E .
$$

By setting $z^{\prime}=z+\mu, E_{3}^{\prime}=E_{3}+B \mu^{2}$, all the above three equations can be reduced to that for a harmonic oscillator. Thus the energy eigenvalues are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E_{1}=\left(n_{1}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{1}, \quad \omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 A}{m}(1+\lambda)} \\
& E_{2}=\left(n_{2}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{2}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 A}{m}(1-\lambda)} \\
& E_{3}=\left(n_{3}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{3}-B \mu^{2}, \quad \omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{2 B}{m}} \text {. } \\
& \left(n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}=0,1,2,3, \ldots\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
2009.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

2009.b.Problem Statement: Now consider the following modified problem with a new potential $V_{\text {new }}$ : for $z>-\mu$ and any $x$ and $y, V_{\text {new }}=V$, where $V$ is the same as in part (a) above; for $z<-\mu$ and any $x$ and $y, V_{\text {new }}=+\infty$. Find the ground state energy.

or

$$

and write the potential as

$$
x=(\mu+t) / \sqrt{2}, \quad y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\mu-t),
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
V(x, y, z)=& A\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}+t^{2}+2 \mu t\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}+t^{2}-2 \mu t\right)\right.\\
&\left.+2 \lambda \cdot \frac{1}{2}\left(\mu^{2}-t^{2}\right)\right]+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right) \\
=& A\left[(1+\lambda) \mu^{2}+(1-\lambda) t^{2}\right]+B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)

and the differentials as

$$
\begin{aligned}

&+\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t \partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial y}=& \frac{\partial}{\partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y^{2}}=&\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu \partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
&-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t \partial \mu} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \\
\nabla^{2}=& \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then Schrödinger equation becomes

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}}\right) \phi(\mu, t, z)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}[E-V(\mu, t, z)] \phi(\mu, t, z)=0 \text {. }
$$

Let $\phi(\mu, t, z)=U(\mu) T(t) Z(z)$. The above equation can be separated into

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \mu^{2}} U(\mu)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{1}-A(1+\lambda) \mu^{2}\right] U(\mu)=0 \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}} T(t)+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{2}-A(1-\lambda) t^{2}\right] T(t)=0 \\
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z^{2}} Z(z)+\left(2 m / \hbar^{2}\right)\left[E_{3}-B\left(z^{2}+2 \mu z\right)\right] Z(z)=0
\end{array}
$$

with

$$
E_{1}+E_{2}+E_{3}=E .
$$

By setting $z^{\prime}=z+\mu, E_{3}^{\prime}=E_{3}+B \mu^{2}$, all the above three equations can be reduced to that for a harmonic oscillator. Thus the energy eigenvalues are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E_{1}=\left(n_{1}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{1}, \quad \omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 A}{m}(1+\lambda)} \\
& E_{2}=\left(n_{2}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{2}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 A}{m}(1-\lambda)} \\
& E_{3}=\left(n_{3}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{3}-B \mu^{2}, \quad \omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{2 B}{m}} \text {. } \\
& \left(n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}=0,1,2,3, \ldots\right)
\end{aligned}
$$With a new potential $V_{\text {new }}$ such that for $z<-\mu, V_{\text {new }}=\infty$ and for $z>-\mu, V_{\text {new }}$ is the same as that in (a), the wave function must vanish for $z \rightarrow-\mu$. The $Z$-equation has solution

$$
Z \sim H_{n_{3}}(\zeta) e^{-\zeta^{2} / 2},
$$

where $\zeta=\left(2 m B / \hbar^{2}\right)^{1 / 4}(z+\mu), H_{n_{3}}(\zeta)$ is the $n_{3}$ th Hermite polynomial and has the parity of $n_{3}$. Hence $n_{3}$ must be an odd integer. The ground state is the state for $n_{1}=n_{2}=0$ and $n_{3}=1$, with the corresponding energy

$$
E=\hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right) / 2+3 \hbar \omega_{3} / 2-B \mu^{2} .
$$

2010.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves in the logarithmic potential

$$
V(r)=C \ln \left(r / r_{0}\right) .
$$

Show that:

All eigenstates have the same mean squared velocity. Find this mean squared velocity.

$(C U S)$
2010.a.Solution:
We have

$$
\left\langle\mathbf{v}^{2}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathbf{P}^{2} / m^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\left\langle\mathbf{P}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m^{2}} \int d^{3} \mathbf{r} \psi^{*} \mathbf{P}^{2} \psi
$$

and, for a stationary state, the virial law gives

$$
\langle\hat{T}\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\langle\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla V\rangle .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\mathbf{v}^{2}\right\rangle &=\left\langle\mathbf{P}^{2} / m^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{m} \cdot 2\langle T\rangle=\frac{1}{m}\langle\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla V\rangle \\
&=\frac{1}{m} \int d^{3} \mathbf{r} \cdot\left(r \frac{d}{d r} C \ln r / r_{0}\right) \psi^{*} \psi \\
&=\frac{C}{m} \int d^{3} \mathbf{r}|\psi|^{2}=\frac{C}{m},
\end{aligned}
$$

which is true for any eigenstate.

2011.a.Problem Statement:
Assume that the eigenstates of a hydrogen atom isolated in space are all known and designated as usual by

$$
\psi_{n l m}(r, \theta, \phi)=R_{n l}(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \phi) .
$$

Suppose the nucleus of a hydrogen atom is located at a distance $d$ from an infinite potential wall which, of course, tends to distort the hydrogen atom.

Find the explicit form of the ground state wave function of this hydrogen atom as $d$ approaches zero.
2011.a.Solution:
Choose a coordinate system with origin at the center of the nucleus and $z$-axis perpendicular to the wall surface as shown in Fig. 2.4. As $d \rightarrow 0$, the solutions of the Schrödinger equation are still $R_{n l} Y_{l m}$ in the half-space $z>0$ i.e., $0<\theta<\pi / 2$, but must satisfy the condition $\psi=0$ at $\theta=\pi / 2$ where $V=\infty$. That is, only solutions satisfying $l+m=$ odd integer are acceptable. As $|m| \leq l$, the first suitable spherical harmonic is

$$
Y_{10}=\sqrt{3 / 4 \pi} \cos \theta \text {. }
$$

2012.a.Problem Statement:
At the time $t=0$ the wave function for hydrogen atom is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, 0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}\left(2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right)
$$

where the subscripts are values of the quantum numbers $n, l, m$. Ignore spin and radiative transitions.

What is the expectation value for the energy of this system?

(Berkeley)
2012.a.Solution:
Making use of the orthonormality of the wave functions, the expectation value for the energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle=& \frac{1}{10}\left\langle 2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right| 2 E_{1} \psi_{100} \\
&\left.+E_{2} \psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} E_{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} E_{2} \psi_{21-1}\right\rangle \\
=& \frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+E_{2}+2 E_{2}+3 E_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+6 E_{2}\right) \\
=& 0.55 E_{1}=-\frac{0.55}{2} m c^{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2} \\
=&-\frac{0.55}{2} \times 0.51 \times 10^{6} \times \frac{1}{137^{2}}=-7.47 \mathrm{eV},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $E_{1}=-m e^{4} / 2 \hbar^{2}, E_{2}=\frac{1}{4} E_{1}$ for the hydrogen atom.
2012.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

2012.b.Problem Statement:
At the time $t=0$ the wave function for hydrogen atom is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, 0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}\left(2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right)
$$

where the subscripts are values of the quantum numbers $n, l, m$. Ignore spin and radiative transitions.

What is the probability of finding the system with $l=1, m=+1$ as a function of time?

(Berkeley)
2012.b.Solution:
Making use of the orthonormality of the wave functions, the expectation value for the energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle=& \frac{1}{10}\left\langle 2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right| 2 E_{1} \psi_{100} \\
&\left.+E_{2} \psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} E_{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} E_{2} \psi_{21-1}\right\rangle \\
=& \frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+E_{2}+2 E_{2}+3 E_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+6 E_{2}\right) \\
=& 0.55 E_{1}=-\frac{0.55}{2} m c^{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2} \\
=&-\frac{0.55}{2} \times 0.51 \times 10^{6} \times \frac{1}{137^{2}}=-7.47 \mathrm{eV},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $E_{1}=-m e^{4} / 2 \hbar^{2}, E_{2}=\frac{1}{4} E_{1}$ for the hydrogen atom.Since

$$
|\psi(t)\rangle=\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)|\psi(0)\rangle
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle &=\delta_{n 2}\left\langle 211\left|\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)\right| \psi(0)\right\rangle \\
&=\delta_{n 2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} E_{2} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

using the given wave function for $t=0$. Hence the probability required is

$$
P=|\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle|^{2}=\frac{1}{5} \delta_{n 2} .
$$

Thus if $n=2, P=1 / 5$; otherwise $P=0$.

2012.c.Problem Statement:
At the time $t=0$ the wave function for hydrogen atom is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, 0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}\left(2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right)
$$

where the subscripts are values of the quantum numbers $n, l, m$. Ignore spin and radiative transitions.

(Berkeley)

$$

=& \frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+E_{2}+2 E_{2}+3 E_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+6 E_{2}\right) \\
=& 0.55 E_{1}=-\frac{0.55}{2} m c^{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2} \\
=&-\frac{0.55}{2} \times 0.51 \times 10^{6} \times \frac{1}{137^{2}}=-7.47 \mathrm{eV},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $E_{1}=-m e^{4} / 2 \hbar^{2}, E_{2}=\frac{1}{4} E_{1}$ for the hydrogen atom.Since

$$
|\psi(t)\rangle=\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)|\psi(0)\rangle
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle &=\delta_{n 2}\left\langle 211\left|\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)\right| \psi(0)\right\rangle \\
&=\delta_{n 2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} E_{2} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

using the given wave function for $t=0$. Hence the probability required is

$$
P=|\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle|^{2}=\frac{1}{5} \delta_{n 2} .
$$

Thus if $n=2, P=1 / 5$; otherwise $P=0$.Let $\alpha=10^{-10} \mathrm{~cm}$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\int_{0}^{\alpha} \psi^{*} \psi r^{2} d r d \Omega \\
&=\int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{1}{10}\left(4\left|R_{10}\right|^{2}+6\left|R_{21}\right|^{2}\right) r^{2} d r
\end{aligned}
$$

making use of the given wave function as in (a). Here for the hydrogen atom

$$
\left|R_{10}\right|^{2}=\frac{4}{a^{3}} e^{-2 r / a}, \quad\left|R_{21}\right|^{2}=\frac{r^{2}}{24 a^{5}} e^{-r / 2 a}
$$

and $a=5.29 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~cm}$. As $r \leq \alpha \ll a$, we can make the approximation

$$
e^{-2 r / a} \approx 1-\frac{2 r}{a}, \quad e^{-r / 2 a}=1-\frac{r}{2 a} .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
P & \approx \frac{4}{10} \int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{4}{a^{3}}\left(1-\frac{2 r}{a}\right) r^{2} d r+\frac{6}{10} \int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{r^{2}}{24 a^{5}}\left(1-\frac{r}{2 a}\right) r^{2} d r \\
&=\left[\frac{4}{3}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{3}-2\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{4}\right] \frac{4}{10}+\frac{6}{10}\left[\frac{1}{120}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{5}-\frac{1}{288}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{6}\right] \\
& \approx \frac{8}{15}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{3} \approx 3.6 \times 10^{-6}
\end{aligned}
$$

2012.d.Problem Statement:
At the time $t=0$ the wave function for hydrogen atom is

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, 0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}\left(2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right)
$$

where the subscripts are values of the quantum numbers $n, l, m$. Ignore spin and radiative transitions.

How does this wave function evolve in time; i.e., what is $\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)$ ?

(Berkeley)
2012.d.Solution:
Making use of the orthonormality of the wave functions, the expectation value for the energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle=& \frac{1}{10}\left\langle 2 \psi_{100}+\psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} \psi_{21-1}\right| 2 E_{1} \psi_{100} \\
&\left.+E_{2} \psi_{210}+\sqrt{2} E_{2} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} E_{2} \psi_{21-1}\right\rangle \\
=& \frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+E_{2}+2 E_{2}+3 E_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{10}\left(4 E_{1}+6 E_{2}\right) \\
=& 0.55 E_{1}=-\frac{0.55}{2} m c^{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2} \\
=&-\frac{0.55}{2} \times 0.51 \times 10^{6} \times \frac{1}{137^{2}}=-7.47 \mathrm{eV},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $E_{1}=-m e^{4} / 2 \hbar^{2}, E_{2}=\frac{1}{4} E_{1}$ for the hydrogen atom.Since

$$
|\psi(t)\rangle=\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)|\psi(0)\rangle
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle &=\delta_{n 2}\left\langle 211\left|\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right)\right| \psi(0)\right\rangle \\
&=\delta_{n 2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} \exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} E_{2} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

using the given wave function for $t=0$. Hence the probability required is

$$
P=|\langle n 11 \mid \psi(t)\rangle|^{2}=\frac{1}{5} \delta_{n 2} .
$$

Thus if $n=2, P=1 / 5$; otherwise $P=0$.Let $\alpha=10^{-10} \mathrm{~cm}$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\int_{0}^{\alpha} \psi^{*} \psi r^{2} d r d \Omega \\
&=\int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{1}{10}\left(4\left|R_{10}\right|^{2}+6\left|R_{21}\right|^{2}\right) r^{2} d r
\end{aligned}
$$

making use of the given wave function as in (a). Here for the hydrogen atom

$$
\left|R_{10}\right|^{2}=\frac{4}{a^{3}} e^{-2 r / a}, \quad\left|R_{21}\right|^{2}=\frac{r^{2}}{24 a^{5}} e^{-r / 2 a}
$$

and $a=5.29 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~cm}$. As $r \leq \alpha \ll a$, we can make the approximation

$$
e^{-2 r / a} \approx 1-\frac{2 r}{a}, \quad e^{-r / 2 a}=1-\frac{r}{2 a} .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
P & \approx \frac{4}{10} \int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{4}{a^{3}}\left(1-\frac{2 r}{a}\right) r^{2} d r+\frac{6}{10} \int_{0}^{\alpha} \frac{r^{2}}{24 a^{5}}\left(1-\frac{r}{2 a}\right) r^{2} d r \\
&=\left[\frac{4}{3}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{3}-2\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{4}\right] \frac{4}{10}+\frac{6}{10}\left[\frac{1}{120}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{5}-\frac{1}{288}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{6}\right] \\
& \approx \frac{8}{15}\left(\frac{\alpha}{a}\right)^{3} \approx 3.6 \times 10^{-6}
\end{aligned}
$$The wave function at time $t$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=& \exp \left[-\frac{i}{\hbar} \hat{H} t\right] \psi(\mathbf{r}, 0) \\
=& \sqrt{\frac{1}{10}}\left[2 e^{-i \omega_{1} t} \psi_{100}+e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \psi_{210}\right.\\
&\left.+\sqrt{2} e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \psi_{211}+\sqrt{3} e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \psi_{21-1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{1}=E_{1} / \hbar, \omega_{2}=E_{2} / \hbar$.

2014.b.Problem Statement:
Consider an electron moving in a spherically symmetric potential $V=$ $k r$, where $k>0$.

Use the Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization rule to calculate the ground state energy.

(Berkeley)
2014.b.Solution:
The uncertainty principle states that

where

$$
\Delta p \Delta r \geq \frac{\hbar}{2},
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta p &=\left[\overline{(p-\bar{p})^{2}}\right]^{1 / 2}=\left[\left(\overline{p^{2}-2 p \bar{p}+\bar{p}^{2}}\right)\right]^{1 / 2} \\
&=\left(\overline{p^{2}}-\bar{p}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\Delta r=\left(\overline{r^{2}}-\bar{r}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} .
$$

The potential is spherically symmetric, so we can take $\bar{p}=0$, i.e. $\Delta p \approx$ $\sqrt{\overline{p^{2}}}$. For an estimate of the energy

$$
E=\frac{\overline{p^{2}}}{2 m}+k \bar{r}
$$

we shall also take

$$
\Delta r \sim \bar{r} .
$$

Then

$$
E \approx \frac{(\Delta p)^{2}}{2 m}+k \Delta r \geq \frac{(\Delta p)^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{k \hbar}{2 \Delta p} .
$$

For the ground state energy $E$, we have

$$
\frac{\partial E}{\partial \Delta p}=\frac{\Delta p}{m}-\frac{k \hbar}{2(\Delta p)^{2}}=0
$$

giving

$$
\Delta p=\left(\frac{m k \hbar}{2}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

and

$$
E=\frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{k^{2} \hbar^{2}}{4 m}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

The Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization rule gives

$$
\oint P_{r} d r=n_{r} h, \quad \oint P_{\phi} d \phi=n_{\phi} h
$$

Choose polar coordinates such that the particle is moving in the plane $\theta=\pi / 2$. The ground state is given by $n_{r}=0, n_{\phi}=1$, and the orbit is circular with radius $a$. The second integral gives

$$
P_{\phi}=I \omega=m a^{2} \omega=\hbar .
$$

The central force is

$$
F_{r}=-\frac{d V}{d r}=-k=-m \omega^{2} a .
$$

Combining we have $a=\left(\hbar^{2} / m k\right)^{1 / 3}$, and hence

$$
E_{0}=P_{\phi}^{2} / 2 m a^{2}+k a=\frac{3}{2}\left(k^{2} \hbar^{2} / m\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

2015.a.Problem Statement:
The interactions of heavy quarks are often approximated by a spinindependent nonrelativistic potential which is a linear function of the radial variable $r$, where $r$ is the separation of the quarks: $V(r)=A+B r$. Thus the famous "charmonium" particles, the $\psi$ and $\psi^{\prime}$, with rest energies $3.1 \mathrm{GeV}$ and $3.7 \mathrm{GeV}\left(1 \mathrm{GeV}=10^{9} \mathrm{eV}\right)$, are believed to be the $n=0$ and $n=1$ bound states of zero orbital angular momentum of a "charm" quark of mass $m_{c}=1.5 \mathrm{GeV} / c^{2}$ (i.e. $E=1.5 \mathrm{GeV}$ ) and an anti-quark of the same mass in the above linear potential. Similarly, the recently discovered upsilon particles, the $\Upsilon$ and $\Upsilon^{\prime}$, are believed to be the $n=0$ and $n=1$ zero orbital angular momentum bound states of a "bottom" quark and anti-quark pair in the same potential. The rest mass of bottom quark is $m_{b}=4.5 \mathrm{GeV} / c^{2}$. The rest energy of $\Upsilon$ is $9.5 \mathrm{GeV}$.

Using dimensional analysis, derive a relation between the energy splitting of the $\psi$ and $\psi^{\prime}$ and that of the $\Upsilon$ and $\Upsilon^{\prime}$, and thereby evaluate the rest energy of the $\Upsilon^{\prime}$.
2015.a.Solution:
In the center-of-mass system of a quark and its antiquark, the equation of relative motion is

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \nabla_{r}^{2}+V(r)\right] \psi(\mathbf{r})=E_{R} \psi(\mathbf{r}), \quad \mu=m_{q} / 2
$$

where $E_{R}$ is the relative motion energy, $m_{q}$ is the mass of the quark. When the angular momentum is zero, the above equation in spherical coordinates can be simplified to

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d}{d r}\right)+V(r)\right] R(r)=E_{R} R(r) .
$$

Let $R(r)=\chi_{0}(r) / r$. Then $\chi_{0}(r)$ satisfies

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi_{0}}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 \mu}{\hbar^{2}}\left[E_{R}-V(r)\right] \chi_{0}=0
$$

i.e.,

$$
\frac{d^{2} \chi_{0}}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2 \mu}{\hbar^{2}}\left(E_{R}-A-B r\right) \chi_{0}=0
$$

Suppose the energy of a bound state depends on the principal quantum number $n$, which is a dimensionless quantity, the constant $B$ in $V(r)$, the quark reduced mass $\mu$, and $\hbar$, namely

$$
E=f(n) B^{x} \mu^{y} \hbar^{z} .
$$

As,

$$
\begin{aligned}
{[E] } &=[M][L]^{2}[T]^{-2}, \\
{[B] } &=[M][L][T]^{-2}, \quad[\mu]=[M] \\
{[\hbar] } &=[M][L]^{2}[T]^{-1},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
x=z=\frac{2}{3}, \quad y=-\frac{1}{3}
$$

and hence

$$
E=f(n)(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}(\mu)^{-1 / 3},
$$

where $f(n)$ is a function of the principal quantum number $n$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_{\psi} &=E_{\psi^{\prime}}-E_{\psi}=f(1) \frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{c}^{1 / 3}}-f(0) \frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{c}^{1 / 3}} \\
&=\frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{c}^{1 / 3}}[f(1)-f(0)]
\end{aligned}
$$

and similarly

$$
\Delta E_{\Upsilon}=\frac{(B \hbar)^{2 / 3}}{\mu_{b}^{1 / 3}}[f(1)-f(0)]
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{\Delta E_{\Upsilon}}{\Delta E_{\psi}}=\left(\frac{\mu_{c}}{\mu_{b}}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{1 / 3} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\Upsilon^{\prime}}-E_{\Upsilon} & \approx 0.42 \mathrm{GeV} \\
E_{\Upsilon^{\prime}} &=E_{\Upsilon}+0.42=9.5+0.42 \approx 9.9 \mathrm{GeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

2018.a.Problem Statement:
A spinless particle of mass $m$ is subject (in 3 dimensions) to a spherically symmetric attractive square-well potential of radius $r_{0}$.

What is the minimum depth of the potential needed to achieve two bound states of zero angular momentum?

(Berkeley)
2018.a.Solution:
The attractive potential may be represented by $V=-V_{0}$, where $V_{0}$ is a positive constant. For bound states $0>E>-V_{0}$. Thus for $l=0$ the radial wave function $R(r)=\chi(r) / r$ satisfies the equations

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \chi}{d r^{2}}-V_{0} \chi=E \chi, & \left(0<r<r_{0}\right) \\
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \chi}{d r^{2}}=E \chi, & \left(r_{0}<r<\infty\right)
\end{array}
$$

with $\chi(0)=0$ and $\chi(\infty)$ finite. To suit these conditions the wave function may be chosen as follows:

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\chi(r)=\sin \alpha r, & 0<r<r_{0}, \\
\chi(r)=B \exp (-\beta r), & r_{0}<r<\infty
\end{array}
$$

where $\alpha=\frac{1}{\hbar} \sqrt{2 m\left(E+V_{0}\right)}, \beta=\frac{1}{\hbar} \sqrt{-2 m E}$.

From the boundary condition that at $r=r_{0}, \chi$ and $\chi^{\prime}$ should be continuous we get $-\alpha \cot \alpha r_{0}=\beta$. Defining $\xi=\alpha r_{0}, \eta=\beta r_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi^{2}+\eta^{2} &=2 m V_{0} r_{0}^{2} / \hbar^{2}, \\
-\xi \cot \xi &=\eta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Each set of the positive numbers $\xi, \eta$ satisfying these equations gives a bound state. In Fig. $2.6$ curve 1 represents $\eta=-\xi$ cot $\xi$ and curve 2, $\xi^{2}+\eta^{2}=2^{2}$, for example. As shown in the figure, for a given value of $V_{0}$, to have two intersections in the quadrant we require

$$
\frac{2 m V_{0} r_{0}^{2}}{\hbar^{2}} \geq\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)^{2}
$$

or

$$
V_{0} \geq \frac{9 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{8 m r_{0}^{2}},
$$

which is the minimum potential depth needed to achieve two bound states of zero angular momentum.

2021.Problem Statement:
Calculate Green's function for a nonrelativistic electron in the potential

$$
\begin{aligned}
& V(x, y, z)=\infty, \quad x \leq 0, \quad(\text { any } y, z) \\
& V(x, y, z)=0, \quad x>0, \quad(\text { any } y, z)
\end{aligned}
$$

and evaluate $\left|G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)\right|^{2}$. Describe the evolution in time of the pattern of probability and interpret physically the reason for this behavior.

(Berkeley)
2021.Solution:
The potential in this problem can be replaced by the boundary condition $G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)=0$ and $x=0$. The boundary problem can then be solved by the method of images. Suppose at $\mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime}$ is the image of the electron at $\mathbf{r}^{\prime}$ about $x=0$. Then

$$
\left(i \hbar \partial_{t}-H\right) G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)=\delta(t)\left[\delta\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)-\delta\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right] .
$$

The Green's function is zero for $x \leq 0$ and for $x \geq 0$ is equal to the $x>0$ part of the solution of (1). Let

$$
G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{4}} \int d^{3} k \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}-i \omega t} \bar{G}\left(\mathbf{k}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, \omega\right) d \omega
$$

We have $i \hbar \partial_{t} G=\hbar \omega G$ and $H=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}$, and the substitution of (2) in (1) gives

$$
\bar{G}\left(\mathbf{k}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, \omega\right)=\frac{1}{\hbar \omega-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}}\left(e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}}-e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime}}\right) .
$$

Re-substituting (3) in (2) gives

$$
G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{4}} \int d^{3} k \int_{\Gamma} e^{i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}-i \omega t} \frac{\left(e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}}-e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime}}\right)}{\hbar \omega-\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}} d \omega .
$$

We first integrate with respect to $\omega$. The path $\Gamma$ is chosen to satisfy the causality condition.

Causality requires that when $t<0, G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)=0$. First let the polar point of $\omega$ shift a little, say by $-i \varepsilon$, where $\varepsilon$ is a small positive number. Finally letting $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right) &=\frac{-i}{\hbar(2 \pi)^{3}} \int \exp \left(i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}-i \frac{\hbar k^{2}}{2 m} t\right)\left(e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}}-e^{-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime}}\right) d^{3} k \\
&=\frac{1}{\hbar}\left[\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar t}\right]^{3 / 2}\left\{\exp \left[\frac{i m\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\right]-\exp \left[\frac{i m\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime}\right)^{2}}{2 \hbar t}\right]\right\}_{(5)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence when both $x$ and $t$ are greater than zero, the Green's function is given by (5); otherwise, it is zero. When $x>0$ and $t>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)\right|^{2}=& \frac{1}{\hbar^{2}}\left[\frac{m}{2 \pi \hbar t}\right]^{3} \\
& \times\left\{2-2 R e \exp \left(\frac{i m}{2 \hbar t}\left[\mathbf{r}^{\prime 2}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime 2}-2 \mathbf{r} \cdot\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right]\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

If the potential $V(x, y, z)$ were absent, the Green's function for the free space, $\left|G\left(\mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r}^{\prime}, t\right)\right|^{2}$, would be proportional to $t^{-3}$. But because of the presence of the reflection wall the interference term occurs.

An electron moves above an impenetrable conducting surface. It is attracted toward this surface by its own image charge so that classically it bounces along the surface as shown in Fig. 2.13.

(Call $y$ the distance above the surface.) Ignore inertial effects of the image.

What is the $x$ and $z$ dependence of the eigenstates?

Figure $2.14$ shows the electron and its image. Accordingly the electric energy for the system is $V(r)=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i} q_{i} V_{i}=\frac{1}{2}\left[e \cdot \frac{-e}{2 y}+(-e) \cdot \frac{e}{2 y}\right]=$ $-e^{2} / 4 y$. The Schrödinger equation is then

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}-\frac{e^{2}}{4 y}\right) \psi(x, y, z)=E \psi(x, y, z) .
$$

Separating the variables by assuming solutions of the type

$$
\psi(x, y, z) \equiv \psi_{n}(y) \phi(x, z) \equiv \psi_{n}(y) \phi_{x}(x) \phi_{z}(z)
$$

we can write the above equation as

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d y^{2}} \psi_{n}(y)-\frac{e^{2}}{4 y} \psi_{n}(y)=E_{y} \psi_{n}(y)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \phi_{x}(x) &=\frac{p_{x}^{2}}{2 m} \phi_{x}(x) \\
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d z^{2}} \phi_{z}(z) &=\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m} \phi_{z}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
E_{y}+\frac{p_{x}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m}=E .
$$

Note that since $V(y)=-\frac{e^{2}}{4 y}$ depends on $y$ only, $p_{x}$ and $p_{z}$ are constants of the motion. Hence

$$
\phi(x, z) \equiv \phi_{x}(x) \phi_{z}(z) \sim e^{i\left(p_{x} x+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar}
$$

and

$$
\psi(x, y, z) \equiv \psi_{n}(y) e^{i\left(p_{x} x+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar}
$$

3004.Problem Statement:
A certain state $|\psi\rangle$ is an eigenstate of $\hat{\mathbf{L}}^{2}$ and $\hat{L}_{z}$ :

$$
\hat{\mathbf{L}}^{2}|\psi\rangle=l(l+1) \hbar^{2}|\psi\rangle, \quad \hat{L}_{z}|\psi\rangle=m \hbar|\psi\rangle .
$$

For this state calculate $\left\langle\hat{L}_{x}\right\rangle$ and $\left\langle\hat{L}_{x}^{2}\right\rangle$.
3004.Solution:
As $\hat{L}_{z}$ is a Hermitian operator, we have

$$
\hat{L}_{z}|\psi\rangle=m \hbar|\psi\rangle \rightarrow\langle\psi| \hat{L}_{z}=m \hbar\langle\psi| .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\hat{L}_{x}\right\rangle &=\left\langle\psi\left|\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[\hat{L}_{y}, \hat{L}_{z}\right]\right| \psi\right\rangle=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left\langle\psi\left|\hat{L}_{y} \hat{L}_{z}-\hat{L}_{z} \hat{L}_{y}\right| \psi\right\rangle \\
&=\frac{m \hbar}{i \hbar}\left(\left\langle\psi\left|\hat{L}_{y}\right| \psi\right\rangle-\left\langle\psi\left|\hat{L}_{y}\right| \psi\right\rangle\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Considering the symmetry with respect to $x, y$, we have

$$
\left\langle\hat{L}_{x}^{2}\right\rangle=\left\langle\hat{L}_{y}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\hat{L}_{x}^{2}+\hat{L}_{y}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\hat{\mathbf{L}}^{2}-\hat{L}_{z}^{2}\right\rangle,
$$

and so

$$
\left\langle\hat{L}_{x}^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\psi\left|\hat{\mathbf{L}}^{2}-\hat{L}_{z}^{2}\right| \psi\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\left[l(l+1)-m^{2}\right] \hbar^{2} .
$$

It can also be calculated using the "raising" and "lowering" operators.

3005.Problem Statement: The spin functions for a free electron in a basis where $\hat{s}_{z}$ is diagonal can be written as $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ with eigenvalues of $\hat{s}_{z}$ being $+1 / 2$ and $-1 / 2$ respectively. Using this basis find a normalized eigenfunction of $\hat{s}_{y}$ with eigenvalue $-1 / 2$
3005.Solution:
In the diagonal representation of $\hat{s}^{2}, \hat{s}_{z}$, we can represent $\hat{s}_{y}$ by

$$
\hat{s}_{y}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad(\hbar=1) .
$$

Let the required eigenfunction of $\hat{s}_{y}$ be $\sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$. Then as

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right),
$$

we have $a=i b$, and so $\sigma_{y}=b\left(\begin{array}{l}i \\ 1\end{array}\right)$

Normalization

$$
\sigma_{y}^{+} \sigma_{y}=b^{2}(-i, 1)\left(\begin{array}{c}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)=2 b^{2}=1
$$

gives $b=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$. Hence

$$
\sigma_{y}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

3006.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a spinless particle represented by the wave function

$$
\psi=K(x+y+2 z) e^{-\alpha r}
$$

where $r=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}$, and $K$ and $\alpha$ are real constants.

What is the total angular momentum of the particle?

You may find the following expressions for the first few spherical harmonics useful:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&Y_{0}^{0}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{4 \pi}}, \quad Y_{1}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sqrt{\frac{3}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi}, \\
&Y_{1}^{0}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4 \pi}} \cos \theta, \quad Y_{2}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sqrt{\frac{15}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta \cos \theta e^{\pm i \phi} .
\end{aligned}
$$
3006.a.Solution:
The wave function may be rewritten in spherical coordinates as

$$
\psi=K r(\cos \phi \sin \theta+\sin \phi \sin \theta+2 \cos \theta) e^{-\alpha r}
$$

its angular part being

$$
\psi(\theta, \phi)=K^{\prime}(\cos \phi \sin \theta+\sin \phi \sin \theta+2 \cos \theta),
$$

where $K^{\prime}$ is the normalization constant such that

$$
K^{\prime 2} \int_{\theta}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \sin \theta(\cos \phi \sin \theta+\sin \phi \sin \theta+2 \cos \theta)^{2} d \phi=1 \text {. }
$$

Since

$$
\cos \phi=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i \phi}+e^{-i \phi}\right), \quad \sin \phi=\frac{1}{2 i}\left(e^{i \phi}-e^{-i \phi}\right)
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\theta, \phi) &=K^{\prime}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i \phi}+e^{-i \phi}\right) \sin \theta+\frac{1}{2 i}\left(e^{i \phi}-e^{-i \phi}\right) \sin \theta+\cos 2 \theta\right], \\
&=K^{\prime}\left[-\frac{1}{2}(1-i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{1}+\frac{1}{2}(1+i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{-1}+2 \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{0}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The normalization condition and the orthonormality of $Y_{l}^{m}$ then give

$$
K^{\prime 2}\left[\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}+4 \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3}\right]=1
$$

or

$$
K^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{8 \pi}},
$$

and thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\theta, \phi)=& \sqrt{\frac{1}{8 \pi}}\left[-\frac{1}{2}(1-i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{1}\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{1}{2}(1+i) \sqrt{\frac{8 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{-1}+2 \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{3}} Y_{1}^{0}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The total angular momentum of the particle is

$$
\sqrt{\left\langle\mathbf{L}^{2}\right\rangle}=\sqrt{l(l+1)} \hbar=\sqrt{2} \hbar .
$$

as the wave function corresponds to $l=1$.

&\left.+4 \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3}(0)\left(Y_{1}^{0}\right)^{2}\right] \\
=& \frac{1}{8 \pi}\left[\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}(+\hbar)+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}(-\hbar)\right]=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$The probability of finding $L_{z}=+\hbar$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\left|\left\langle L_{z}=+\hbar \mid \psi(\theta, \phi)\right\rangle\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{8 \pi} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8 \pi}{3}=\frac{1}{6} .
\end{aligned}
$$The probability of finding the particle in the solid angle $d \Omega$ at $\theta, \varphi$ is

$$
\int \psi^{*}(\theta, \varphi) \psi(\theta, \varphi) d \Omega=\frac{1}{8 \pi}[\sin \theta(\sin \phi+\cos \phi)+2 \cos \theta]^{2} d \Omega .
$$
3006.d.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3007.Problem Statement: A particle in a central potential has an orbital angular momentum $l=2 \hbar$ and a spin $s=1 \hbar$. Find the energy levels and degeneracies associated with a spin-orbit interaction term of the form $H_{s 0}=A \mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{S}$, where $A$ is a constant.
3007.Solution:
Choose $\left\{H, \mathbf{J}^{2}, J_{z}, \mathbf{L}^{2}, \mathbf{S}^{2}\right\}$ as a complete set of mechanical variables. The wave function associated with angle and spin is $\phi_{j m_{j} l s}$, for which

with

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathbf{J}^{2} \phi_{j m_{j} l s}=\hbar^{2} j(j+1) \phi_{j m_{j} l s}, & \mathbf{L}^{2} \phi_{j m_{j} l s}=\hbar^{2} l(l+1) \phi_{j m_{j} l s} \\
\mathbf{S}^{2} \phi_{j m_{j} l s}=\hbar^{2} s(s+1) \phi_{j m_{j} l s}, & J_{z} \phi_{j m_{j} l s}=\hbar m_{j} \phi_{j m_{j} l s}
\end{array}
$$

$$
H_{s 0}=A \mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{S}=\frac{1}{2} A\left(\mathbf{J}^{2}-\mathbf{L}^{2}-\mathbf{S}^{2}\right),
$$

as $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{L}+\mathbf{S}$. Thus the energy levels and degeneracies are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{s 0} &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2} A[j(j+1)-l(l+1)-s(s+1)] \\
&= \begin{cases}2 A \hbar^{2}, & j=3 \\
-A \hbar^{2}, & j=2 \\
-3 A \hbar^{2}, & j=1\end{cases} \\
d=2 j+1 &= \begin{cases}7, & j=3 \\
5, & j=2 \\
3, & j=1\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

3009.b.Problem Statement:
Suppose an electron is in a state described by the wave function

$$
\psi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}}\left(e^{i \phi} \sin \theta+\cos \theta\right) g(r)
$$

where

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty}|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r=1
$$

and $\phi, \theta$ are the azimuth and polar angles respectively.

What is the probability of obtaining each of the possible results in part (a)?
3009.b.Solution:
As

$$
Y_{10}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4 \pi}} \cos \theta, Y_{1, \pm 1}=\mp \sqrt{\frac{3}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi},
$$

the wave function can be written as

$$
\psi=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(-\sqrt{2} Y_{11}+Y_{10}\right) g(r)
$$

Hence the possible values of $L_{z}$ are $+\hbar, 0$.

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int|\psi|^{2} d r &=\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int_{0}^{\infty}|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r \int_{0}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi}(1+\cos \phi \sin 2 \theta) \sin \theta d \phi \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta d \theta=1
\end{aligned}
$$

the given wave function is normalized. The probability density is then given by $P=|\psi|^{2}$. Thus the probability of $L_{z}=+\hbar$ is $\left(\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\right)^{2}$ or $2 / 3$ and that of $L_{z}=0$ is $\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}$ or $1 / 3$.
3009.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3009.c.Problem Statement:
Suppose an electron is in a state described by the wave function

$$
\psi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}}\left(e^{i \phi} \sin \theta+\cos \theta\right) g(r)
$$

where

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty}|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r=1
$$

and $\phi, \theta$ are the azimuth and polar angles respectively.

What is the expectation value of $L_{z}$ ?
3009.c.Solution:
As

$$
Y_{10}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4 \pi}} \cos \theta, Y_{1, \pm 1}=\mp \sqrt{\frac{3}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi},
$$

the wave function can be written as

$$
\psi=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(-\sqrt{2} Y_{11}+Y_{10}\right) g(r)
$$

Hence the possible values of $L_{z}$ are $+\hbar, 0$.

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int|\psi|^{2} d r &=\frac{1}{4 \pi} \int_{0}^{\infty}|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r \int_{0}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi}(1+\cos \phi \sin 2 \theta) \sin \theta d \phi \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta d \theta=1
\end{aligned}
$$

the given wave function is normalized. The probability density is then given by $P=|\psi|^{2}$. Thus the probability of $L_{z}=+\hbar$ is $\left(\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\right)^{2}$ or $2 / 3$ and that of $L_{z}=0$ is $\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}$ or $1 / 3$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int \psi^{*} L_{z} \psi r^{2} \sin \theta d \theta d \phi d r=& \int\left[\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(-\sqrt{2} Y_{11}+Y_{10}\right)\right]^{*} \\
& \times \hat{L}_{z}\left[\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(-\sqrt{2} Y_{11}+Y_{10}\right)\right] \\
& \times|g(r)|^{2} r^{2} d r \sin \theta d \theta d \phi \\
=& \frac{2}{3} \hbar \int_{0}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} Y_{11}^{2} d \phi=\frac{2}{3} \hbar
\end{aligned}
$$

3015.a.Problem Statement: Determine the energy levels of a particle bound by the isotropic potential $V(r)=k r^{2} / 2$, where $k$ is a positive constant.
3015.a.Solution:
The Hamiltonian is

$$
\hat{H}=-\left(\hbar^{2} / 2 m\right) \nabla^{2}+k r^{2} / 2 .
$$

Choose $\left(\hat{H}, \hat{l}^{2}, \hat{l}_{z}\right)$ to have common eigenstates. The energy levels of bound states are given by

$$
E=\left(2 n_{r}+l+3 / 2\right) \hbar \omega_{0}=(N+3 / 2) \hbar \omega_{0}, \quad \omega_{0}=\sqrt{k / m} .
$$

3016.Problem Statement: The ground state of the realistic helium atom is of course nondegenerate. However, consider a hypothetical helium atom in which the two electrons are replaced by two identical, spin-one particles of negative charge. Neglect spin-dependent forces. For this hypothetical atom, what is the degeneracy of the ground state? Give your reasoning.
3016.Solution:
The two new particles are Bosons; thus the wave function must be symmetrical. In the ground state, the two particles must stay in 1s orbit. Then the space wave function is symmetrical, and consequently the spin wave function is symmetrical too. As $s_{1}=1$ and $s_{2}=1$, the total $S$ has three possible values:

$S=2$, the spin wave function is symmetric and its degeneracy is $2 S+1=5$.

$S=1$, the spin wave function is antisymmetric and its degeneracy is $2 S+1=3$.

$S=0$, the spin wave function is symmetric and its degeneracy is $2 S+1=1$

If the spin-dependent forces are neglected, the degeneracy of the ground state is $5+3+1=9$.
3016.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3017.b.Problem Statement:
The $z$-component of the spin of an electron in free space (no electromagnetic fields) is measured and found to be $+\hbar / 2$.

What is the probability of finding these various results?

(Berkeley)
3017.b.Solution:
In the $\sigma_{z}$ representation, the spin wave function is $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$, the eigenfunctions of $\sigma_{x}$ are $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1\end{array}\right), \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -1\end{array}\right)$, corresponding to eigenvalues $+1,-1$ respectively. Expanding $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ in these two states, we see that the possible results of a measurement of $s_{x}$ are $\pm \hbar / 2$ since $\hat{s}_{x}=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{x}$, the mean value being zero:

$$
\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle=(1,0) \hat{s}_{x}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The probabilities of finding the result to be $+\frac{\hbar}{2}$ and $-\frac{\hbar}{2}$ are $P_{+}$and $P_{-}$respectively:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&P_{+}=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}, \\
&P_{-}=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,-1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
3017.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3017.c.Problem Statement:
The $z$-component of the spin of an electron in free space (no electromagnetic fields) is measured and found to be $+\hbar / 2$.

If the axis defining the measured spin direction makes an angle $\theta$ with respect to the original $z$-axis, what is the probability of the various possible results?

(Berkeley)

3017.d.Problem Statement:
The $z$-component of the spin of an electron in free space (no electromagnetic fields) is measured and found to be $+\hbar / 2$.

What is the expectation value of the spin measurement in (c)?

(Berkeley)
3017.d.Solution:
In the $\sigma_{z}$ representation, the spin wave function is $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$, the eigenfunctions of $\sigma_{x}$ are $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1\end{array}\right), \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -1\end{array}\right)$, corresponding to eigenvalues $+1,-1$ respectively. Expanding $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$ in these two states, we see that the possible results of a measurement of $s_{x}$ are $\pm \hbar / 2$ since $\hat{s}_{x}=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{x}$, the mean value being zero:

$$
\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle=(1,0) \hat{s}_{x}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The probabilities of finding the result to be $+\frac{\hbar}{2}$ and $-\frac{\hbar}{2}$ are $P_{+}$and $P_{-}$respectively:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&P_{+}=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}, \\
&P_{-}=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,-1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$Suppose the spin axis is $\mathbf{n}=\mathbf{n}(\theta, \varphi)=.(\sin \theta \cos \varphi, \sin \theta \sin \varphi$, $\cos \theta)$. Then the eigenstates for $s_{n}=\mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{n}$ are

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} e^{-i \varphi / 2} \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2} e^{i \varphi / 2}
\end{array}\right),\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sin \frac{\theta}{2} e^{-i \varphi / 2} \\
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} e^{i \varphi / 2}
\end{array}\right),
$$

corresponding to eigenvalues $+\hbar / 2$ and $-\hbar / 2$ respectively. The probability of finding the eigenvalues $+\hbar / 2$ and $-\hbar / 2$ are $\cos ^{2}(\theta / 2)$ and $\sin ^{2}(\theta / 2)$ respectively.The expectation value of the spin is

$$
\frac{\hbar}{2} P_{+}+\left(-\frac{\hbar}{2}\right) P_{-}=\frac{\hbar}{2} \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}-\frac{\hbar}{2} \sin ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}=\frac{\hbar}{2} \cos \theta
$$
3017.d.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3018.b.Problem Statement:
Assume that the system is in a state corresponding to the upper eigenvalue. What is the probability that a measurement of $\hat{s}_{y}$ will yield the value $\hbar / 2$ ? The Pauli matrices are

$$
\sigma_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right) .
$$
3018.b.Solution:
Using the definition of angular momentum operators let

$$
\hat{T}=A \hat{s}_{y}+B \hat{s}_{z}=A \frac{1}{2} \hbar \sigma_{y}+B \frac{1}{2} \hbar \sigma_{z}
$$

Then

$$
(\hat{T})^{2}=\frac{1}{4} \hbar^{2}\left(A^{2}+B^{2}+A B\left\{\sigma_{y}, \sigma_{z}\right\}\right)=\frac{1}{4} \hbar^{2}\left(A^{2}+B^{2}\right)
$$

as

$$
\sigma_{i}^{2}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)=I, \quad i=1,2,3,
$$

and

$$
\left\{\sigma_{i}, \sigma_{j}\right\} \equiv \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}+\sigma_{j} \sigma_{i}=2 \delta_{i j} \text {. }
$$

Hence the two eigenvalues of $\hat{T}$ are

$$
T_{1}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}, \quad T_{2}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}} .
$$

In the representation of $\hat{\mathbf{s}}^{2}$ and $\hat{s}_{z}$,

$$
\hat{T}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(A \sigma_{y}+B \sigma_{z}\right)=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
B & -i A \\
i A & -B
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Let the eigenvector be $\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$. Then the eigenequation is

$$
\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
B & -i A \\
i A & -B
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=T\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)
$$

where

$$
T=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\pm \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}} & 0 \\
0 & \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
B \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}} & -i A \\
i A & -B \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

Hence

$$
a: b=i A: B \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}},
$$

and so the normalized eigenvector is

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\left[\frac{1}{A^{2}+\left(B \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}\right)^{2}}\right]^{1 / 2}\left(\begin{array}{c}
+i A \\
B \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

In the representation of $\hat{s}^{2}$ and $\hat{s}_{z}$, the eigenvector of $\hat{s}_{y}$ is

$$
\left|s_{y}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-i \\
1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Hence the probability of finding $s_{y}=\hbar / 2$ is

$$
P_{\mp}=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(i 1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2}=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(i a+b)^{2}\right|^{2}=\frac{\left(B \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}-A\right)^{2}}{2\left[\left(B \mp \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}\right)^{2}+A^{2}\right]} .
$$

Note that $P_{-}$is the probability corresponding to the system in the state of eigenvalue $T=\hbar \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}} / 2$, and $P_{+}$is that corresponding to the state of $T=-\hbar \sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}} / 2$.
3018.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3019.Problem Statement:
A system of three (non-identical) spin one-half particles, whose spin operators are $\mathbf{s}_{1}, \mathbf{s}_{2}$ and $\mathbf{s}_{3}$, is governed by the Hamiltonian

$$
H=A \mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2} / \hbar^{2}+B\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right) \cdot \mathbf{s}_{3} / \hbar^{2} .
$$

Find the energy levels and their degeneracies.
3019.Solution:
Using a complete set of dynamical variables of the system $\left(H, \mathrm{~s}_{12}^{2}\right.$, $\left.\mathbf{s}^{2}, s_{3}\right)$, where $\mathbf{s}_{12}=\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}, \mathbf{s}=\mathbf{s}_{12}+\mathbf{s}_{3}=\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}+\mathbf{s}_{3}$, the eigenfunction is $\left|s_{12} s_{3} s m_{s}\right\rangle$, and the stationary state equation is

$$
\hat{H}\left|s_{12} s_{3} s m_{s}\right\rangle=E\left|s_{12} s_{3} s m_{s}\right\rangle .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{s}_{1}^{2} &=\mathbf{s}_{2}^{2}=\mathbf{s}_{3}^{2}=\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right), \\
\mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{s}_{12}^{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}^{2}-\mathbf{s}_{2}^{2}\right) \\
\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right) \cdot \mathbf{s}_{3} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{s}^{2}-\mathbf{s}_{12}^{2}-\mathbf{s}_{3}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H}=& \frac{A}{\hbar^{2}} \mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2}+\frac{B}{\hbar^{2}}\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right) \cdot \mathbf{s}_{3} \\
=& \frac{A}{2}\left[\frac{1}{\hbar^{2}} \mathbf{s}_{12}^{2}-\frac{3}{4}-\frac{3}{4}\right] \\
&+\frac{B}{2}\left[\frac{1}{\hbar^{2}} \mathbf{s}^{2}-\frac{1}{\hbar^{2}} \mathbf{s}_{12}^{2}-\frac{3}{4}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Now as the expectation value of $\mathbf{s}$ is $s(s+1)$, etc., we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H}\left|s_{12} s_{3} s m_{s}\right\rangle=&\left\{\frac{A}{2}\left[s_{12}\left(s_{12}+1\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right]\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{B}{2}\left[s(s+1)-s_{12}\left(s_{12}+1\right)-\frac{3}{4}\right]\right\}\left|s_{12} s_{3} s m_{s}\right\rangle,
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=& \frac{A}{2}\left[s_{12}\left(s_{12}+1\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \\
&+\frac{B}{2}\left[s(s+1)-s_{12}\left(s_{12}+1\right)-\frac{3}{4}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that for $s_{12}=0, s=1 / 2: E=-3 A / 4$, the degeneracy of the energy level, $2 s+1$, is 2 ; for $s_{12}=1, s=1 / 2: E=A / 4-B$, the degeneracy of the energy level, is 2 ; for $s_{12}=1, s=3 / 2: E=A / 4+B / 2$, the degeneracy of the energy level is 4 .
3019.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3020.Problem Statement: A particle of spin one is subject to the Hamiltonian $H=A s_{z}+B s_{x}^{2}$, where $A$ and $B$ are constants. Calculate the energy levels of this system. If at time zero the spin is in an eigenstate of $s$ with $s_{z}=+\hbar$, calculate the expectation value of the spin at time $t$.
3020.Solution:
We first find the stationary energy levels of the system. The stationary Schrödinger equation is

$$
E \psi=\hat{H} \psi=\left(A s_{z}+B s_{x}^{2}\right) \psi
$$

where

$$
\psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}
u_{1} \\
u_{2} \\
u_{3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

is a vector in the spin space. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
s_{x} &=\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -i \\
0 & i & 0
\end{array}\right) \hbar, \\
s_{z} &=\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
0 & -i & 0 \\
i & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right) \hbar, \\
s_{x}^{2} &=\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right) \hbar^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\hat{H}=A s_{z}+B s_{x}^{2}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -i A^{\prime} & 0 \\
i A^{\prime} & B^{\prime} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & B^{\prime}
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $A^{\prime}=A \hbar, B^{\prime}=B \hbar^{2}$. The energy levels are given by the eigenvalues of the above matrix, which are roots of the equation

$$
\operatorname{Det}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
-E & -i A^{\prime} & 0 \\
i A^{\prime} & B^{\prime}-E & 0 \\
0 & 0 & B^{\prime}-E
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

i.e.,

$$
\left(E-B^{\prime}\right)\left(E^{2}-B^{\prime} E-A^{\prime}\right)=0 .
$$

Thus the energy levels are

$$
E_{0}=B^{\prime}, \quad E_{\pm}=\left(B^{\prime \prime} \pm \omega\right) \hbar / 2,
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{B^{\prime 2}+4 A^{\prime 2}} / \hbar, B^{\prime \prime}=B^{\prime} / \hbar=B \hbar$. The corresponding eigenfunctions are

$$
E_{0}=B^{\prime}: \quad \varphi_{s_{0}}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-207.jpg?height=211&width=1040&top_left_y=1660&top_left_x=158)

$$
E_{-}=\frac{B^{\prime}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{B^{\prime 2}+4 A^{\prime 2}}}{2}: \quad \varphi_{S-}=\sqrt{\frac{\omega+B^{\prime \prime}}{2 \omega}} \quad\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
-i \sqrt{\frac{\omega-B^{\prime \prime}}{\omega+B^{\prime \prime}}} \\
0
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

The general wave function of the system is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varphi_{S}(t)=& C_{1} \varphi_{S 0} \exp \left[-\frac{i B^{\prime}}{\hbar} t\right]+C_{2} \varphi_{S+} \exp \left[-i \frac{E_{+}}{\hbar} t\right] \\
&+C_{3} \varphi_{S-} \exp \left[-i \frac{E_{-}}{\hbar} t\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Initially,

$$
s_{z} \varphi_{s}(0)=\hbar \varphi_{s}(0) .
$$

Let

$$
\varphi_{s}(0)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
\alpha \\
\beta \\
\gamma
\end{array}\right)
$$

The above requires

$$
\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
0 & -i & 0 \\
i & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right) \quad\left(\begin{array}{l}
\alpha \\
\beta \\
\gamma
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
\alpha \\
\beta \\
\gamma
\end{array}\right)
$$

.e.,

$$
\beta=i \alpha, \quad \gamma=0 .
$$

Thus we can take the initial wave function (normalized) as

$$
\varphi_{S}(0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
i \\
0
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Equating $\varphi_{s}(0)$ with $C_{1} \varphi_{S 0}+C_{2} \varphi_{S+}+C_{3} \varphi_{S-\text { gives }}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&C_{1}=0, C_{2}=\frac{\left(\omega+B^{\prime \prime}\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\omega-B^{\prime \prime}\right)^{1 / 2}}{2 \omega^{1 / 2}} \\
&C_{3}=\frac{\left(\omega+B^{\prime \prime}\right)^{1 / 2}-\left(\omega-B^{\prime \prime}\right)^{1 / 2}}{2 \omega^{1 / 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We can now find the expectation value of the spin:

$$
\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle=\varphi_{S}^{+}(t) s_{x} \varphi_{S}(t)=0,
$$

where we have used the orthogonality of $\varphi_{S 0}, \varphi_{S+}$ and $\varphi_{S-}$. Similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left\langle s_{y}\right\rangle=0, \\
&\left\langle s_{z}\right\rangle=\varphi_{S}^{+}(t) s_{z} \varphi_{S}(t)=\left[1-\frac{2 B^{2} \hbar^{2}}{\omega^{2}} \sin ^{2}(\omega t / 2)\right] \hbar .
\end{aligned}
$$

3021.Problem Statement:
A system of two particles each with spin $1 / 2$ is described by an effective Hamiltonian

$$
H=A\left(s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}\right)+B s_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2},
$$

where $s_{1}$ and $\mathbf{s}_{2}$ are the two spins, $s_{1 z}$ and $s_{2 z}$ are their $z$-components, and $A$ and $B$ are constants. Find all the energy levels of this Hamiltonian.
3021.Solution:
We choose $\chi_{S M_{S}}$ as the common eigenstate of $\mathbf{S}^{2}=\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right)^{2}$ and $S_{z}=s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}$. For $S=1, M_{S}=0, \pm 1$, it is a triplet and is symmetric when the two electrons are exchanged. For $S=0, M_{S}=0$, it is a singlet and is antisymmetric. For stationary states we use the time-independent Schrödinger equation

$$
H_{S M_{S}}=E \chi_{S M_{S}} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{S}^{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}} &=S(S+1) \hbar^{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}}=2 \hbar^{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}}, \mathbf{S}^{2} \chi_{00}=0 \\
\mathbf{S}^{2} &=\left(\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}\right)^{2}=\mathbf{s}_{1}^{2}+\mathbf{s}_{2}^{2}+2 \mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2} \\
&=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{4}+\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}+2 \mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
s_{1} \cdot s_{2} \chi_{1 M_{S}}=\left(\frac{S^{2}}{2}-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}\right) \chi_{1 M_{S}}=\left(\hbar^{2}-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}\right) \chi_{1 M_{S}}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} \chi_{1 M_{S}}
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{s}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{2} \chi_{00}=\left(0-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2}\right) \chi_{00}=-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2} \chi_{00}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
S_{z} \chi_{1 M_{S}} &=\left(s_{1 z}+s_{2 z}\right) \chi_{1 M_{S}}=M_{S} \hbar \chi_{1 M_{S}}, \\
s_{z} \chi_{00} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence for the triplet state, the energy levels are

$$
E=M_{S} \hbar A+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B, \quad \text { with } \quad M_{S}=0, \pm 1,
$$

comprising three lines

$$
E_{1}=\hbar A+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B, E_{2}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B, E_{3}=-\hbar A+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4} B
$$

For the singlet state, the energy level consists of only one line

$$
E_{0}=-\frac{3}{4} \hbar^{2} B .
$$

3022.a.Problem Statement:
Suppose an atom is initially in an excited ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state (Fig. 3.1) and subsequently decays into a lower, short-lived ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state with emission of a photon $\gamma_{1}$ (Fig. 3.2). Soon after, it decays into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ ground state by emitting a second photon $\gamma_{2}$ (Fig. 3.3). Let $\theta$ be the angle between the two emitted photons.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-210.jpg?height=199&width=192&top_left_y=1201&top_left_x=563)

Fig. $3.1$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-210.jpg?height=281&width=188&top_left_y=1499&top_left_x=565)

Fig. $3.2$ 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-211.jpg?height=278&width=209&top_left_y=160&top_left_x=562)

Fig. 3.3

What is the relative probability of $\theta$ in this process?

It may be of some help to know the rotation matrices $d_{m^{\prime} m}$, which relate one angular momentum representation in one coordinate system to another angular momentum representation in a rotated coordinate system, given below:

$$
\begin{array}{cccc}
m=1 & m=0 & m=-1 \\
m^{\prime}=1
\end{array}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} \\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha \\
\frac{1-\cos \alpha}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \alpha & \frac{1+\cos \alpha}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\alpha$ is the angle between the $z$-axis of one system and the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the other.
3022.a.Solution:
The atom is initially in the excited state ${ }^{1} S_{0}$. Thus the projection of the atomic angular momentum on an arbitrary $z$ direction is $L_{z}=0$. We can take the direction of the first photon emission as the $z$ direction. After the emission of the photon and the atom goes into the ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ state, if the angular momentum of that photon is $L_{z}=\pm \hbar$, correspondingly the angular momentum of the atomic state ${ }^{1} P_{1}$ is $L_{z}=\mp \hbar$, i.e., $m_{z}=\mp 1$. If we let the direction of emission of the second photon be the $z^{\prime}$-axis the projection of the eigenstate of the $z$-component of angular momentum on the $z^{\prime}$ direction is equivalent to multiplying the initial state with the $d_{m^{\prime} m}$ matrix. Only atoms that are in states $m_{z}^{\prime}=\pm 1$ can emit photon (as $L_{z}^{\prime}=\pm \hbar$ must be satisfied) in $z^{\prime}$ direction and make the atom decay into the ${ }^{1} S_{0}$ state $\left(m_{z}^{\prime}=0\right)$. Then the transitions are from $m=\pm 1$ to $m^{\prime}=\pm 1$, and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C_{1}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(0,0,1)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{2}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=+1\right\rangle \\
& =(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} \\\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \cos \theta & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta \\\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \theta & \frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& =\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{3}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=+1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1-\cos \theta}{2}, \\
& C_{4}=\left\langle m_{z^{\prime}}=-1\left|d_{m^{\prime} m}\right| m_{z}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1+\cos \theta}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The relative probability of $\theta$ is

$$
P(\theta) \propto\left|C_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{2}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{3}\right|^{2}+\left|C_{4}\right|^{2}=1+\cos ^{2} \theta .
$$

3024.Problem Statement: A particle with magnetic moment $\mu=\mu_{0}$ s and spin s, with magnitude $1 / 2$, is placed in a constant magnetic field pointing along the $x$-axis. At $t=0$, the particle is found to have $s_{z}=+1 / 2$. Find the probabilities at any later time of finding the particle with $s_{y}=\pm 1 / 2$.
3024.Solution:
The Hamiltonian (spin part) of the system is

$$
\hat{H}=-\mu_{0} \hat{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}=-\frac{1}{2} \hat{\sigma}_{x} B \mu_{0},
$$

as $\mathbf{s}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \sigma_{x}$, being in the $x$ direction. In the $\sigma_{x}$ representation, the Schrödinger equation that the spin wave function $\left(\begin{array}{l}a_{1} \\ a_{2}\end{array}\right)$ satisfies is

$$
i \hbar \frac{d}{d t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2}
\end{array}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} B\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2}
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

or

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
i \hbar \frac{d}{d t} a_{1}+\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} B a_{2}=0 \\
i \hbar \frac{d}{d t} a_{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mu_{0} B a_{1}=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Elimination of $a_{1}$ or $a_{2}$ gives

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}} a_{1,2}+\frac{\mu_{0}^{2} B^{2}}{4 \hbar^{2}} a_{1,2}=0,
$$

which have solutions

$$
a_{1,2}=A_{1,2} e^{i \omega t}+B_{1,2} e^{-i \omega t}
$$

where

$$
\omega=\frac{\mu_{0} B}{2 \hbar}
$$

and $A_{1,2}, B_{1,2}$ are constants. As

$$
\hat{s}_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{z}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
\hat{s}_{z}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right),
$$

the initial spin wave function is $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)$, i.e. $a_{1}(0)=1, a_{2}(0)=0$. The Schrödinger equation then gives

$$
\frac{d a_{1}(0)}{d t}=0, \quad \frac{d a_{2}(0)}{d t}=i \frac{\mu_{0} B}{2 \hbar}=i \omega .
$$

These four initial conditions give

$$
\begin{cases}A_{1}+B_{1}=1, & A_{2}+B_{2}=0 \\ \omega\left(A_{1}-B_{1}\right)=0, & \omega\left(A_{2}-B_{2}\right)=\omega\end{cases}
$$

with the solution $A_{1}=A_{2}=B_{1}=-B_{2}=1 / 2$. Substitution in the expressions for $a_{1,2}$ results in

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
a_{1}(t) \\
a_{2}(t)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega t \\
i \sin \omega t
\end{array}\right) .
$$

As the eigenstate of $s_{y}=+1 / 2$ is

$$
\left|s_{y}(+)\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
i
\end{array}\right)
$$

and that of $s_{y}=-1 / 2$ is

$$
\left|s_{y}(-)\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-i
\end{array}\right)
$$

the probability of finding $s_{y}=+1 / 2$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(+) &=\left|\left\langle s_{y}(+) \mid \psi(t)\right\rangle\right|^{2} \\
&=\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1-i)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega t \\
i \sin \omega t
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2}(1+\sin 2 \omega t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly the probability of finding $s_{y}=-1 / 2$ is

$$
P(-)=\left|\left\langle s_{y}(-) \mid \psi(t)\right\rangle\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}(1-\sin 2 \omega t) .
$$

3025.Problem Statement:
The Hamiltonian for a spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particle with charge $+e$ in an external magnetic field is

$$
H=-\frac{g e}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B} \text {. }
$$

Calculate the operator $d \mathbf{s} / d t$ if $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{y}$. What is $s_{z}(t)$ in matrix form?
3025.Solution:
In the Heisenberg picture,

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{s}}{d t}=\frac{1}{i \hbar}[\mathbf{s}, H]=-\frac{g e}{i 2 m \hbar c}[\mathbf{s}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}] .
$$

As

$$
[\mathbf{s}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}]=\left[s_{x}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \hat{\mathbf{x}}+\left[s_{y}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \hat{\mathbf{y}}+\left[s_{z}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \hat{\mathbf{z}}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[s_{x}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] } &=\left[s_{x}, s_{z}\right] B_{x}+\left[s_{x}, s_{y}\right] B_{y}+\left[s_{x}, s_{z}\right] B_{z} \\
&=i \hbar\left(s_{z} B_{y}-s_{y} B_{z}\right) \\
&=i \hbar(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{s})_{x}, \quad \text { etc }
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
[\mathbf{s}, \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}]=-i \hbar \mathbf{s} \times \mathbf{B},
$$

and hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{s}}{d t}=+\frac{g e}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

If $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{y}}$, the above gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d s_{x}(t)}{d t} &=-\frac{g e B}{2 m c} s_{z}(t), \\
\frac{d s_{z}(t)}{d t} &=\frac{g e B}{2 m c} s_{x}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

and so

$$
\frac{d^{2} s_{z}(t)}{d t^{2}}+\left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c}\right)^{2} s_{z}(t)=0
$$

with the solution

$$
s_{z}(t)=c_{1} \cos (g \omega t)+c_{2} \sin (g \omega t),
$$

where $\omega=e B / 2 m c$. At $t=0$ we have

$$
s_{z}(0)=c_{1}, \quad s_{z}^{\prime}(0)=c_{2} g \omega=g \omega s_{x}(0)
$$

and hence

$$
s_{z}(t)=s_{z}(0) \cos \left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c} t\right)+s_{x}(0) \sin \left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c} t\right) .
$$
3025.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics
3025.Final Answer: $$s_{z}(0) \cos \left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c} t\right)+s_{x}(0) \sin \left(\frac{g e B}{2 m c} t\right)$$

3028.b.Problem Statement:
A negatively charged $\pi^{-}$meason (a pseudoscalar particle: zero spin, odd parity) is initially bound in the lowest-energy Coulomb wave function around a deuteron. It is captured by the deuteron (a proton and a neutron in a ${ }^{3} S_{1}$ state), which is converted into a pair of neutrons:

$$
\pi^{-}+d \rightarrow n+n .
$$

What is their total spin angular momentum?

You may find some of the first few (not normalized) spherical harmonics useful:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
Y_{0}^{0}=1, & Y_{1}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi}, \\
Y_{1}^{0}=\cos \theta, & Y_{2}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sin 2 \theta e^{\pm i \phi} .
\end{array}
$$
3028.b.Solution:
Because of the conservation of parity in strong interactions, we have

$$
p\left(\pi^{-}\right) p(d)(-1)^{L_{1}}=p(n) p(n)(-1)^{L_{2}},
$$

where $L_{1}, L_{2}$ are the orbital angular momenta of $\pi^{-}+d$ and $n+n$ respectively. As the $\pi^{-}$, being captured, is in the lowest energy state of the Coulomb potential before the reaction, $L_{1}=0$. Since $p\left(\pi^{-}\right)=-1, p(d)=$ $1, p(n) p(n)=1$, we have

$$
(-1)^{L_{2}}=-1 \text {, }
$$

and so

$$
L_{2}=2 m+1, m=0,1,2, \ldots .
$$

The deutron has $J=1$ and $\pi^{-}$has zero spin, so that $J=1$ before the reaction takes place. The conservation of angular momentum requires that after the reaction, $\mathbf{L}_{2}+\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{J}$. The identity of $n$ and $n$ demands that the total wave function be antisymmetric. Then since the spacial wave function is antisymmetric, the spin wave function must be symmetric, i.e. $S=1$ and so $L_{2}=2,1$ or 0 . As $L_{2}$ is odd, we must have $L_{2}=1, S=1$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-222.jpg?height=420&width=265&top_left_y=782&top_left_x=532)

Fig. $3.5$

The total orbital angular momentum and the total spin angular momentum are both $\sqrt{1(1+1)} \hbar=\sqrt{2} \hbar$.

What is the probability for finding both neutron spins directed opposite to the spin of the deuteron?

You may find some of the first few (not normalized) spherical harmonics useful:

\begin{array}{ll}
Y_{0}^{0}=1, & Y_{1}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sin \theta e^{\pm i \phi}, \\
Y_{1}^{0}=\cos \theta, & Y_{2}^{\pm 1}=\mp \sin 2 \theta e^{\pm i \phi} .
\end{array}
$$
3028.c.Solution:
Because of the conservation of parity in strong interactions, we have

$$
p\left(\pi^{-}\right) p(d)(-1)^{L_{1}}=p(n) p(n)(-1)^{L_{2}},
$$

where $L_{1}, L_{2}$ are the orbital angular momenta of $\pi^{-}+d$ and $n+n$ respectively. As the $\pi^{-}$, being captured, is in the lowest energy state of the Coulomb potential before the reaction, $L_{1}=0$. Since $p\left(\pi^{-}\right)=-1, p(d)=$ $1, p(n) p(n)=1$, we have

$$
(-1)^{L_{2}}=-1 \text {, }
$$

and so

$$
L_{2}=2 m+1, m=0,1,2, \ldots .
$$

The deutron has $J=1$ and $\pi^{-}$has zero spin, so that $J=1$ before the reaction takes place. The conservation of angular momentum requires that after the reaction, $\mathbf{L}_{2}+\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{J}$. The identity of $n$ and $n$ demands that the total wave function be antisymmetric. Then since the spacial wave function is antisymmetric, the spin wave function must be symmetric, i.e. $S=1$ and so $L_{2}=2,1$ or 0 . As $L_{2}$ is odd, we must have $L_{2}=1, S=1$.

The total orbital angular momentum and the total spin angular momentum are both $\sqrt{1(1+1)} \hbar=\sqrt{2} \hbar$.Assume that the deuteron spin is in the direction $J_{z}=1 \hbar$ before the reaction. If both neutrons had spins in the reversed direction, we would have $S_{z}=-1 \hbar, L_{z}=2 \hbar$, which is impossible since $L_{2}=1$. Hence the probability is zero.

Then since the spacial wave function is antisymmetric, the spin wave function must be symmetric, i.e. $S=1$ and so $L_{2}=2,1$ or 0 . As $L_{2}$ is odd, we must have $L_{2}=1, S=1$.

If both neutrons had spins in the reversed direction, we would have $S_{z}=-1 \hbar, L_{z}=2 \hbar$, which is impossible since $L_{2}=1$. $$

has $S_{z}=0$ and so there must be one neutron with $s_{z}=-\hbar / 2$. Hence the probability distribution required is

3029.a.Problem Statement:
An $\Omega^{-}$hyperon (spin $3 / 2$, mass $1672 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $+$ ) can decay via the weak interaction into a $\Lambda$ hyperon (spin $1 / 2$, mass $1116 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $+$ ) and a $K^{-}$meson (spin 0 , mass $494 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, intrinsic parity $-)$, i.e., $\Omega^{-} \rightarrow \Lambda+K^{-}$.

What is the most general form of the angular distribution of the $K^{-}$mesons relative to the spin direction of the $\Omega^{-}$for the case when the $\Omega^{-}$has a maximum possible component of angular momentum along the $z$-axis, i.e., the initial state $\left|\Omega_{j}^{m}\right\rangle=\left|\Omega_{3 / 2}^{+3 / 2}\right\rangle$.

(Berkeley)
3029.a.Solution:
The initial state of the system is $|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle$, where the values are the orbital and spin momenta of the $\Omega^{-}$. The spin part of the final state is $\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle|0,0\rangle=\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle$, and the orbital part is $Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)=|l, m\rangle$. Thus the total final state of this system is

$$
|l, m\rangle\left|1 / 2, s_{z}\right\rangle \text {. }
$$

By conservation of angular momentum $l=1,2 ; m=3 / 2-s_{z}$. Thus the final state is a $p$ wave if $l=1$, the state being $|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle$; a $d$ wave if $l=2$, the state being a combination of $|2,2\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle$ and $|2,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle$

Hence the wave functions are

$$
\psi_{p}=Y_{11}(\theta, \varphi)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{d} &=\left[\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}}|2,2\rangle\left|\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle-\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}}|2,1\rangle\left|\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right] \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} Y_{21}(\theta, \varphi) \\
\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}} Y_{22}(\theta, \varphi)
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi &=a_{d} \psi_{d}+a_{p} \psi_{p} \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
a_{p} Y_{11}(\theta, \varphi)-a_{d} \sqrt{\frac{1}{5}} Y_{21}(\theta, \varphi) \\
\sqrt{\frac{4}{5}} a_{d} Y_{22}(\theta, \varphi)
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
\psi^{*} \psi=\frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta\left[\left|a_{p}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{d}\right|^{2}-2 R e a_{p}^{*} a_{d} \cos \theta\right],
$$

i.e., the intensity of the emitted particles is

$$
I \propto \sin ^{2} \theta(1+\alpha \cos \theta),
$$

where

$$
\alpha=-2 \operatorname{Re} a_{p}^{*} a_{d} /\left(\left|a_{p}\right|^{2}+\left|a_{d}\right|^{2}\right) .
$$

This is the most general form of the angular distribution of the $\mathrm{K}^{-}$mesons.

3031.a.Problem Statement: Compute the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients for the states with $\mathbf{J}=$ $\mathbf{J}_{1}+\mathbf{J}_{2}, M=m_{1}+m_{2}$, where $j_{1}=1$ and $j_{2}=1 / 2$, and $j=3 / 2, M=1 / 2$ for the various possible $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ values.
3031.a.Solution:
As $M=m_{1}+m_{2}=1 / 2,\left(m_{1}, m_{2}\right)$ can only be $(1,-1 / 2)$ or $(0,1 / 2)$. Consider

$$
|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle .
$$

As

$$
M_{-}|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{3}|3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle,
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
M_{-}|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle &=\left(M_{1-}+M_{2-}\right)|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle \\
&=\sqrt{2}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle+|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\langle 1,1,1 / 2,-1 / 2 \mid 3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=1 / \sqrt{3} \\
\langle 1,0,1 / 2,1 / 2 \mid 3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}
\end{gathered}
$$
3031.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3031.b.Problem Statement:
Consider the reactions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\pi^{+} p \rightarrow \pi^{+} p \\
&\pi^{-} p \rightarrow \pi^{-} p \\
&\pi^{-} p \rightarrow \pi^{0} n
\end{aligned}
$$

These reactions, which conserve isospin, can occur in the isospin $I=3 / 2$ state ( $\Delta$ resonance ) or the $I=1 / 2$ state $\left(N^{*}\right.$ resonance). Calculate the ratios of these cross-sections, $\sigma_{\mathrm{i}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{ii}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{iii}}$, for an energy corresponding to a $\Delta$ resonance and an $N^{*}$ resonance respectively. At a resonance energy you can neglect the effect due to the other isospin states. Note that the pion is an isospin $I=1$ state and the nucleon an isospin $I=1 / 2$ state.

(Berkeley)
3031.b.Solution:
As $M=m_{1}+m_{2}=1 / 2,\left(m_{1}, m_{2}\right)$ can only be $(1,-1 / 2)$ or $(0,1 / 2)$. Consider

$$
|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle .
$$

As

$$
M_{-}|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{3}|3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle,
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
M_{-}|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle &=\left(M_{1-}+M_{2-}\right)|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle \\
&=\sqrt{2}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle+|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\langle 1,1,1 / 2,-1 / 2 \mid 3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=1 / \sqrt{3} \\
\langle 1,0,1 / 2,1 / 2 \mid 3 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}
\end{gathered}
$$As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi^{+} &=|1,1\rangle, \quad \pi^{0}=|1,0\rangle, \quad \pi^{-}=|1,-1\rangle, \\
p &=|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle, \quad n=|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\pi^{+} p\right\rangle &=|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=|3 / 2,3 / 2\rangle \\
\left|\pi^{-} p\right\rangle &=|1,-1\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=a|3 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle+b|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle, \\
\left|\pi^{0} n\right\rangle &=|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle=c|3 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle+d|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

From a table of Clebsch-Gordan coefficients, we find $a=\sqrt{1 / 3}, b=$ $-\sqrt{2 / 3}, c=\sqrt{2 / 3}, d=\sqrt{1 / 3}$. For the $\Delta$ resonance state, $I=3 / 2$ and the ratios of the cross sections are

$$
\sigma_{\mathrm{i}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{ii}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{iii}}=1:|a|^{4}:|a c|^{2}=1: \frac{1}{9}: \frac{2}{9} .
$$

For the $N^{*}$ resonance state, $I=1 / 2$, and the ratios are

$$
\sigma_{\mathrm{i}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{ii}}: \sigma_{\mathrm{iii}}=0:|b|^{4}:|b d|^{2}=0: \frac{4}{9}: \frac{2}{9} .
$$
