3032.Problem Statement: Consider an electron in a uniform magnetic field along the $z$ direction. Let the result of a measurement be that the electron spin is along the positive $y$ direction at $t=0$. Find the Schrödinger state vector for the spin, and the average polarization (expectation value of $s_{x}$ ) along the $x$ direction for $t>0$.
3032.Solution:
As we are only interested in the spin state and the magnetic field is uniform in space, we can leave out the space part of the wave function. Then the Hamiltonian can be taken to be

$$
H=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\mu_{e} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\hbar \omega \sigma_{z},
$$

where $\mu=-\mu_{e} \sigma, \omega=\mu_{e} B / \hbar=e B / 2 m c, \mu_{e}$ being the Bohr magneton $\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}$. As the electron is initially along the $y$ direction, the initial spin wave function is

$$
\psi(t=0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
i
\end{array}\right)
$$

Let the spin wave function at a later time $t$ be $\left(\begin{array}{c}\alpha \\ \beta\end{array}\right)$. The Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar d \psi / d t=H \psi
$$

then gives

$$
i \hbar\left(\begin{array}{l}
\dot{\alpha} \\
\dot{\beta}
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\alpha \\
\beta
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\dot{\alpha}=-i \omega \alpha, \quad \dot{\beta}=i \omega \beta,
$$

with the solution

$$
\psi(t)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\alpha(t) \\
\beta(t)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i \omega t} \alpha_{0} \\
e^{i \omega t} \beta_{0}
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i \omega t} \\
i e^{-i \omega t}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle s_{x}\right\rangle &=\left\langle\psi(t)\left|\hat{s}_{x}\right| \psi(t)\right\rangle \\
&=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left\langle\psi\left|\sigma_{x}\right| \psi\right\rangle \\
&=\frac{\hbar}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}\left(e^{i \omega t}-i e^{-i \omega t}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
e^{-i \omega t} \\
i e^{i \omega t}
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{i \hbar}{4}\left(e^{2 i \omega t}-e^{-2 i \omega t}\right) \\
&=-\frac{\hbar}{2} \sin (2 \omega t)
\end{aligned}
$$

3033.Problem Statement: Consider an electron in a uniform magnetic field pointing along the $z$ direction. The electron spin is measured (at time $t_{0}$ ) to be pointing along the positive $y$-axis. What is the polarization along the $x$ and $z$ directions (i.e. the expectation values of $2 s_{x}$ and $2 s_{z}$ ) for $t>t_{0}$ ?
3033.Solution:
The Schrödinger equation for the spin state vector is

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)=-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)=\mu_{e} \sigma \cdot \mathbf{B}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\mu_{e}=|e| \hbar / 2 m_{e} c$ is the magnitude of the magnetic moment of an electron. As $\mathbf{B}$ is along the $z$ direction, the above becomes

or

$$
i \hbar \partial_{t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)=\mu_{e} B\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

The solutions are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
i \hbar \partial_{t} a(t)=\mu_{e} B a(t), \\
i \hbar \partial_{t} b(t)=-\mu_{e} B b(t) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a(t)=a\left(t_{0}\right) e^{-\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu_{e} B\left(t-t_{0}\right)}, \\
&b(t)=b\left(t_{0}\right) e^{\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu_{e} B\left(t-t_{0}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

At time $t_{0}$, the electron spin is in the positive $y$ direction. Thus

or

$$
s_{y}\left(\begin{array}{l}
a\left(t_{0}\right) \\
b\left(t_{0}\right)
\end{array}\right)=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a\left(t_{0}\right) \\
b\left(t_{0}\right)
\end{array}\right)=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{c}
a\left(t_{0}\right) \\
b\left(t_{0}\right)
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-i b\left(t_{0}\right)=a\left(t_{0}\right), \\
i a\left(t_{0}\right)=b\left(t_{0}\right) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

The normalization condition

$$
\left|a\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}+\left|b\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}=1 \text {, }
$$

then gives

As $\frac{b\left(t_{0}\right)}{a\left(t_{0}\right)}=i$, we can take

$$
\left|a\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}=\left|b\left(t_{0}\right)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{2} .
$$

$$
a\left(t_{0}\right)=1 / \sqrt{2}, \quad b\left(t_{0}\right)=i / \sqrt{2} .
$$

Hence for time $t>t_{0}$, the polarizations along $x$ and $z$ directions are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle 2 s_{x}\right\rangle &=\hbar\left(a^{*}, b^{*}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\hbar\left(a^{*} b+b^{*} a\right)=-\hbar \sin \left[\frac{2 \mu_{e}}{\hbar} B\left(t-t_{0}\right)\right] \\
\left\langle 2 s_{z}\right\rangle &=\hbar\left(a^{*}, b^{*}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\hbar\left(a^{*} a-b^{*} b\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

3034.Problem Statement:
Two spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles form a composite system. Spin $A$ is in the eigenstate $S_{z}=+1 / 2$ and spin $B$ in the eigenstate $S_{x}=+1 / 2$. What is the probability that a measurement of the total spin will give the value zero?

$(C U S)$
3034.Solution:
In the uncoupling representation, the state in which the total spin is zero can be written as

$$
|0\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|S_{A z}=\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left|S_{B z}=-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle-\left|S_{A z}=-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left|S_{B z}=\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right)
$$

where $S_{A z}$ and $S_{B z}$ denote the $z$-components of the spins of $A$ and $B$ respectively. As these two spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles are now in the state

$$
|Q\rangle=\left|S_{A z}=+1 / 2\right\rangle\left|S_{B x}=+1 / 2\right\rangle
$$

the probability of finding the total spin to be zero is

$$
P=|\langle 0 \mid Q\rangle|^{2} .
$$

In the representation of $\hat{\mathbf{S}}^{2}$ and $\hat{S}_{z}$, the spin angular momentum operator $\hat{S}_{x}$ is defined as

$$
\hat{S}_{x}=\frac{\hbar}{2} \sigma_{x}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Solving the eigenequation of $\hat{S}_{x}$, we find that its eigenfunction $\mid S_{x}=$ $+1 / 2\rangle$ can be expressed in the representation of $\mathbf{S}^{2}$ and $S_{z}$ as

$$
\left|S_{x}=+1 / 2\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|S_{z}=1 / 2\right\rangle+\left|S_{z}=-1 / 2\right\rangle\right)
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\langle S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left\langle S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{z}=\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right. \\
\left.+\left\langle S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{z}=-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{gathered}
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle 0 \mid Q\rangle=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left\langle S_{A z}=\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{A z}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left\langle S_{B z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{B x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right.\\
&\left.-\left\langle S_{A z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{A z}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\left\langle S_{B z}=\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{B x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle\right) \\
=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left\langle S_{B z}=-\frac{1}{2} \mid S_{B x}=+\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
P=|\langle 0 \mid Q\rangle|^{2}=\frac{1}{4}=25 \% .
$$

3035.a.Problem Statement:
An electron has been observed to have its spin in the direction of the $z$-axis of a rectangular coordinate system. What is the probability that a second observation will show the spin to be directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis?

(Berkeley)
3035.a.Solution:
The initial spin state of the electron is

$$
\left|\psi_{0}\right\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

The state whose spin is directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis is

$$
|\psi\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{r}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Thus the probability that a second observation will show the spin to be directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(\theta)=\left|\left\langle\psi \mid \psi_{0}\right\rangle\right|^{2} &=\left|\left(\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, \sin \frac{\theta}{2}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2} \\
&=\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

3035.b.Problem Statement:
The total spin of the neutron and proton in a deuteron is a triplet state. The resultant spin has been observed to be parallel to the $z$-axis of a rectangular coordinate system. What is the probability that a second observation will show the proton spin to be parallel to the $z$-axis?

(Berkeley)
3035.b.Solution:
The initial spin state of the electron is

$$
\left|\psi_{0}\right\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

The state whose spin is directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis is

$$
|\psi\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{r}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2} \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Thus the probability that a second observation will show the spin to be directed in $x-z$ plane at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(\theta)=\left|\left\langle\psi \mid \psi_{0}\right\rangle\right|^{2} &=\left|\left(\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, \sin \frac{\theta}{2}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2} \\
&=\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$The initial spin state of the neutron-proton system is

$$
\left|\psi_{0}\right\rangle=|1,1\rangle=|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{n}|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{p}
$$

Suppose a second observation shows the proton spin to be parallel to the $z$-axis. Since the neutron spin is parallel to the proton spin in the deuteron, the final state remains, as before,

$$
\left|\psi_{f}\right\rangle=|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{n}|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle_{p} .
$$

Hence the probability that a second observation will show the proton spin to be parallel to the $z$-axis is 1 .

3036.c.Problem Statement:
The deuteron is a bound state of a proton and a neutron of total angular momentum $J=1$. It is known to be principally an $S(L=0)$ state with a small admixture of a $D(L=2)$ state.

Calculate the magnetic moment of the pure $D$ state $n-p$ system with $J=1$. Assume that the $n$ and $p$ spins are to be coupled to make the total spin $S$ which is then coupled to the orbital angular momentum $L$ to give the total angular momentum $J$. Express your result in nuclear magnetons. The proton and neutron magnetic moments are $2.79$ and $-1.91$ nuclear magnetons respectively.

$(C U S)$
3036.c.Solution:
The parities of the $S$ and $D$ states are positive, while the parity of the $P$ state is negative. Because of the conservation of parity in strong interaction, a quantum state that is initially an $S$ state cannot have a $P$ state component at any later moment.

The possible spin values for a system composed of a proton and a neutron are 1 and 0 . We are given $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{L}+\mathbf{S}$ and $J=1$. If $S=0, L=1$, the system would be in a $P$ state, which must be excluded as we have seen in (a). The allowed values are then $S=1, L=2,1,0$. Therefore a $G$ state $(L=4)$ cannot contribute.

The total spin is $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{s}_{p}+\mathbf{s}_{n}$. For a pure $D$ state with $J=1$, the orbital angular momentum (relative to the center of mass of the $n$ and $p$ ) is $L=2$ and the total spin must be $S=1$. The total magnetic moment arises from the coupling of the magnetic moment of the total spin, $\mu$, with that of the orbital angular momentum, $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{L}$, where $\boldsymbol{\mu}=\boldsymbol{\mu}_{p}+\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{p}, \boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}$ being the spin magnetic moments of $p$ and $n$ respectively.

The average value of the component of $\mu$ in the direction of the total spin $\mathbf{S}$ is

$$
\mu_{s}=\frac{\left(g_{p} \mu_{N} \mathbf{s}_{p}+g_{n} \mu_{N} \mathbf{s}_{n}\right) \cdot \mathbf{S}}{\mathbf{S}^{2}} \mathbf{S}=\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N} \mathbf{S}
$$

where

$$
\mu_{N}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m_{p} c}, \quad g_{p}=5.58, \quad g_{n}=-3.82,
$$

as $\mathbf{s}_{p}=\mathbf{s}_{n}=\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{S}$.

The motion of the proton relative to the center of mass gives rise to a magnetic moment, while the motion of the neutron does not as it is uncharged. Thus

$$
\mu_{L}=\mu_{N} \mathbf{L}_{p},
$$

where $\mathbf{L}_{p}$ is the angular momentum of the proton relative to the center of mass. As $\mathbf{L}_{p}+\mathbf{L}_{n}=\mathbf{L}$ and we may assume $\mathbf{L}_{p}=\mathbf{L}_{n}$, we have $\mathbf{L}_{p}=\mathbf{L} / 2$ (the center of mass is at the mid-point of the connecting line, taking $m_{p} \approx m_{n}$ ). Consequently, $\mu_{L}=\mu_{N} \mathbf{L} / 2$.

The total coupled magnetic moment along the direction of $\mathbf{J}$ is then

$$
\mu_{T}=\frac{\left[\frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{J}+\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N} \mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{J}\right] \mathbf{J}}{J(J+1)} .
$$

Since $\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{L}+\mathbf{S}, \mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{L}=\frac{1}{2}\left(J^{2}-L^{2}-S^{2}\right)$. With $J=1, L=2, S=1$ and so $J^{2}=2, L^{2}=6, S^{2}=2$, we have $\mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{L}=-3$ and thus $\mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{J}=3$, $\mathbf{S} \cdot \mathbf{J}=-1$. Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\mu}_{T} &=\left[\frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \cdot 3+\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right) \mu_{N}(-1)\right] \mathbf{J} / 2 \\
&=\left[1.5-\frac{1}{2}\left(g_{p}+g_{n}\right)\right] \frac{1}{2} \mu_{N} \mathbf{J}=0.31 \mu_{N} \mathbf{J} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the direction of $\mathbf{J}$ as the $z$-axis and letting $J_{z}$ take the maximum value $J_{z}=1$, we have $\mu_{T}=0.31 \mu_{N}$.

3038.Problem Statement: An alkali atom in its ground state passes through a Stern-Gerlach apparatus adjusted so as to transmit atoms that have their spins in the $+z$ direction. The atom then spends time $\tau$ in a magnetic field $H$ in the $x$ direction. At the end of this time what is the probability that the atom would pass through a Stern-Gerlach selector for spins in the $-z$ direction? Can this probability be made equal to unity? if so, how?
3038.Solution:
The Hamiltonian

$$
\hat{H}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{H}=\frac{|e| \hbar H}{2 m c} \sigma_{x} \equiv \hbar \omega \sigma_{x}, \quad \omega=\frac{|e| H}{2 m c}
$$

gives the equation of motion

$$
-\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{d}{d t}\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2}
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2}
\end{array}\right)=\hbar \omega\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{2} \\
\psi_{1}
\end{array}\right)
$$

or

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
i \dot{\psi}_{1}=\omega \psi_{2} \\
i \dot{\psi}_{2}=\omega \psi_{1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

and hence

$$
\ddot{\psi}_{1}+\omega^{2} \psi_{1}=0 .
$$

The solution is $\psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}\psi_{1} \\ \psi_{2}\end{array}\right)$, with

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1}(t)=a e^{i \omega t}+b e^{-i \omega t} \\
\psi_{2}(t)=\frac{i}{\omega} \dot{\psi}_{1}=-a e^{i \omega t}+b e^{-i \omega t} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

The initial condition

$$
\psi(t=0)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

then gives $a=b=1 / 2$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi &=\left(\begin{array}{l}
\psi_{1} \\
\psi_{2}
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{i \omega t}+e^{-i \omega t} \\
-e^{i \omega t}+e^{-i \omega t}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega t \\
-i \sin \omega t
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\cos \omega t\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)-i \sin \omega t\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the above $\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ is the eigenvector $\sigma_{z}$ for eigenvalue $-1$. Hence the probability that the spins are in the $-z$ direction at time $\tau$ after the atom passes through the Stern-Gerlach selector is

$$
\left|\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega \tau \\
-i \sin \omega \tau
\end{array}\right)\right|^{2}=\sin ^{2} \omega \tau=\frac{1-\cos 2 \omega \tau}{2} .
$$

The probability equals 1 , if

$$
1-\cos 2 \omega \tau=2,
$$

or

$$
\cos 2 \omega \tau=-1,
$$

i.e. at time

$$
\tau=\frac{(2 n+1) \pi}{2 \omega}=(2 n+1) \frac{m c \pi}{|e| H} .
$$

Hence the probability will become unity at times $\tau=(2 n+1) m c \pi /$ $|e| H$

3040.Problem Statement:
The magnetic moment of a silver atom is essentially equal to the magnetic moment of its unpaired valence electron which is $\boldsymbol{\mu}=-\gamma \mathbf{s}$, where $\gamma=e / m c$ and $\mathbf{s}$ is the electron's spin.

Suppose that a beam of silver atoms having velocity $V$ is passed through a Stern-Gerlach apparatus having its field gradient in the $z$ direction, and that only the beam with $m_{s}=\hbar / 2$ is to be considered in what follows. This beam then enters a region of length $L$ having a constant magnetic field $B_{0}$ directly along the axis of the beam ( $y$-axis). It next enters another Stern-Gerlach apparatus identical to the first as shown in Fig. 3.7. Describe clearly what is seen when the beam exits from the second SternGerlach apparatus. Express the intensities of the resulting beams in terms of $V, L, B_{0}$ and the constants of the problem.

Use quantum mechanical equations of motion to derive your result.

(Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-242.jpg?height=263&width=772&top_left_y=1190&top_left_x=273)

Fig. $3.7$
3040.Solution:
If we took a picture at the exit of the second $S-G$ apparatus, we would see two black lines arising from the deposition of the two kinds of silver atoms with $m_{s}=\hbar / 2$ and $m_{s}=-\hbar / 2$.

Denote the state of the system in the region $L$ by $|t\rangle$. If we consider only atoms of $m_{s}=\hbar / 2$ in the beam that enters the region $L$ at $t=0$, then 

$$
|t=0\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

The Hamiltonian of the system in the region of length $L$ is

$$
H=-\mu \cdot \mathbf{B}=\frac{\gamma \hbar B_{0}}{2} \sigma_{y},
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
|t\rangle &=\exp \left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} H t\right)|t=0\rangle \\
&=\exp \left(-\frac{i \gamma B_{0} t}{2} \sigma_{y}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\left(\cos \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}-i \sigma_{y} \sin \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\cos \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)+\sin \frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence at the exit of the region, the intensities of beams with $m_{s}=\frac{\hbar}{2}$ and $m_{s}=-\frac{\hbar}{2}$ are respectively

$$
I_{+}=I_{0} \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\right), \quad I_{-}=I_{0} \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma B_{0} t}{2}\right)
$$

where $I_{0}$ is the intensity of the beam that enters the region.

When the beam leaves the region $L, t=L / V$. So the ratio of intensities is

$$
\cot ^{2}\left(\gamma B_{0} L / 2 V\right) \text {. }
$$

The splitting of the beam is seen when it exists from the second SternGerlach apparatus.

3042.b.Problem Statement:
A hydrogen atom is in a ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}$ state with total angular momentum up along the $z$-axis. In all parts of this problem show your computations and reasoning carefully.

Compute the probability per unit solid angle $P(\theta, \varphi)$ that the electron will be found at spherical angles $\theta, \varphi$ (independent of radial distance and spin).

(Berkeley)
3042.b.Solution:
For the state ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}, l=1, s=1 / 2, J=1 / 2, J_{z}=1 / 2$. Transforming the coupling representation into the uncoupling representation, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=&|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle \\
&-\sqrt{1 / 3}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $P_{\downarrow}=2 / 3$.

As

$$
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sqrt{2} Y_{11} \\
Y_{10}
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

we have

$$
P(\theta, \varphi) d \Omega=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 Y_{11}^{*} Y_{11}+Y_{10}^{*} Y_{10}\right) d \Omega .
$$

Hence the probability per unit solid angle is

$$
P(\theta, \varphi)=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 \times \frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta+\frac{3}{4 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta\right)=\frac{1}{4 \pi} .
$$

3042.c.Problem Statement:
A hydrogen atom is in a ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}$ state with total angular momentum up along the $z$-axis. In all parts of this problem show your computations and reasoning carefully.

An experimenter applies a weak magnetic field along the positive $z$-axis. What is the effective magnetic moment of the atom in this field?

(Berkeley)
3042.c.Solution:
For the state ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}, l=1, s=1 / 2, J=1 / 2, J_{z}=1 / 2$. Transforming the coupling representation into the uncoupling representation, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=&|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle \\
&-\sqrt{1 / 3}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $P_{\downarrow}=2 / 3$.

As

$$
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sqrt{2} Y_{11} \\
Y_{10}
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

we have

$$
P(\theta, \varphi) d \Omega=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 Y_{11}^{*} Y_{11}+Y_{10}^{*} Y_{10}\right) d \Omega .
$$

Hence the probability per unit solid angle is

$$
P(\theta, \varphi)=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 \times \frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta+\frac{3}{4 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta\right)=\frac{1}{4 \pi} .
$$In the weak magnetic field, $J$ and $J_{z}$ are "good" quantum numbers and the state remains unchanged. The effective magnetic moment is

$$
\mu=\left\langle\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\left|\mu_{z}\right| \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=g \frac{e}{2 m c}\left\langle\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\left|J_{z}\right| \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=g \cdot \frac{e \hbar}{4 m c}
$$

where $m$ is the electron mass and

$$
g=1+\frac{J(J+1)-l(l+1)+s(s+.1)}{2 J(J+1)}=\frac{2}{3} .
$$

Hence $\mu=e \hbar / 6 m c$.

3042.e.Problem Statement:
A hydrogen atom is in a ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}$ state with total angular momentum up along the $z$-axis. In all parts of this problem show your computations and reasoning carefully.

[Assume the Hamiltonian is linear in the magnetic field.]

What is the effective magnetic moment of this final state?

(Berkeley)
3042.e.Solution:
For the state ${ }^{2} P_{1 / 2}, l=1, s=1 / 2, J=1 / 2, J_{z}=1 / 2$. Transforming the coupling representation into the uncoupling representation, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=&|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle=\sqrt{2 / 3}|1,1\rangle|1 / 2,-1 / 2\rangle \\
&-\sqrt{1 / 3}|1,0\rangle|1 / 2,1 / 2\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $P_{\downarrow}=2 / 3$.

As

$$
\left|J, J_{z}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sqrt{2} Y_{11} \\
Y_{10}
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

we have

$$
P(\theta, \varphi) d \Omega=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 Y_{11}^{*} Y_{11}+Y_{10}^{*} Y_{10}\right) d \Omega .
$$

Hence the probability per unit solid angle is

$$
P(\theta, \varphi)=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 \times \frac{3}{8 \pi} \sin ^{2} \theta+\frac{3}{4 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta\right)=\frac{1}{4 \pi} .
$$In the weak magnetic field, $J$ and $J_{z}$ are "good" quantum numbers and the state remains unchanged. The effective magnetic moment is

$$
\mu=\left\langle\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\left|\mu_{z}\right| \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=g \frac{e}{2 m c}\left\langle\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\left|J_{z}\right| \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=g \cdot \frac{e \hbar}{4 m c}
$$

where $m$ is the electron mass and

$$
g=1+\frac{J(J+1)-l(l+1)+s(s+.1)}{2 J(J+1)}=\frac{2}{3} .
$$

Hence $\mu=e \hbar / 6 m c$.In a strong magnetic field, the interaction of the magnetic moment with the field is much stronger than the coupling interaction of spin and orbit, so that the latter can be neglected. Here $l$ and $s$ are good quantum numbers. The Hamiltonian related to the magnetic field is

$$
W=-\boldsymbol{\mu}_{l} \cdot \mathbf{B}-\boldsymbol{\mu}_{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}=e B \hat{l}_{z} / 2 m c+e B \hat{s}_{z} / m c
$$

When the magnetic field is increased slowly from zero, the state remains at the lowest energy. From the expression of $W$, we see that when the magnetic field becomes strong, only if $l_{z}=-\hbar, s_{z}=-\hbar / 2$ can the state remain at the lowest energy. Thus the quantum numbers of the final state are $l=1, l_{z}=-1, s=1 / 2, s_{z}=-1 / 2$.

the effective magnetic moment of the final state is

$$
\mu=\bar{\mu}_{l z}+\bar{\mu}_{s z}=-e \hbar / 2 m c-e \hbar / 2 m c=-e \hbar / m c
$$

3043.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a neutral particle with intrinsic angular momentum $\sqrt{s(s+1)}$, where $s=\hbar / 2$, i.e., a spin-1/2 particle.

Assume the particle has a magnetic moment $\mathbf{M}=\gamma \mathbf{s}$, where $\gamma$ is a constant. The quantum-mechanical state of the particle can be described in a spin space spanned by the eigenvectors $|+\rangle$ and $|-\rangle$ representing alignments parallel and antiparallel to the $z$-axis:

$$
\hat{s}_{z}|+\rangle=\frac{\hbar}{2}|+\rangle, \quad \hat{s}_{z}|-\rangle=-\frac{\hbar}{2}|-\rangle .
$$

At time $t=0$ the state of the system is $|\psi(t=0)\rangle=|+\rangle$. The particle moves along the $y$-axis through a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{y}}$ oriented along the $y$-axis.

As expressed in the $|+\rangle,|-\rangle$ basis, what is $|\psi(t)\rangle$ ?

$(C U S)$
3043.a.Solution:
The Hamiltonian of the particle is

$$
\hat{H}=-\mathbf{M} \cdot \mathbf{B}=-\gamma \hat{s}_{y} B .
$$

In the representation of $\hat{\mathbf{s}}^{2}, \hat{s}_{z}$

$$
\hat{s}_{y}=\frac{\hbar}{2}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right) \text {, }
$$

and so the two eigenstates of $\hat{s}_{y}$ are

$$
\left|s_{y}=\hbar / 2\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-i \\
1
\end{array}\right), \quad\left|s_{y}=-\hbar / 2\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\hat{H}\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=-\gamma B \frac{1}{2} \hbar\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle \\
&\hat{H}\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=\gamma B \frac{1}{2} \hbar\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

any state of the particle can be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\psi(t)\rangle=& c_{1}\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle \exp \left(+i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
&+c_{2}\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle \exp \left(-i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the initial condition

$$
|\psi(t=0)\rangle=\left|s_{z}=\hbar / 2\right\rangle
$$

gives

$$
\left|s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=c_{1}\left|s_{y}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle+c_{2}\left|s_{y}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{1} &=\left\langle\frac{1}{2} \hbar=s_{y} \mid s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-i \\
1
\end{array}\right)^{+}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(i 1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i \\
c_{2} &=\left\langle-\frac{1}{2} \hbar=s_{y} \mid s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right)^{+}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(-i 1)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\psi(t)\rangle=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-i \\
1
\end{array}\right) \exp \left(i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} i \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
i \\
1
\end{array}\right) \exp \left(-i \frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right) \\
=& \cos \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\left|s_{z}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle-\sin \left(\frac{1}{2} \gamma B t\right)\left|s_{z}=-\frac{1}{2} \hbar\right\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$
3043.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

3044.Problem Statement:
A particle of spin $1 / 2$ and magnetic moment $\mu$ is placed in a magnetic field

$$
\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \hat{\mathbf{z}}+B_{1} \cos \omega t \hat{\mathbf{x}}-B_{1} \sin \omega t \hat{\mathbf{y}},
$$

which is often employed in magnetic resonance experiments.

Assume that the particle has spin up along the $+z$-axis at $t=0$ $\left(m_{s}=+1 / 2\right)$. Derive the probability to find the particle with spin down $\left(m_{s}=-1 / 2\right)$ at time $t>0$.

(Berkeley)
3044.Solution:
The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
H=-\mu \sigma \cdot \mathrm{B} .
$$

Letting

$$
\omega_{0}=\mu B_{0} / \hbar, \quad \omega_{1}=\mu B_{1} / \hbar,
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=-\mu\left(B_{0} \sigma_{z}+B_{1} \sigma_{x} \cos \omega t-B_{1} \sigma_{y} \sin \omega t\right) \\
&=-\hbar \omega_{0} \sigma_{z}-\hbar \omega_{1}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & e^{i \omega t} \\
e^{-i \omega t} & 0
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\sigma_{x}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right), \sigma_{y}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right), \sigma_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Let the wave function of the system be

$$
|t\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

The Schrödinger equation $i \hbar \partial_{t}|t\rangle=H|t\rangle$, or

$$
i\left(\begin{array}{l}
\dot{a} \\
\dot{b}
\end{array}\right)=-\omega_{0}\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)-\omega_{1}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & e^{i \omega t} \\
e^{-i \omega t} & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right),
$$

gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{a}=i \omega_{0} a+i \omega_{1} e^{i \omega t} b, \\
\dot{b}=-i \omega_{0} b+i \omega_{1} e^{-i \omega t} a .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a=\alpha \exp \left(i \omega_{0} t\right), \\
b=\beta \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Substitution in the above equations gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{\alpha}=i \omega_{1} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right] \beta, \\
\dot{\beta}=i \omega_{1} \exp \left[-i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right] \alpha .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Assume that $\alpha$ and $\beta$ have the forms

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\alpha=A_{1} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega+\Omega\right) t\right], \\
\beta=A_{2} e^{i \Omega t}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $A_{1}, A_{2}$, and $\Omega$ are constants. Substitution gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega+\Omega\right) A_{1}-\omega_{1} A_{2}=0, \\
-\omega_{1} A_{1}+\Omega A_{2}=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

For this set of equations to have nontrivial solutions the determinant of the coefficients of $A_{1}, A_{2}$ must be zero, i.e.,

$$
\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega+\Omega\right) \Omega-\omega_{1}^{2}=0,
$$

giving

$$
\Omega_{\pm}=-\left(-\omega_{0}+\frac{\omega}{2}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(-\omega_{0}+\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} .
$$

Therefore the general form of $\beta$ is

$$
\beta=A_{2+} \exp \left(i \Omega_{+} t\right)+A_{2-} \exp \left(i \Omega_{-} t\right),
$$

and that of $\alpha$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha=& \frac{\dot{\beta} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{i \omega_{1}} \\
=& \frac{1}{\omega_{1}} \exp \left[i\left(-2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]\left[\Omega_{+} A_{2+} \exp \left(i \Omega_{+} t\right)\right.\\
&\left.+\Omega_{-} A_{2-} \exp \left(i \Omega_{-} t\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Initially the spin is up along the $z$-axis, so

giving

$$
|t=0\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
a(0) \\
b(0)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\alpha(0) \\
\beta(0)
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\omega_{1}}\left(\Omega_{+} A_{2+}+\Omega_{-} A_{2-}\right) &=1, \\
A_{2+}+A_{2-} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The solution is

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{2+} &=-A_{2-}=\omega_{1} /\left(\Omega_{+}-\Omega_{-}\right) \\
&=\frac{\omega_{1}}{2 \sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
b(t)=& \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) \beta(t) \\
=& \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) A_{2+} \\
& \times\left[\exp \left(i \Omega_{+} t\right)-\exp \left(i \Omega_{-} t\right)\right] \\
=& \exp (-i \omega t / 2) 2 i A_{2+} \\
& \times \sin \left(\sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} t\right) \\
=& \frac{i \omega_{1} \exp [-i(\omega / 2) t]}{\sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}}} \\
& \times \sin \left(\sqrt{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The probability that the particle has spin down along the $z$-axis at time $t$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=|\langle z \downarrow \mid t\rangle|^{2} \\
&=|b(t)|^{2}=\frac{\omega_{1}^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\sqrt{\left.\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} t\right)}{\left(\omega_{0}-\omega / 2\right)^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

3046.Problem Statement:
A spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ system of magnetic moment $\mu$ is placed in a dc magnetic field $H_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}$ in which the energy of the spin state $|+1 / 2\rangle$ is $\hbar \omega_{0}$, that of $|-1 / 2\rangle$ being taken as 0 . The system is in the state $|-1 / 2\rangle$ when at $t=0$, a magnetic field $H\left(\mathbf{e}_{x} \cos \omega_{0} t+\mathbf{e}_{y} \sin \omega_{0} t\right)$ is suddenly turned on. Ignoring relaxation find the energy of the spin system as a function of $\omega_{0}, H, c$ and $t$, where

$$
c=\left\langle+1 / 2\left|\mu_{x}+i \mu_{y}\right|-1 / 2\right\rangle .
$$

Why is the energy of the spin system not conserved?
3046.Solution:
The Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H} &=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot\left(\mathbf{H}+\mathbf{H}_{0}\right)=-\mu \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot\left(\mathbf{H}+\mathbf{H}_{0}\right) \\
&=-\mu\left(H \sigma_{x} \cos \omega_{0} t+H \sigma_{y} \sin \omega_{0} t+H_{0} \sigma_{z}\right) \\
&=-\mu\left(\begin{array}{cc}
H_{0} & H \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) \\
H \exp \left(i \omega_{0} t\right) & -H_{0}
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \partial \psi / \partial t=\hat{H} \psi
$$

setting

$$
\psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}
a(t) \\
b(t)
\end{array}\right)
$$

we get

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d a}{d t}=\frac{\mu i}{\hbar}\left[H_{0} a+H \exp \left(-i \omega_{0} t\right) b\right] \\
\frac{d b}{d t}=\frac{\mu i}{\hbar}\left[H \exp \left(i \omega_{0} t\right) a-H_{0} b\right]
\end{array}\right.
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a=A \exp \left[-i\left(\Omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right) t\right] \\
&b=B \exp \left[-i\left(\Omega-\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right) t\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A, B$ and $\Omega$ are constants. Substitution gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(\Omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) A+\omega^{\prime} B=0 \\
\left(\Omega-\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}-\omega\right) B+\omega^{\prime} A=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega &=\frac{\mu H_{0}}{\hbar}, \\
\omega^{\prime} &=\frac{\mu H}{\hbar}
\end{aligned}
$$

For nontrivial solutions we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\Omega+\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) & \omega^{\prime} \\
\omega^{\prime} & \Omega-\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

giving

$$
\Omega=\pm \sqrt{\omega^{\prime 2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)^{2}}=\pm Q
$$

where $Q=\left|\sqrt{\omega^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)^{2}}\right|$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(t)=&\left(A_{1} e^{-i Q t}+A_{2} e^{i Q t}\right) \exp \left(-i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \alpha \\
&+\left(B_{1} e^{-i Q t}+B_{2} e^{i Q t}\right) \exp \left(i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
B_{1,2}=-A_{1,2} \frac{\Omega_{1,2}+\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{\omega^{\prime}}
$$

the subscripts 1,2 corresponding to the values of $\Omega$ with $+,-$ signs respectively, and

$$
\alpha=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right), \quad \beta=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

At $t=0$ the system is in the $\left|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle$ state and $\psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$. Thus $B_{1}+$ $B_{2}=1, A_{1}+A_{2}=0$. Then as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(Q+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) A_{1}+\omega^{\prime} B_{1}=0 \\
\left(-Q+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right) A_{2}+\omega^{\prime} B_{2}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q\left(A_{1}-A_{2}\right)+\omega^{\prime} &=0 \\
\left(\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}+\omega\right)\left(A_{1}-A_{2}\right)+\omega^{\prime}\left(B_{1}-B_{2}\right) &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{1} &=-\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{2 Q}, \quad A_{2}=\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{2 Q} \\
B_{1} &=\frac{Q+\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{2 Q} \\
B_{2} &=\frac{Q-\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{2 Q}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore the wave function of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(t)=& \frac{\omega^{\prime}}{Q} i \sin (Q t) \exp \left(-i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \alpha \\
&+\left[\cos Q t-i \frac{\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)}{Q} \sin Q t\right] \exp \left(i \frac{\omega_{0}}{2} t\right) \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

and the energy of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=&\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle=-\mu\left[-H_{0} \cos ^{2} Q t\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{\omega^{2} H_{0}-\left(\omega+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0}\right)^{2} H_{0}-2 \omega^{\prime} H\left(\omega+\frac{\omega_{0}}{2}\right)}{Q^{2}} \sin ^{2} Q t\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that as

$$
\begin{aligned}
c &=\left\langle+\frac{1}{2}\left|\mu_{x}+i \mu_{y}\right|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\mu\left\langle+\frac{1}{2}\left|\sigma_{x}+i \sigma_{y}\right|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle \\
&=\mu\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 2 \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=2 \mu, \\
\mu &=\frac{c}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As the energy of the system changes with time $t$, it is not conserved. This is because with regard to spin it is not an isolated system.

3047.a.Problem Statement:
A beam of neutrons of velocity $v$ passes from a region (I) (where the magnetic field is $\mathbf{B}=B_{1} \mathbf{e}_{z}$ ) to a region (II) (where the field is $\mathbf{B}=B_{2} \mathbf{e}_{x}$ ). In region (I) the beam is completely polarized in the $+z$ direction.

Assuming that a given particle passes from (I) to (II) at time $t=0$, what is the spin wave function of that particle for $t>0$ ?
3047.a.Solution:
Considering only the spin wave function, the Schrödinger equation is

$$
i \hbar \partial|\chi\rangle / \partial t=\hat{H}|\chi\rangle
$$

where

$$
\hat{H}=-\mu \cdot \mathrm{B}=-\mu_{n} B_{2} \sigma_{x},
$$

with $\mu_{n}=-1.9103 \mu_{N}$ being the anomalous magnetic moment of the neutron, $\mu_{N}=e \hbar / 2 m_{p} c$ the nuclear magneton, $m_{p}$ the mass of a proton. Thus

$$
\frac{d}{d t}|\chi\rangle=\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu_{n} B_{2} \sigma_{x}|\chi\rangle \equiv-i \omega_{2} \sigma_{x}|\chi\rangle
$$

where $\omega_{2}=\frac{\left|\mu_{n}\right| B_{2}}{\hbar}$. Let $|\chi\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}a \\ b\end{array}\right)$. The above gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{a}=-i \omega_{2} b, \\
\dot{b}=-i \omega_{2} a .
\end{array}\right.
$$

The initial condition is $a(0)=1, b(0)=0$ as the beam is initially polarized in the $+z$ direction. Solving for $a$ and $b$ and using the initial condition we obtain for $t>0$ 

$$
|\chi\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\cos \omega_{2} t \\
-i \sin \omega_{2} t
\end{array}\right)
$$

3048.a.Problem Statement:
The Hamiltonian for a $\left(\mu^{+} e^{-}\right)$atom in the $n=1, l=0$ state in an external magnetic field $B$ is

$$
H=a \mathbf{s}_{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{s}_{e}+\frac{|e|}{m_{e} c} \mathbf{s}_{e} \cdot \mathbf{B}-\frac{|e|}{m_{\mu} c} \mathbf{s}_{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B} .
$$

What is the physical significance of each term? Which term dominates in the interaction with the external field?
3048.a.Solution: The first term in $\hat{H}$ is due to the magnetic interaction between $\mu$ and $e$, the second and third terms respectively account for the magnetic interactions of $\mu$ and $e$ with the external field $\mathbf{B}$. Of the latter, the term $|e| \mathbf{s}_{e} \cdot \mathbf{B} / m_{e} c$ is dominant as $m_{e} \approx m_{\mu} / 200$.

4003.b.Problem Statement:
The Hamiltonian for a spinless charged particle in a magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}$ is

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r})\right)^{2},
$$

where $e$ is the charge of particle, $\mathbf{p}=\left(p_{x} p_{y}, p_{z}\right)$ is the momentum conjugate to the particle's position $\mathbf{r}$. Let $A=-B_{0} y \mathbf{e}_{x}$, corresponding to a constant magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}$.

Find the (quantum) energy levels of this system.
4003.b.Solution:
The Hamiltonian for the particle can be written as

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(p_{x}+\frac{e B_{0}}{c} y\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{y}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{z}^{2} .
$$

As $H$ does not depend on $x$ and $z$ explicitly, the basic commutation relations in quantum mechanics

$$
\left[x_{i}, p_{j}\right]=i \hbar \delta_{i j},\left[p_{i}, p_{j}\right]=0,
$$

require

$$
\left[p_{x}, H\right]=0,\left[p_{z}, H\right]=0,
$$

which show that $p_{x}, p_{z}$ are constants of the motion.

In view of (a) we can choose $\left\{H, p_{x}, p_{z}\right\}$ as a complete set of mechanical variables. The corresponding eigenfunction is

$$
\psi(x, y, z)=e^{i\left(x p_{x}+z p_{z}\right) / \hbar} \phi(y)
$$

where $p_{x}, p_{z}$ are no longer operators but are now constants. The Schrödinger equation

$$
H \psi(x, y, z)=E \psi(x, y, z)
$$

then gives

or

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\left(p_{x}+\frac{e B_{0}}{c} y\right)^{2}-\hbar^{2} \frac{d^{2}}{d y^{2}}+p_{z}^{2}\right] \phi(y)=E \phi(y)
$$

Setting

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \phi}{d y^{2}}+\frac{m}{2}\left(\frac{e B_{0}}{m c}\right)^{2}\left(y+\frac{c p_{x}}{e B_{0}}\right)^{2} \phi=\left(E-\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m}\right) \phi
$$

$$
\omega=\frac{|e| B_{0}}{m c}, y^{\prime}=y+\frac{c p_{x}}{e B_{0}}, E^{\prime}=E-\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m},
$$

we can write the equation as

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \phi}{d y^{\prime 2}}+\frac{m}{2} \omega^{2} y^{\prime 2} \phi=E^{\prime} \phi,
$$

which is the energy eigenequation for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator. The energy eigenvalues are therefore

$$
E^{\prime}=E-p_{z}^{2} / 2 m=(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega, n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

Hence the energy levels for the system are

$$
E_{n}=p_{z}^{2} / 2 m+(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega, n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$
4003.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

4005.Problem Statement:
Write down the Hamiltonian for a spinless charged particle in a magnetic field. Show that the gauge transformation $\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r}) \rightarrow \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r})+\nabla f(\mathbf{r})$ is equivalent to multiplying the wave function by the factor $\exp [i e f(r) / \hbar c]$. What is the significance of this result? Consider the case of a uniform field $B$ directed along the $z$-axis. Show that the energy levels can be written as

$$
E=(n+1 / 2) \frac{|e| \hbar}{m c} B+\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{z}^{2}}{2 m} .
$$

Discuss the qualitative features of the wave functions.

Hint: use the gauge where $A_{x}=-B y, A_{y}=A_{z}=0$.
4005.Solution:
The Hamiltonian for the particle is

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}
$$

where $\mathbf{A}$ is related to the magnetic field by 

$$
\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A} .
$$

The Schrödinger equation is then

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi(\mathbf{r})=E \psi(\mathbf{r})
$$

Suppose we make the transformation

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r}) \rightarrow \mathbf{A}^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r})+\nabla f(\mathbf{r}), \\
& \psi(\mathbf{r}) \rightarrow \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=\psi(\mathbf{r}) \exp \left\{\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right\},
\end{aligned}
$$

and consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}^{\prime}\right) \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r}) &=\hat{\mathbf{p}} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})-\left[\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}+\frac{e}{c} \nabla f(\mathbf{r})\right] \exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right] \psi(\mathbf{r}) \\
&=\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right]\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right) \psi(\mathbf{r}) \\
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r}) &=\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right]\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi(\mathbf{r})
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used

$$
\hat{\mathbf{p}} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{\hbar}{i} \nabla\left\{\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right] \psi(\mathbf{r})\right\}=\exp \left[\frac{i e}{\hbar c} f(\mathbf{r})\right]\left[\frac{e}{c} \nabla f(\mathbf{r})+\hat{\mathbf{p}}\right] \psi(\mathbf{r}) .
$$

Substitution in Schrödinger's equation gives

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r})=E \psi^{\prime}(\mathbf{r}) .
$$

This shows that under the gauge transformation $\mathbf{A}^{\prime}=\mathbf{A}+\nabla f$, the Schrödinger equation remains the same and that there is only a phase difference between the original and the new wave functions. Thus the system has gauge invariance.

Now consider the case of a uniform field $\mathbf{B}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=B \mathbf{e}_{z}$, for which we have

$$
A_{x}=-B y, \quad A_{y}=A_{z}=0 .
$$

The Hamiltonian can be written as

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\left(\hat{p}_{x}+\frac{e B}{c} y\right)^{2}+\hat{p}_{y}^{2}+\hat{p}_{z}^{2}\right] .
$$

Since $\left[\hat{p}_{x}, \hat{H}\right]=\left[\hat{p}_{z}, \hat{H}\right]=0$ as $H$ does not depend on $x, z$ explicitly, we may choose the complete set of mechanical variables $\left(\hat{p}_{x}, \hat{p}_{z}, \hat{H}\right)$. The corresponding eigenstate is

$$
\psi(x, y, z)=e^{i\left(p_{x} x+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar} \chi(y) .
$$

Substituting it into the Schrödinger equation, we have

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\left(p_{x}+\frac{e B}{c} y\right)^{2}-\hbar^{2} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y^{2}}+p_{z}^{2}\right] \chi(y)=E \chi(y)
$$

Let $c p_{x} / e B=-y_{0}$. Then the above equation becomes

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \chi^{\prime \prime}+\frac{m}{2}\left(\frac{e B}{m c}\right)^{2}\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2} \chi=\left(E-p_{z}^{2} / 2 m\right) \chi
$$

which is the equation of motion of a harmonic oscillator. Hence the energy levels are

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} k_{z}^{2}+\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \frac{|e| B}{m c}, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots,
$$

where $k_{z}=p_{z} / \hbar$, and the wave functions are

$$
\psi_{p_{x} p_{z} n}(x, y, z)=e^{i\left(p_{x} x+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar} \chi_{n}\left(y-y_{0}\right),
$$

where

$$
\chi_{n}\left(y-y_{0}\right) \sim \exp \left[-\frac{|e| B}{2 \hbar c}\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}\right] H_{n}\left(\sqrt{\frac{|e| B}{\hbar c}}\left(y-y_{0}\right)\right)
$$

$H_{n}$ being Hermite polynomials. As the expressions for energy does not depend on $p_{x}$ and $p_{z}$ explicitly, there are infinite degeneracies with respect to $p_{x}$ and $p_{z}$
4005.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

4006.b.Problem Statement:
A point particle of mass $m$ and charge $q$ moves in spatially constant crossed magnetic and electric fields $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \hat{\mathbf{z}}, \mathbf{E}=E_{0} \hat{\mathbf{x}}$.

Evaluate the expectation value of the velocity $\mathbf{v}$ in a state of zero momentum.
4006.b.Solution:
Choose a gauge $\mathbf{A}=B_{0} x \hat{\mathbf{y}}, \varphi=-E_{0} x$ so that $\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=B_{0} \hat{\mathbf{z}}$, $-\nabla \cdot \varphi=E_{0}$. Then

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}+q \varphi=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{x}^{2}+\left(p_{y}-\frac{q}{c} B_{0} x\right)^{2}+p_{z}^{2}\right]-q E_{0} x .
$$

As $H$ does not depend on $y$ and $z$ explicitly, $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$ each commutes with $H$, so that $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$ are conserved. Thus they can be replaced by their eigenvalues directly. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=& \frac{1}{2 m} p_{x}^{2}+\frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2 m c^{2}}\left(x-\frac{c p_{y}}{q B_{0}}-\frac{c^{2} m E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}}\right)^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{z}^{2}-\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}^{2}}{2 B_{0}^{2}}-\frac{c p_{y} E_{0}}{B_{0}}=\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\xi}^{2} \\
&+\frac{m}{2} \omega^{2} \xi^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{z}^{2}-\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}^{2}}{2 B_{0}^{2}}-\frac{c p_{y} E_{0}}{B_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
p_{\xi}=p_{x}, \quad \xi=x-\frac{c p_{y}}{q B_{0}}-\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}}
$$

are a new pair of conjugate variables. Let $\omega=|q| B_{0} / m c$. By comparing the expression of $H$ with that for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator, we get the eigenvalues of $H$ :

$$
E_{n}=(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega+p_{z}^{2} / 2 m-m c^{2} E_{0}^{2} / 2 B_{0}^{2}-c p_{y} E_{0} / B_{0}, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

The fact that only $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$, but not $y$ and $z$, appear in the expression for energy indicates an infinite degeneracy exists with respect to $p_{y}$ and to $p_{z}$

A state of zero momentum signifies one in which the eigenvalues of $p_{y}$ and $p_{z}$ as well as the expectation value of $p_{x}$ are all zero. As velocity is defined as

$$
\mathbf{v}=\frac{1}{m} \mathbf{p}_{\mathrm{mec}}=\frac{1}{m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)
$$

its expectation value is

$$
\langle\mathbf{v}\rangle=\frac{1}{m}\left\langle\mathbf{p}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right\rangle=-\frac{q}{m c}\langle\mathbf{A}\rangle=-\frac{q B_{0}}{m c}\langle x\rangle \hat{\mathbf{y}} .
$$

Then as

$$
\langle x\rangle=\langle\xi\rangle+\frac{c p_{y}}{q B_{0}}+\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}}=\frac{m c^{2} E_{0}}{q B_{0}^{2}},
$$

since $\langle\xi\rangle=0$ for a harmonic oscillator and $p_{y}=0$, we have

$$
\langle\mathbf{v}\rangle=-\frac{c E_{0}}{B_{0}} \hat{\mathbf{y}} .
$$

4007.Problem Statement:
Determine the energy levels, their degeneracy and the corresponding eigenfunctions of an electron contained in a cube of essentially infinite volume $L^{3}$. The electron is in an electromagnetic field characterized by the vector potential

$$
\mathbf{A}=H_{0} x \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{y} \quad\left(\left|\hat{\mathbf{e}}_{y}\right|=1\right) .
$$
4007.Solution:
As $\mathbf{A}=H_{0} x \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{y}$, we have the Schrödinger equation

$$
\hat{H} \psi=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\hat{p}_{x}^{2}+\hat{p}_{z}^{2}+\left(\hat{p}_{y}-H_{0} x e / c\right)^{2}\right] \psi=E \psi,
$$

where $e$ is the electron charge $(e<0)$.

As $\left[\hat{H}, \hat{p}_{y}\right]=\left[\hat{H}, \hat{p}_{z}\right]=0,\left[\hat{p}_{y}, \hat{p}_{z}\right]=0$, we can choose $\hat{H}, \hat{p}_{y}, \hat{p}_{z}$ as a complete set of mechanical variables, the corresponding eigenfunction being

$$
\psi=e^{i\left(p_{y} y+p_{z} z\right) / \hbar} \psi_{0}(x),
$$

where $p_{y}, p_{z}$ are arbitrary real numbers. Substitution of $\psi$ in the Schrödinger equation gives

where $E_{0}=E-p_{z}^{2} / 2 m$, or

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[\hat{p}_{x}^{2}+\left(e H_{0} / c\right)^{2}\left(x-c p_{y} / e H_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \psi_{0}=E_{0} \psi_{0}
$$

where $x_{0}=c p_{y} / e H_{0}$.

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} d^{2} \psi_{0} / d x^{2}+\frac{m}{2}\left(H_{0} e / c m\right)^{2}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2} \psi_{0}=E_{0} \psi_{0}
$$

The last equation is the energy eigenequation of a one-dimensional oscillator of natural frequency $\omega_{0}=-H_{0} e / m c$ and equilibrium position $x=x_{0}$, the energy eigenvalues being

$$
E_{0}=(n+1 / 2) \hbar \omega_{0}, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots,
$$

or

$$
E=p_{z}^{2} / 2 m-(n+1 / 2) H_{0} e \hbar / m c, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

The corresponding eigenfunctions are

$$
\psi_{0 n} \sim \exp \left[\frac{e H_{0}}{2 \hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}\right] H_{n}\left(-\frac{e H_{0}}{\hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)\right)
$$

where $H_{n}$ are Hermite polynomials.

As no $p_{y}$ terms occur in the expression for energy levels and $p_{y}$ can be any arbitrary real number, the degeneracies of energy levels are infinite.

The eigenfunctions for the original system are therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(\mathbf{x})=& C_{n} \exp \left[\frac{i\left(p_{y} y+p_{z} z\right)}{\hbar}+\frac{e H_{0}}{2 \hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \times H_{n}\left(-\frac{e H_{0}}{\hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{n}$ is the normalization constant.

4007.Final Answer: $$C_{n} \exp \left[\frac{i\left(p_{y} y+p_{z} z\right)}{\hbar}+\frac{e H_{0}}{2 \hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}\right]  \times H_{n}\left(-\frac{e H_{0}}{\hbar c}\left(x-x_{0}\right)\right)$$

4008.b.Problem Statement:
Consider a loop of thin wire in the shape of a circle of radius $R$ (Fig. 4.1). A constant magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the loop produces a magnetic flux passing through the loop. Imagine that the wire contains only one electron which is free to move. This electron has a wave function $\psi(\theta)$ which depends only upon the angular $\operatorname{coordinate} \theta$. Neglect all interactions between the electron spin and the magnetic field as well as all magnetic fields produced by the electron itself.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-274.jpg?height=335&width=433&top_left_y=1265&top_left_x=442)

Fig. 4.1

Imagine that we start with the wire in its ground state in the presence of a magnetic flux $\phi$. Next the magnetic field is turned off. Calculate the current in the loop.
4008.b.Solution:
In cylindrical coordinates $r, \theta$, $z$, as $\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=B \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{z}$ where $B$ is a constant, we can take $A_{r}=A_{z}=0, A_{\theta}=\frac{r B}{2}$, i.e., $\mathbf{A}=\frac{r B}{2} \hat{\mathbf{e}}_{\theta}$, and consider the Schrödinger equation for the electron,

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi=E \psi
$$

where $e$ is the electron charge $(e<0)$. Let

$$
\psi=\psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right)
$$

Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right) \psi &=\exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right)\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}+\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right) \psi^{\prime} \\
&=\exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) \hat{\mathbf{p}} \psi^{\prime} \\
\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2} \psi &=\exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{x} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) \hat{\mathbf{p}}^{2} \psi^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

the Schrödinger equation becomes

$$
\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{\mathbf{p}}^{2} \psi^{\prime}=E \psi^{\prime} .
$$

Since the electron is confined to a loop of radius $R$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi=\psi(\theta) &=\psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int_{r=R} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right)=\psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} \int^{\theta} A R d \theta\right) \\
& \propto \psi^{\prime} \exp \left(\frac{i e}{c \hbar} A R \theta\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\psi^{\prime}=\psi^{\prime}(\theta)$ and $\hat{p}=-\frac{i \hbar}{R} \frac{d}{d \theta}$. Thus we have

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}} \frac{d^{2} \psi^{\prime}(\theta)}{d \theta^{2}}=E \psi^{\prime}(\theta),
$$

with solution

$$
\psi^{\prime}(\theta) \sim e^{i c_{1} \theta},
$$

where $c_{1}$ is a constant given by $E=\frac{\hbar^{2} c_{1}^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}$. Thus

$$
\psi(\theta) \sim \exp \left[i\left(c_{1}+e A R / c \hbar\right) \theta\right] .
$$

For single-valuedness, $\psi(\theta)=\psi(\theta+2 \pi)$, i.e.,

$$
2 \pi\left(c_{1}+e A R / c \hbar\right)=2 n \pi,
$$

where $n$ is zero or an integer $(0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots)$. Solving for $c_{1}$ we have

$$
c_{1}=n-e A R / c \hbar=n-e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar,
$$

and hence

$$
E_{n}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}\left(n-e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar\right)^{2}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}\left(n+\phi / \phi_{0}\right)^{2},
$$

where $\phi=\pi R^{2} B, \phi_{0}=-c h / e$. It is seen that the dependence of $E_{n}$ on the external magnetic field $B$ or the flux $\phi$ is parabolic, as shown in Fig. 4.2.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-276.jpg?height=342&width=343&top_left_y=1227&top_left_x=487)

Fig. $4.2$

As $n$ is an integer, the ground state (lowest energy level) energy $E_{g}$ is given by

$$
E_{g}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}}\left[n^{*}-e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar\right]^{2}
$$

where $n^{*}$ is the integer nearest to $e R^{2} B / 2 c \hbar$ (or $e \phi / c h$ ), which is negative as $e$ is negative for an electron.

Suppose we start with a state $E_{n}$ which is the ground state, $n$ will remain the same when $B$ is turned off. Thus the wave function will be $\psi=C \exp (i n \theta)$ and the electric current density is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{j} &=\left.e \frac{\hbar}{2 m i}\left(\psi^{*} \nabla \psi-\psi \nabla \psi^{*}\right)\right|_{r=R}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m i}(i n) \frac{2}{R} \psi^{*} \psi \hat{e}_{\theta} \\
&=\frac{e \hbar n}{m R} \psi^{*} \psi \hat{e}_{\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C$ is the normalization constant. Let $S$ denote the cross section of the thin wire. We have from the normalization condition

$$
\int \psi^{*} \psi d l d S=2 \pi R|C|^{2} S=1
$$

that

$$
|C|^{2}=\frac{1}{2 \pi R S} .
$$

Hence

$$
I=\int \mathbf{j} \cdot d \mathbf{S}=\frac{e \hbar n}{m R}|C|^{2} S=\frac{e \hbar n}{2 \pi m R^{2}} .
$$

Note that $\mathbf{j}$ has been considered to be uniform in any cross section as the wire is thin.

Because the electron is initially in the ground state, for which $E_{n}$ is the minimum energy, we have

$$
n=\left[\frac{e \phi}{c h}\right] \quad \text { or } \quad\left[\frac{e \phi}{c h}\right]-1,
$$

where $[A]$ denotes the greatest integer which is not greater than $A$.

For the case of macroscopic magnetudes as in part (c), the quantum number is numerically large and we can simply use $n \approx e \phi / c h$, in which case

$$
I \approx e^{2} \phi / 4 \pi^{2} R^{2} m c .
$$

4009.b.Problem Statement: What is the quantum mechanical Hamiltonian for a free electron with magnetic moment $\mu$ in the external constant magnetic field $H_{z}$ in the $z$-direction, in the reference frame of the electron?
4009.b.Solution:
Consider the Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(t)=\hat{H} \psi(t)
$$

Making the time reversal transformation $t \rightarrow-t$, we obtain

$$
-i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(-t)=\hat{H}(-t) \psi(-t)
$$

or

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi^{*}(-t)=\hat{H}^{*}(-t) \psi^{*}(-t) .
$$

If $\hat{H}^{*}(-t)=\hat{H}(t)$, then the Schrödinger equation is covariant under time reversal and the time reversed form of the wave function is $\psi^{*}(-t)$.

Let $-e$ be the charge of the electron. Then $\boldsymbol{\mu}=-\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c} \sigma$ and in the reference frame of the electron,

$$
\hat{H}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{H}=-\mu_{z} H_{z}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c} \sigma_{z} H_{z} .
$$
4009.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

4009.c.Problem Statement: Suppose that an extra constant magnetic field $H_{y}$ is imposed in the $y$-direction. Determine the form of the quantum mechanical operator for the time rate of change of $\mu$ in this case.
4009.c.Solution:
Consider the Schrödinger equation

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(t)=\hat{H} \psi(t)
$$

Making the time reversal transformation $t \rightarrow-t$, we obtain

$$
-i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(-t)=\hat{H}(-t) \psi(-t)
$$

or

$$
i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi^{*}(-t)=\hat{H}^{*}(-t) \psi^{*}(-t) .
$$

If $\hat{H}^{*}(-t)=\hat{H}(t)$, then the Schrödinger equation is covariant under time reversal and the time reversed form of the wave function is $\psi^{*}(-t)$.

Let $-e$ be the charge of the electron. Then $\boldsymbol{\mu}=-\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c} \sigma$ and in the reference frame of the electron,

$$
\hat{H}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{H}=-\mu_{z} H_{z}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c} \sigma_{z} H_{z} .
$$The magnetic field is now $H_{y} \hat{\mathbf{y}}+H_{z} \hat{\mathbf{z}}$, and so

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\left(\sigma_{z} H_{z}+\sigma_{y} H_{y}\right),
$$

SO

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \mu}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}[\mu, \hat{H}]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left(\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\right)^{2}\left[-\sigma_{x} \hat{\mathbf{x}}-\sigma_{y} \hat{\mathbf{y}}-\sigma_{z} \hat{\mathbf{z}},\right.\\
\left.\sigma_{z} H_{z}+\sigma_{y} H_{y}\right]=& \frac{2}{\hbar}\left(\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\right)^{2}\left[\left(\sigma_{y} H_{z}-\sigma_{z} H_{y}\right) \hat{x}-\sigma_{x} H_{z} \hat{y}\right.\\
&\left.+i \sigma_{x} H_{y} \hat{z}\right]=\frac{2}{\hbar}\left(\frac{e \hbar}{2 m c}\right)^{2} \sigma \times \mathbf{H} \\
=& \frac{e}{m c} \mathbf{H} \times \mu
\end{aligned}
$$

where use has been made of the relations $\sigma_{x} \sigma_{y}=i \sigma_{z}, \sigma_{y} \sigma_{z}=i \sigma_{x}$, $\sigma_{z} \sigma_{x}=i \sigma_{y}$
4009.c.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

4010.d.Problem Statement:
A particle has mass $m$, charge $q$, intrinsic angular momentum $\mathbf{s}(s$ is not necessarily equal to $\hbar / 2)$ and a magnetic dipole moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}=g q \mathbf{s} / 2 m c$. The particle moves in a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ with a velocity small compared with $c$.

(Helicity is defined here as the cosine of the angle between the vectors $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{s})$

What is the actual value of the constant $g$ for any one of the following particles: $e, p, n, \pi$ ?
4010.d.Solution:
The Hamiltonian for the system is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=& \frac{1}{2 m}\left(\mathbf{P}-\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\frac{1}{2 m} \mathbf{P}^{2}-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P} \\
&+\frac{q^{2}}{2 m c^{2}} \mathbf{A}^{2}-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Neglecting terms $A^{2}$ and higher in $H$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d P_{i}}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[P_{i}, H\right]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[P_{i},-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P}\right.\\
&\left.-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right]=\frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left[P_{i}, A_{j} P_{j}\right] \\
=& \frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left(P_{i} A_{j} P_{j}-A_{j} P_{j} P_{i}\right) \\
=& \frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left[\left(P_{i} A_{j}\right) P_{j}+A_{j} P_{i} P_{j}-A_{j} P_{j} P_{i}\right] \\
=& \frac{i q}{\hbar m c}\left(P_{i} A_{j}\right) P_{j}=\frac{q}{m c}\left(\partial_{i} A_{j}\right) P_{j} . \\
\frac{d s_{i}}{d t}=& \frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[s_{i}, H\right]=\frac{1}{i \hbar}\left[s_{i},-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] \\
&=\frac{i g q}{2 \hbar m c}\left[s_{i}, s_{j} B_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{-g q}{2 m c}\left(B_{j} s_{k}-B_{k} s_{j}\right) \\
&=-\frac{g q}{2 m c}(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{s})_{i},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\left[s_{i}, s_{j}\right]=i \hbar s_{k}$. Note that we have used the convention that repetition of a subscript implies summation over that subscript.

As $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{s}$ commute we can consider the problem in the common eigenstates of $\mathbf{P}, \mathbf{s}^{2}$ and $s_{z}$.

The helicity $h$ is defined as

$$
h=\mathbf{P} \cdot \mathbf{s} /|\mathbf{P}||\mathbf{s}|=\frac{P_{i} s_{i}}{|\mathbf{P}||\mathbf{s}|},
$$

and as

$$
\mathbf{A}_{i}=\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{r})_{i}=\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{i j k} B_{j} x_{k},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[h,-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P}\right] } &=\frac{-q}{m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[s_{i} P_{i}, A_{j} P_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{-q s_{i}}{m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[P_{i}, A_{j} P_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{q s_{i} P_{j}}{m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left(\frac{i \hbar}{2}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}\left(\varepsilon_{j k l} B_{k} x_{l}\right) \\
&=\frac{i \hbar q}{2 m c} \varepsilon_{j k l} \frac{s_{i}}{|\mathbf{s}|} \frac{P_{j}}{|\mathbf{P}|} B_{k} \delta_{i l} \\
&=\frac{i \hbar q}{2 m c} \varepsilon_{i j k} \frac{s_{i}}{|\mathbf{s}|} \frac{P_{j}}{|\mathbf{P}|} B_{k} \\
{\left[h,-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right] } &=\frac{-g q}{2 m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[s_{i} P_{i}, s_{j} B_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{-g q P_{i}}{2 m c|\mathbf{s}||\mathbf{P}|}\left[s_{i}, s_{j} B_{j}\right] \\
&=-\frac{i \hbar g q}{2 m c} \varepsilon_{i j k} \frac{s_{i}}{|\mathbf{s}|} \frac{P_{j}}{|\mathbf{P}|} B_{k} .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the helicity is a constant of the motion, then

$$
[h, H]=\left[h,-\frac{q}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{P}\right]+\left[h,-\frac{g q}{2 m c} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right]=0
$$

which requires $g=1$.

The values of $g$ for the various particles are

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Particle & $e$ & $p$ & $n$ & $\pi$ \\
\hline$g$ & $-2.0$ & $5.6$ & $-3.8$ & 0 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

4011.Problem Statement:
In a recent classic table-top experiment, a monochromatic neutron beam $(\lambda=1.445 \AA)$ was split by Bragg reflection at point $A$ of an interferometer into two beams which were recombined (after another reflection) at point $D$ (see Fig. 4.3). One beam passes through a region of transverse magnetic field of strength $B$ for a distance $l$. Assume that the two paths from $A$ to $D$ are identical except for the region of the field.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-282.jpg?height=343&width=582&top_left_y=298&top_left_x=368)

Fig. $4.3$

Find the explicit expressions for the dependence of the intensity at point $D$ on $\mathbf{B}, l$ and the neutron wavelength, with the neutron polarized either parallel or anti-parallel to the magnetic field.
4011.Solution:
This is a problem on spinor interference. Consider a neutron in the beam. There is a magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ in the region where the Schrödinger equation for the (uncharged) neutron is

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}-\mu \sigma \cdot \mathbf{B}\right) \psi=E \psi
$$

Supposing B to be constant and uniform, we have

$$
\psi\left(t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[-i \hat{H}\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right) / \hbar\right] \psi\left(t_{0}\right)
$$

where $t_{0}, t_{1}$ are respectively the instants when the neutron enters and leaves the magnetic field.

Write $\psi(t)=\psi(\mathbf{r}, t) \psi(\mathbf{s}, t)$, where $\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)$ and $\psi(\mathbf{s}, t)$ are respectively the space and spin parts of $\psi$. Then

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{r}, t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[-\frac{i}{\hbar}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2}\right)\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right)\right] \psi\left(\mathbf{r}, t_{0}\right)
$$

which is the same as the wave function of a free particle, and 

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[\frac{i}{\hbar} \mu \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right)\right] \psi\left(s, t_{0}\right) .
$$

The interference arises from the action of $\mathbf{B}$ on the spin wave function. As $\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)$ is the wave function of a free particle, we have $t_{1}-t_{0}=l / v=$ $m l / \hbar k$ and

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)=\exp \left[i 2 \pi \mu m l \lambda \sigma \cdot \mathbf{B} / h^{2}\right] \psi\left(s, t_{0}\right)
$$

where $k=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}=\frac{m v}{\hbar}$ is the wave number of the neutron. The intensity of the interference of the two beams at $D$ is then proportional to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left|\psi_{D}^{(1)}(\mathbf{r}, t) \psi_{D}^{(1)}(\mathbf{s}, t)+\psi_{D}^{(2)}(\mathbf{r}, t) \psi_{D}^{(2)}(\mathbf{s}, t)\right|^{2} \\
&\quad \propto\left|\psi_{D}^{(1)}(\mathbf{s}, t)+\psi_{D}^{(2)}(\mathbf{s}, t)\right|^{2}=\left|\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{0}\right)+\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\exp \left(i \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda}{h^{2}} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right)=& \cos \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}+i \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \frac{\mathbf{B}}{B} \\
& \times \sin \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\pm \sigma B$ depending on whether $\sigma$ is parallel or anti-parallel to $\mathbf{B}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{0}\right)+\psi^{(2)}\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{1}\right)\right|^{2}=&\left|1+\exp \left(i \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda}{h^{2}} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}\right)\right|^{2}\left|\psi\left(\mathbf{s}, t_{0}\right)\right|^{2} \\
=&\left|1+\cos \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}} \pm i \sigma \sin \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}\right|^{2} \\
=&\left(1+\cos \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}\right)^{2} \\
&+\sin ^{2} \frac{2 \pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}=4 \cos ^{2} \frac{\pi \mu m l \lambda B}{h^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the interference intensity at $D \propto \cos ^{2}\left(\pi \mu m l \lambda B / h^{2}\right)$, where $\mu$ is the intrinsic magnetic moment of the neutron $(\mu<0)$.

4014.a.Problem Statement:
Consider the one-dimensional motion of an uncharged particle of spin $1 / 2$ and magnetic moment $\mu=-2 \mu_{0} \mathrm{~s} / \hbar$. The particle is confined in an infinite square well extending from $x=-L$ to $x=L$. In region I $(x<0)$ there is a uniform magnetic field in the $z$ direction $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}$; in region II $(x>0)$ there is a uniform field of the same magnitude but pointing in the $x$ direction $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{x}$. Here $\mathbf{e}_{x}$ and $\mathbf{e}_{z}$ are unit vectors in the $x$ and $z$ directions.

Use perturbation theory to find the ground state energy and ground state wave function (both space and spin parts) in the weak field limit $B_{0} \ll(\hbar / L)^{2} / 2 m \mu_{0}$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-290.jpg?height=403&width=557&top_left_y=1093&top_left_x=380)

Fig. $4.5$
4014.a.Solution:
In the absence of magnetic field, $H=H_{0}$ and the energy eigenfunctions (space part) and eigenvalues are respectively

$$
\psi_{n}=\sqrt{1 / L} \sin \frac{n \pi(x+L)}{2 L},
$$

$$
E_{n}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} n^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}, \quad n=1,2,3, \ldots
$$

As for the spin part, we know that each energy level has a degeneracy of 2 . When a magnetic field is present, $H=H_{0}+H^{\prime}$, where

$$
H^{\prime}=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\frac{2 \mu_{0} \mathbf{s} \cdot \mathbf{B}}{\hbar}=\mu_{0} \boldsymbol{\sigma} \cdot \mathbf{B}= \begin{cases}\mu_{0} B_{0} \sigma_{z}, & -L \leq x \leq 0 \\ \mu_{0} B_{0} \sigma_{x}, & 0 \leq x \leq L \\ 0 & \text { elsewhere }\end{cases}
$$

If the field is weak, let $u_{1}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right), u_{2}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ be the base vectors. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
H_{11}^{\prime}=&\left\langle u_{1}\left|H^{\prime}\right| u_{1}\right\rangle=\mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right) \\
& \times \int_{-L}^{0} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}, \\
H_{21}^{\prime}=& H_{12}^{\prime}=\left\langle u_{1}\left|H^{\prime}\right| u_{2}\right\rangle \\
=& \mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \int_{0}^{L} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}, \\
H_{22}^{\prime}=&\left\langle\mu_{2}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \mu_{2}\right\rangle \\
=&-\mu_{0} B_{0}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{rr}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \int_{-L}^{0} \psi_{1}^{*}(x) \psi_{1}(x) d x=-\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and from det $\left(H^{\prime}-E^{(1)} I\right)=0$ we get

$$
\left(\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}-E^{(1)}\right)\left(-\frac{\mu_{0} B_{0}}{2}-E^{(1)}\right)-\frac{\mu_{0}^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{4}=0,
$$

or

$$
E^{(1)}=\pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mu_{0} B_{0} .
$$

The ground state energy level is therefore

$$
E_{0}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mu_{0} B_{0} .
$$

From

$$
\left(H^{\prime}-E^{(1)} I\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a \\
b
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

we get the ground state wave function

$$
\varphi_{0}=a u_{1}+b u_{2}=\psi_{1}(x)\left(\begin{array}{c}
1-\sqrt{2} \\
1
\end{array}\right) . \quad \text { (unnormalized) }
$$

4015.b.Problem Statement:
Consider an infinitely long solenoid which carries a current $I$ so that there is a constant magnetic field inside the solenoid. Suppose in the region outside the solenoid the motion of a particle with charge $e$ and mass $m$ is described by the Schrödinger equation. Assume that for $I=0$, the solution of the equation is given by

$$
\psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t)=e^{i E_{0} t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}) . \quad(\hbar=1)
$$

Consider a two-slit diffraction experiment for the particles described above (see Fig. 4.6). Assume that the distance $d$ between the two splits is large compared to the diameter of the solenoid. Compute the shift $\Delta S$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-294.jpg?height=322&width=617&top_left_y=789&top_left_x=350)

Fig. 4.6

of the diffraction pattern on the screen due to the presence of the solenoid with $I \neq 0$. Assume $l \gg \Delta S$.

Hint: Let

$$
\psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=\psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t) \psi_{A}(\mathbf{x})
$$

where

$$
\left(\nabla-i \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}(\mathbf{x})\right) \psi_{A}(\mathbf{x})=0 . \quad(\hbar=1) .
$$
4015.b.Solution:
In the presence of a vector potential $\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{p} \rightarrow \mathbf{p}-e \mathbf{A} / c$. In the absence of electromagnetic field the Schrödinger equation is

$$
i \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\left[\frac{1}{2 m} \mathbf{p}^{2}+V(\mathbf{x})\right] \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t),
$$

where, as below, we shall use units such that $\hbar=1$. The Schrödinger equation in the presence of an electromagnetic field can thus be obtained (using the minimum electromagnetic coupling theory) as

$$
i \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=\left[\frac{1}{2 m}\left(-i \nabla-\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}+V(\mathbf{x})\right] \psi(\mathbf{x}, t)
$$

where $A$ is given by $\nabla \times \mathbf{A}=\mathbf{B}$. Let

$$
\psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=\psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t) \exp \left(i \int^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) .
$$

Then the above becomes

$$
i \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\left[\frac{1}{2 m} \mathbf{p}^{2}+V(\mathbf{x})\right] \psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t),
$$

which is the Schrödinger equation for zero magnetic field. Hence

$$
\psi_{1}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}, t)=e^{i E_{0} t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}),
$$

and so

$$
\psi(\mathbf{x}, t)=e^{i E_{0} t} \psi_{0}(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left(i \int^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) .
$$

This is a problem on the Aharonov-Bohm effect. When $I=0$, for any point on the screen the probability amplitude $f$ is $f=f_{+}+f_{-}$, where $f_{+}$and $f_{-}$represent the contributions of the upper and lower slits respectively. When the current is on, i.e., $I \neq 0$, we have the probability amplitude $f^{\prime}=f_{+}^{\prime}+f_{-}^{\prime}$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{+}^{\prime} &=\exp \left(i \int_{c_{+}}^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{+}, \\
f_{-}^{\prime} &=\exp \left(i \int_{c_{-}}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{-},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $c_{+}$and $c_{-}$denote integral paths above and below the solenoid respectively. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}=& f_{+}^{\prime}+f_{-}^{\prime}=\exp \left(i \int_{c_{+}}^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{+}+\exp \left(i \int_{c_{-}}^{\mathbf{x}} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{-} \\
& \sim \exp \left(i \oint \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}\right) f_{-}+f_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

on dividing the two contributions by a common phase factor $\exp \left(i \int_{c_{+}}^{\mathbf{x}} \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right.$. $d \mathbf{x})$, which does not affect the interference pattern. The closed line integral, to be taken counterclockwise along an arbitrary closed path around the solenoid, gives

$$
\oint \frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{x}=\frac{e}{c} \int \nabla \times \mathbf{A} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\frac{e}{c} \int \mathbf{B} \cdot d \mathbf{s}=\frac{e \phi}{c},
$$

where $\phi$ is the magnetic flux through the solenoid.

Thus the introduction of the solenoid gives a phase factor $e \phi / c$ to the probability amplitude at points on the screen contributed by the lower slit.

Using a method analogous to the treatment of Young's interference in optics, we see that the interference pattern is shifted by $\Delta S$. Assuming $l \gg d$ and $l \gg \Delta S$, we have

$$
\Delta S \cdot \frac{d}{l} \cdot k=\frac{e}{c} \phi,
$$

$k$ being the wave number of the particles, and so

$$
\Delta S=\frac{e l \phi}{c d k}=\frac{e l \phi}{c d \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} .
$$

Note the treatment is only valid nonrelativistically.
