6056.Problem Statement:
Suppose that, because of a small parity-violating force, the $2^{2} S_{1 / 2}$ level of the hydrogen atom has a small $P$-wave admixture

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi(n&\left.=2, j=\frac{1}{2}\right)=\psi_{s}\left(n=2, j=\frac{1}{2}, l=0\right) \\
&+\varepsilon \psi_{p}\left(n=2, j=\frac{1}{2}, l=1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

What first-order radiative decay will de-excite this state? What is the form of the decay matrix element? What does it become if $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$, and why?
6056.Solution:
The first-order radiative decay is related to electric dipole transition. It causes the state to decay to $\psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}\right)$, which is two-fold degenerate, corresponding to $m_{j}=\pm \frac{1}{2}, l=0$. The matrix element for such an electric dipole transition is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
H_{12}^{\prime} &=\left\langle\psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}\right)|-e \mathbf{r}| \psi\left(n=2, j=\frac{1}{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
&=\varepsilon\left\langle\psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}\right)|-e \mathbf{r}| \psi_{p}\left(n=2, j=\frac{1}{2}, l=1\right)\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

because of the selection rule $\Delta l=\pm 1$ for the transition. Using non-coupling representation basic vectors to denote the relevant coupling representation basic vectors we have the following final and initial states:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}, m_{j}=\frac{1}{2}\right)=|100\rangle\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0\end{array}\right) \text {, } \\
& \psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}, m_{j}=-\frac{1}{2}\right)=|100\rangle\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\1\end{array}\right) \text {, } \\
& \psi_{p}\left(n=2, j=\frac{1}{2}, l=1, m_{j}=\frac{1}{2}\right)=-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}|210\rangle\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& +\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}|211\rangle\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\1\end{array}\right) \text {, } \\
& \psi_{p}\left(n=2, j=\frac{1}{2}, l=1, m_{j}=-\frac{1}{2}\right)=-\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}|21,-1\rangle\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0\end{array}\right) \\
& +\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}|210\rangle\left(\begin{array}{l}0 \\1\end{array}\right) \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the non-vanishing matrix elements of $H_{12}^{\prime}$ are

$$
\begin{gathered}
\varepsilon\left\langle\psi\left(n=1, j=m_{j}=\frac{1}{2}\right)|-e \mathbf{r}| \psi_{p}\left(m_{j}=\frac{1}{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} e \varepsilon\langle 100|\mathbf{r}| 210\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} e \varepsilon\langle 100|z| 210\rangle \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
=\frac{e \varepsilon}{3}\langle 100|r| 200\rangle \mathbf{e}_{z}=\frac{e \varepsilon A}{3} \mathbf{e}_{z}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $A=\langle 100|r| 200\rangle, \mathbf{e}_{z}$ is a unit vector along the $z$ direction,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \varepsilon\left\langle\psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}, m_{j}=-\frac{1}{2}\right)|-e \mathbf{r}| \psi_{p}\left(m_{j}=\frac{1}{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
& =-\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} e \varepsilon\langle 100|\mathbf{r}| 211\rangle \\
& =-\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} e \varepsilon\left\langle 100\left|x \mathbf{e}_{x}+y \mathbf{e}_{y}\right| 211\right\rangle=-\frac{e \varepsilon A}{3}\left(e_{x}+i \mathbf{e}_{y}\right) \text {, } \\
& \varepsilon\left\langle\psi\left(n=1, j=m_{j}=\frac{1}{2}\right)|-e \mathbf{r}| \psi_{p}\left(m_{j}=-\frac{1}{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
& =-\frac{e \varepsilon A}{3}\left(e_{x}-i e_{y}\right), \\
& \varepsilon\left\langle\psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}, m_{j}=-\frac{1}{2}\right)|-e \mathbf{r}| \psi_{p}\left(m_{j}=-\frac{1}{2}\right)\right\rangle \\
& =-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} e \varepsilon\langle 100|r| 210\rangle=\frac{e \varepsilon A}{3} e_{x} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the above we have used the relations

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=1, \quad\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=0, \quad \text { etc. } \\
\mathbf{r} &=x \mathbf{e}_{x}+y \mathbf{e}_{y}+z \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
&=r \sin \theta \cos \varphi \mathbf{e}_{x}+r \sin \theta \sin \varphi \mathbf{e}_{y}+r \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
\langle 100|z| 210\rangle &=\langle 100|r| 200\rangle\langle\ell=0, m=0|\cos \theta| \ell=1, m=0\rangle, \quad \text { etc., }
\end{aligned}
$$

and the selection rules

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Delta m=0 & \text { for the } z \text {-component of } e \mathbf{r} \\
\Delta m=\pm 1 & \text { for the } x \text {-, } y \text {-components of } e \mathbf{r}
\end{array}
$$

Thus if the parity of the $2^{2} S_{1 / 2}$ state is destroyed by the inclusion of the $\varepsilon$ term the electric dipole radiation would cause transition from the 2 ${ }^{2} S_{1 / 2}$ state to the ground state $1{ }^{2} S_{1 / 2}$, the probability of such de-excitation being $\propto \varepsilon^{2}$. If $\varepsilon=0$ electric dipole radiation does not allow de-excitation from the state

$$
\psi_{s}\left(n=2, j=\frac{1}{2}, l=0\right) \quad \text { to the state } \psi\left(n=1, j=\frac{1}{2}, l=0\right)
$$

because the perturbation $H^{\prime}$ is a polar vector whose the matrix elements are nonzero only when $\Delta l=\pm 1$.
6056.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

6057.a.Problem Statement:
The part of the Hamiltonian describing the hyperfine interaction between the electron and proton in atomic hydrogen is given by

$$
H^{\prime}=-\frac{8 \pi}{3} \mu_{e} \cdot \mu_{p} \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r}),
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}=\frac{e_{i} g_{i}}{2 m_{i} c} \mathbf{S}_{i}$ is the magnetic moment and $\mathbf{S}_{i}=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{i}$ is the spin of particle $i$ (the $\sigma^{\prime} s$ are Pauli matrices). Calculate the hyperfine splitting between the $1 s^{3} S_{1}$ and $1 s^{1} S_{0}$ states of atomic hydrogen. Which state has the lower energy? Explain why physically.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{A}=& {\left[-i \frac{\omega}{c}\langle\mathbf{x}\rangle+i \frac{\omega}{c} \hat{\mathbf{n}} \times \frac{e}{2 m_{e} c}\langle\mathbf{L}\rangle+i \frac{\omega e}{2 m_{e} c^{2}} \hat{\mathbf{n}} \times\left\langle\sigma_{e}\right\rangle+\ldots\right] } \\
& \times \frac{e^{i \frac{\omega}{c} r-i \omega t}}{r},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ is a unit vector along the direction of propagation of the radiation and $\langle\cdot\rangle$ denotes the matrix element for this transition. Show explicitly for each of the three terms whether or not $\langle\cdot\rangle$ is nonzero. What is the character of the radiation emitted in the transition?
6057.a.Solution:
Let the spatial wave function of $1 s$ state be $\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r})$, the spin singlet state be $\chi_{00}$, and the spin triplet state be $\chi_{1 M}(M=0, \pm 1)$.

The perturbation method for degenerate states is to be used, the perturbation Hamiltonian being 

$$
\begin{aligned}
H^{\prime}=& \frac{2 \pi}{3} \cdot \frac{e^{2} g_{e} g_{p}}{m_{e} m_{p} c^{2}} \mathbf{S}_{e} \cdot \mathbf{S}_{p} \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{B}{2}\left[\left(\mathbf{S}_{e}+\mathbf{S}_{p}\right)^{2}\right.\\
&\left.-\mathbf{S}_{e}^{2}-\mathbf{S}_{p}^{2}\right] \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{B}{2}\left[\mathbf{S}^{2}-\frac{3}{2} \hbar^{2}\right] \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r})
\end{aligned}
$$

where $B=\frac{2 \pi}{3} \frac{e^{2} g_{e} g_{p}}{m_{e} m_{p} c^{2}}$ and $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{S}_{e}+\mathbf{S}_{p}$, with $S_{e}^{2}=S_{p}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \hbar$. If $\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}) \chi_{00}$ and $\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}) \chi_{1 M}$ are chosen to be the basis vectors, then $H^{\prime}$ is a diagonal matrix. For the $1 s^{1} S_{0}$ energy level, $S=0$ and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_{1} &=\left\langle\psi_{0} \chi_{00}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{0} \chi_{00}\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{3}{4} B \hbar^{2}\left|\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}=0)\right|^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the $1 s^{3} S_{1}$ energy level, $S^{2}=1(1+1) \hbar^{2}$ and we have

$$
\Delta E_{2}=\left\langle\psi_{0} \chi_{1 M}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{0} \chi_{1 M}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{4} B \hbar^{2}\left|\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}=0)\right|^{2} .
$$

As

$$
\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}} \frac{2}{a^{3 / 2}} e^{-r / a}, \quad\left|\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}=0)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{\pi a^{3}} .
$$

Hence the hyperfine splitting is

$$
\Delta E=\Delta E_{2}-\Delta E_{1}=\frac{1}{\pi a^{3}} B \hbar^{2} .
$$

The above calculation shows that the singlet state $\left({ }^{1} S_{0}\right)$ has lower energy. The reason is as follows. The intensity of the field produced by a magnetic dipole decreases rapidly with increasing distance. So for the magnetic dipole interaction between the electron and proton we have to consider the case when they are very close. When $\mu_{e}$ is parallel to $\mu_{p}$, the energy of the magnetic interaction is lower (as $E=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}$ ) than when they are antiparallel. Since when $\mu_{e}$ and $\mu_{p}$ are parallel, $\mathbf{S}_{e}$ and $\mathbf{S}_{p}$ are antiparallel. The gap in singlet state has the lower energy.
6057.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

6057.b.Problem Statement:
The vector potential of the radiation field emitted in a transition between the states in part (a) has the general form that, as $r \rightarrow \infty$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{A}=& {\left[-i \frac{\omega}{c}\langle\mathbf{x}\rangle+i \frac{\omega}{c} \hat{\mathbf{n}} \times \frac{e}{2 m_{e} c}\langle\mathbf{L}\rangle+i \frac{\omega e}{2 m_{e} c^{2}} \hat{\mathbf{n}} \times\left\langle\sigma_{e}\right\rangle+\ldots\right] } \\
& \times \frac{e^{i \frac{\omega}{c} r-i \omega t}}{r},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ is a unit vector along the direction of propagation of the radiation and $\langle\cdot\rangle$ denotes the matrix element for this transition. Show explicitly for each of the three terms whether or not $\langle\cdot\rangle$ is nonzero. What is the character of the radiation emitted in the transition?
6057.b.Solution:
Let the spatial wave function of $1 s$ state be $\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r})$, the spin singlet state be $\chi_{00}$, and the spin triplet state be $\chi_{1 M}(M=0, \pm 1)$.

The perturbation method for degenerate states is to be used, the perturbation Hamiltonian being 

$$
\begin{aligned}
H^{\prime}=& \frac{2 \pi}{3} \cdot \frac{e^{2} g_{e} g_{p}}{m_{e} m_{p} c^{2}} \mathbf{S}_{e} \cdot \mathbf{S}_{p} \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{B}{2}\left[\left(\mathbf{S}_{e}+\mathbf{S}_{p}\right)^{2}\right.\\
&\left.-\mathbf{S}_{e}^{2}-\mathbf{S}_{p}^{2}\right] \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{B}{2}\left[\mathbf{S}^{2}-\frac{3}{2} \hbar^{2}\right] \delta^{3}(\mathbf{r})
\end{aligned}
$$

where $B=\frac{2 \pi}{3} \frac{e^{2} g_{e} g_{p}}{m_{e} m_{p} c^{2}}$ and $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{S}_{e}+\mathbf{S}_{p}$, with $S_{e}^{2}=S_{p}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \hbar$. If $\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}) \chi_{00}$ and $\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}) \chi_{1 M}$ are chosen to be the basis vectors, then $H^{\prime}$ is a diagonal matrix. For the $1 s^{1} S_{0}$ energy level, $S=0$ and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_{1} &=\left\langle\psi_{0} \chi_{00}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{0} \chi_{00}\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{3}{4} B \hbar^{2}\left|\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}=0)\right|^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the $1 s^{3} S_{1}$ energy level, $S^{2}=1(1+1) \hbar^{2}$ and we have

$$
\Delta E_{2}=\left\langle\psi_{0} \chi_{1 M}\left|H^{\prime}\right| \psi_{0} \chi_{1 M}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{4} B \hbar^{2}\left|\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}=0)\right|^{2} .
$$

As

$$
\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi}} \frac{2}{a^{3 / 2}} e^{-r / a}, \quad\left|\psi_{0}(\mathbf{r}=0)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{\pi a^{3}} .
$$

Hence the hyperfine splitting is

$$
\Delta E=\Delta E_{2}-\Delta E_{1}=\frac{1}{\pi a^{3}} B \hbar^{2} .
$$

The above calculation shows that the singlet state $\left({ }^{1} S_{0}\right)$ has lower energy. The reason is as follows. The intensity of the field produced by a magnetic dipole decreases rapidly with increasing distance. So for the magnetic dipole interaction between the electron and proton we have to consider the case when they are very close. When $\mu_{e}$ is parallel to $\mu_{p}$, the energy of the magnetic interaction is lower (as $E=-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}$ ) than when they are antiparallel. Since when $\mu_{e}$ and $\mu_{p}$ are parallel, $\mathbf{S}_{e}$ and $\mathbf{S}_{p}$ are antiparallel. The gap in singlet state has the lower energy.For the transition from the triplet state to the singlet state, due to the vector potential $\mathbf{A}$, as the terms for $\hat{\mathbf{x}}$ and $\hat{\mathbf{L}}$ do not contain spin operators, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\mathbf{x}\rangle &=\left\langle\psi_{0} \chi_{00}|\hat{\mathbf{x}}| \psi_{0} \chi_{1 M}\right\rangle=\left\langle\psi_{0}|\hat{\mathbf{x}}| \psi_{0}\right\rangle\left\langle\chi_{00} \mid \chi_{1 M}\right\rangle=0 \\
\langle\mathbf{L}\rangle &=\left\langle\psi_{0} \chi_{00}|\hat{\mathbf{L}}| \psi_{0} \chi_{1 M}\right\rangle=0 \\
\left\langle\sigma_{e}\right\rangle &=\left\langle\psi_{0} \chi_{00}\left|\sigma_{e}\right| \psi_{0} \chi_{1 M}\right\rangle=\left\langle\chi_{00}\left|\sigma_{e}\right| \chi_{1 M}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\chi_{00} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)_{p}-\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{p}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)_{e}\right], \\
\chi_{11} &=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{p}, \\
\chi_{10} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)_{p}+\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)_{p}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)_{e}\right] \\
\chi_{1,-1} &=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)_{p}
\end{aligned}
$$

and if we take the $z$-axis parallel to $\mathbf{n}$ the $z$ component of $\left\langle\sigma_{e}\right\rangle$ will contribute nothing to $\mathbf{n} \times\left\langle\sigma_{e}\right\rangle$, thus we have effectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\chi_{00}\left|\sigma_{e}\right| \chi_{11}\right\rangle &=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right) \sigma_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mathbf{e}_{x}-\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}} \mathbf{e}_{y}, \\
\left\langle\chi_{00}\left|\sigma_{e}\right| \chi_{1,-1}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right) \sigma_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mathbf{e}_{x}-\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}} \mathbf{e}_{y} \\
\left\langle\chi_{00}\left|\sigma_{e}\right| \chi_{10}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0
\end{array}\right) \sigma_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1
\end{array}\right) \sigma_{e}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\mathbf{e}_{z}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbf{e}_{x}, \mathbf{e}_{y}, \mathbf{e}_{z}$ are unit vectors along the $x-, y-, z$-axis respectively. Hence $\left\langle\sigma_{e}\right\rangle \neq 0$. Note that the direction of $\mathbf{A}$ is parallel to $\mathbf{n} \times\left\langle\sigma_{e}\right\rangle$. It is similar to the vector potential of magnetic dipole radiation, so the radiation emitted in the transition has the character of magnetic dipole radiation.
6057.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

6060.Problem Statement:
An electron is bound in the ground state by a potential

$$
V=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
-\frac{\beta}{x}, & x>0 \\
\infty, & x<0
\end{array}\right.
$$

which is independent of $y$ and $z$. Find the cross section for absorption of plane-wave light of energy $\omega \hbar$, direction $\mathbf{k}$, polarization $\varepsilon$. Specify the final state of the electron. Take

$$
\frac{\beta^{2} m}{\hbar^{2}} \ll \hbar \omega \ll m c^{2}
$$
6060.Solution:
As initially the electron moves freely in the $y, z$ directions, its initial state is given by

$$
\psi_{i}(\mathbf{r})=\varphi(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left(\frac{i\left(p_{y} y+p_{z} z\right)}{\hbar}\right)
$$

with

$$
\begin{cases}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \varphi}{d x^{2}}-\frac{\beta}{x} \varphi=E \varphi, & x>0, \\ \varphi=0, & x<0 .\end{cases}
$$

The equation for $\varphi$ is the same as the radial equation of a hydrogen atom with $\ell=0$. Hence the energy states are

$$
E_{n}=-\frac{m \beta^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \frac{1}{n^{2}}, \quad n=1,2, \ldots
$$

Thus the ground (initial) state for $x$ motion has energy and wave function

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{1}=-\frac{m \beta^{2}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \\
\varphi_{1}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{2 x}{a^{3 / 2}} e^{-x / a}, \quad \mathbf{x}>0
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
a=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m \beta}
$$

The condition $\hbar \omega \gg \frac{m \beta^{2}}{\hbar^{2}} \approx\left|E_{1}\right|$ means that the photon energy is much higher than the mean binding energy of the electron and can therefore liberate it from the potential well. However, as $\hbar \omega \ll m c^{2}$, this energy is much lower than the electron rest mass and cannot produce electron pairs. So the electron initial state is

$$
\psi_{i}(\mathbf{r}) \equiv\langle\mathbf{r} \mid i\rangle=C \varphi_{1}(x) \exp \left[i\left(k_{y}^{(e)} y+k_{z}^{(e)} z\right)\right]
$$

where $k_{y}^{(e)}=p_{y} / \hbar, k_{z}^{(e)}=p_{z} / \hbar$ are the wave numbers of the electron in the $y, z$ directions respectively, $C=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{L}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{L}$ if the initial-state wave function is normalized to one electron in a 2-dimensional box of sides $L$ in the $y-z$ plane. The final state of the electron is that of a free electron moving in direction $\mathbf{k}_{f}^{(e)}$ (direction of observation):

$$
\psi_{f}(\mathbf{r}) \equiv\langle\mathbf{r} \mid f\rangle=\left(\frac{1}{L}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left(i \mathbf{k}_{f}^{(e)} \cdot \mathbf{r}\right)
$$

where $L^{3}$ is the 3 -dimensional box used for normalization. The perturbation Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H^{\prime} &=H-H_{0}=\left\{\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\hat{\mathbf{p}}+\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{A}\right)^{2}+V\right\}-\left\{\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{\mathbf{p}}^{2}+V\right\} \\
& \simeq \frac{e}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{p}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A$ is the vector potential of the photon field and the charge of the electron is $-e$. In the above we have chosen the gauge $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{A}=0$ and omitted terms of orders higher than $A^{2}$. Let the corresponding initial electric field be

$$
\mathbf{E}=E \varepsilon \sin \left(\omega t-\mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}+\delta_{0}\right),
$$

where $\mathbf{k}_{i}$ is the wave vector of the incident photon and $\varepsilon=\left\{\varepsilon_{x}, \varepsilon_{y}, \varepsilon_{z},\right\}$ is a unit vector in the direction of $\mathbf{E}$. The vector potential can be taken to be

$$
\mathbf{A}=\frac{c E}{\omega} \varepsilon \cos \left(\omega t-\mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}+\delta_{0}\right)
$$

as $\mathbf{E}=-\frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t}$, and the perturbation Hamiltonian is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
H^{\prime} \simeq \frac{e}{m c} \mathbf{A} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{p}}=& \frac{-i \hbar e}{2 m \omega}\left\{\exp \left[i\left(\omega t-\mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}+\delta_{0}\right)\right]\right.\\
&\left.+\exp \left[-i\left(\omega t-\mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}+\delta_{0}\right)\right]\right\} E \varepsilon \nabla
\end{aligned}
$$

In photon absorption, $E_{f}>E_{i}$ and we need to consider only the second term (the first term is for photo-emission); so the perturbation Hamiltonian is

$$
H^{\prime}=\frac{-i \hbar e}{2 m \omega} \exp \left[-i\left(\omega t-\mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}+\delta_{0}\right)\right] E \varepsilon \nabla .
$$

For a plane electromagnetic wave,

$$
\mathbf{H}=\frac{1}{k} \mathbf{k} \times \mathbf{E},
$$

and so the Poynting vector is

$$
\mathbf{S}=\frac{c}{4 \pi}(\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{H})=\frac{c}{4 \pi k} E^{2} \mathbf{k}
$$

Averaging over time we have

$$
\bar{S}=\frac{c E^{2}}{8 \pi} .
$$

Hence the number of incident photons crossing unit area per unit time is

$$
n=\frac{\bar{S}}{\hbar \omega}=\frac{c E^{2}}{8 \pi \hbar \omega} .
$$

The differential absorption cross section for photoelectric effect is given by

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega_{f}}=\frac{\omega_{i \rightarrow f}}{n},
$$

where $\omega_{i \rightarrow f}$ is the number of electrons in solid angle $d \Omega_{f}$ which transit from the initial state to final states $f$ near energy $E_{f}$ in unit time. First order perturbation theory gives the transition probability per unit time as

$$
\omega_{i \rightarrow f} d \Omega_{f}=\frac{2 \pi}{\hbar} \rho\left(E_{f}\right)\left|W_{f i}\right|^{2} d \Omega_{f}
$$

where $\rho\left(E_{f}\right)$ is the density of the final states per unit energy range.

For nonrelativistic electrons,

$$
\rho=\frac{m k_{f}^{(e)} L^{3}}{8 \pi^{3} \hbar^{2}},
$$

where $k_{f}^{(e)}$ is the wave number of the electrons in the final states of energies near $E_{f}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
W_{f i}=\left\langle f\left|H^{\prime}\right| i\right\rangle=&\left\langle f\left|\frac{-i \hbar e}{2 m \omega} \exp \left[-i\left(-\mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}+\delta_{0}\right)\right] E \varepsilon \cdot \nabla\right| i\right\rangle \\
=& \frac{-i \hbar e}{2 m \omega} e^{-i \delta_{0}} \int_{0}^{+\infty} d x \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \int_{0} d y d z \cdot L^{-3 / 2} \\
& \times \exp \left[-i \mathbf{k}_{f}^{(e)} \cdot \mathbf{r}+i \mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}\right](E \varepsilon \cdot \nabla) C \varphi_{1}(x) \\
& \times \exp \left[i\left(k_{y}^{(e)} y+k_{z}^{(e)} z\right)\right] \\
=& \frac{-i \hbar e C E e^{-i \delta_{0}}}{2 m \omega} L^{-3 / 2} \int d x d y d z\left\{\varepsilon_{x}\left(\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{a}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+i \varepsilon_{y} k_{y}^{(e)}+i \varepsilon_{z} k_{z}^{(e)}\right\} \varphi_{1}(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left[-i \mathbf{k}_{f}^{(e)} \cdot \mathbf{r}+i \mathbf{k}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}\right] \\
& \times \exp \left[i\left(k_{y}^{(e)} y+k_{z}^{(e)} z\right)\right] \\
=& \frac{4 \pi^{2} \sqrt{a} \hbar e E e^{-i \delta_{0}}}{m \omega L^{5 / 2}\left[1+i a\left(k_{x}^{(f)}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)\right]^{2}}\left\{\varepsilon_{x}\left(k_{x}^{(f)}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)\right.\\
&\left.-\varepsilon_{y} k_{y}^{(e)}-\varepsilon_{z} k_{z}^{(e)}\right\} \delta\left(-k_{y}^{(f)}+k_{y}^{(i)}\right.\\
&\left.+k_{y}^{(e)}\right) \delta\left(-k_{z}^{(f)}+k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the differential absorption cross section is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega_{f}}=& \frac{8 \pi a k_{f} e^{2}}{m \omega c\left(1+a^{2} \Delta^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[\varepsilon_{x} \Delta-\varepsilon_{y} k_{y}^{(e)}-\varepsilon_{z} k_{z}^{(e)}\right]^{2} \\
& \times \delta\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}-k_{y}^{(f)}\right) \delta\left(k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}-k_{z}^{(f)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In above calculation, we have made the change of symbols

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{k}_{f}^{(e)} \rightarrow \mathbf{k}^{f} \equiv\left\{k_{x}^{(f)}, k_{y}^{(f)}, k_{z}^{(f)}\right\}, \mathbf{k}_{i} \rightarrow \mathbf{k}^{(i)} \equiv\left\{k_{x}^{(i)}, k_{y}^{(i)}, k_{z}^{(i)}\right\} \\
k_{x}^{(f)}-k_{x}^{(i)}=\Delta
\end{gathered}
$$

and used

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\delta\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}-k_{y}^{(f)}\right)\right]^{2}=} & \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-L / 2}^{L / 2} \delta\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}-k_{y}^{(f)}\right) \\
& \times \exp \left[i y\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}-k_{y}^{(f)}\right)\right] d y \\
=& \frac{L}{2 \pi} \delta\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}-k_{y}^{(f)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\left[\delta\left(k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}-k_{z}^{(f)}\right)\right]^{2}=\frac{L}{2 \pi} \delta\left(k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}-k_{z}^{(f)}\right) .
$$

Note that the two $\delta$-functions express momentum conservation in the directions of $y$ and $z$. Also, energy conservation requires

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{f}^{2}}{2 m} &=E_{1}+\frac{\hbar^{2}\left(k_{y}^{(e)^{2}}+k_{z}^{(e)^{2}}\right)}{2 m}+\hbar \omega \\
&=-\left|E_{1}\right|+\frac{\hbar^{2}\left(k_{y}^{(e)^{2}}+k_{z}^{(e)^{2}}\right)}{2 m}+\hbar \omega .
\end{aligned}
$$

The $\delta$ functions mean that the $y$ and $z$ components of $\mathbf{k}_{f}$ are fixed, and so is the $x$ component of $\mathbf{k}_{f}$. The physical reason why the $\delta$-functions appear in the expression for the differential absorption cross section is that when an electron which has definite momenta in the $y$ and $z$ directions collide with an incident photon which also has a definite momentum, energy and momentum conservation laws require the scattering direction of the electron in the final state to be fixed.

To find the total absorption cross section, we note that

$$
\delta(\alpha x)=\frac{1}{\alpha} \delta(x)
$$

and so

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\delta\left(k_{y}^{(f)}-k_{y}^{(i)}-k_{y}^{(e)}\right)=\frac{1}{k_{f}} \delta\left(\sin \theta_{f} \sin \varphi_{f}-\frac{k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}}{k_{f}}\right), \\
\delta\left(k_{z}^{(f)}-k_{z}^{(i)}-k_{z}^{(e)}\right)=\frac{1}{k_{f}} \delta\left(\cos \theta_{f}-\frac{k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}}{k_{f}}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Then the total absorption cross section is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{a}=& \int \frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega_{f}} d \Omega_{f} \\
=& \frac{8 \pi a e^{2} k_{f}}{m \omega c} \int \frac{1}{k_{f}^{2}}\left[\frac{\varepsilon_{z}\left(k_{f} \sin \theta_{f} \cos \varphi_{f}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)-\varepsilon_{y} k_{y}^{(e)}-\varepsilon_{z} k_{z}^{(e)}}{1+a^{2}\left(k_{f} \sin \theta_{f} \cos \varphi_{f}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)^{2}}\right]^{2} \\
& \times \delta\left(\sin \theta_{f} \sin \varphi_{f}-\frac{k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}}{k_{f}}\right) \delta\left(\cos \theta_{f}-\frac{k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}}{k_{f}}\right) \\
& \times \frac{\sin \theta_{f}}{} d \theta_{f} d \varphi_{f} \\
=& \frac{8 \pi a e^{2}}{m \omega c k_{f}} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left[\frac{\varepsilon_{x}\left(k_{f} \sin \theta_{f} \cos \varphi_{f}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)-\varepsilon_{y} k_{y}^{(e)}-\varepsilon_{z} k_{z}^{(e)}}{1+a^{2}\left(k_{f} \sin \theta_{f} \cos \varphi_{f}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)^{2}}\right]^{2} \\
& \times \frac{\delta\left(\sin \varphi_{f}-\frac{k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}}{k_{f} \sin \theta_{f}}\right) \frac{d\left(\sin \varphi_{f}\right)}{\cos \varphi_{f}}}{\sin \theta_{f}} \\
=& \frac{8 \pi a e^{2}}{m \omega c k_{f}} \cdot\left[\frac{\varepsilon_{x}\left(k_{f} \sin \theta_{f} \cos \varphi_{f}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)-\varepsilon_{y} k_{y}^{(e)}-\varepsilon_{z} k_{z}^{(e)}}{1+a^{2}\left(k_{f} \sin \theta_{f} \cos \varphi_{f}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right)^{2}}\right]^{2} \\
& \times \frac{1}{\sin \theta_{f} \cdot \cos \varphi_{f}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos \theta_{f} &=\frac{k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}}{k_{f}}, \quad \sin \theta_{f}=\frac{\sqrt{k_{f}^{2}-\left(k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}\right)^{2}}}{k_{f}}, \\
\cos \varphi_{f} &=\frac{\sqrt{k_{f}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta_{f}-\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}\right)^{2}}}{k_{f} \sin \theta_{f}}, \\
\sin \varphi_{f} &=\frac{k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}}{k_{f} \sin \theta_{f}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{a}=& \frac{8 \pi a e^{2}}{m \omega c} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k_{f}^{2}-\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}\right)^{2}-\left(k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}\right)^{2}}} \\
& \times \varepsilon_{x}\left[\sqrt{k_{f}^{2}-\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}\right)^{2}-\left(k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}\right)^{2}}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\times\left\{\frac{\varepsilon_{y} k_{y}^{(e)}+\varepsilon_{z} k_{z}^{(e)}}{1+a^{2}\left[\sqrt{k_{f}^{2}-\left(k_{y}^{(i)}+k_{y}^{(e)}\right)^{2}-\left(k_{z}^{(i)}+k_{z}^{(e)}\right)^{2}}-k_{x}^{(i)}\right]^{2}}\right\}^{2} .
$$

6061.c.Problem Statement:
A system of two distinguishable spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles is described by the Hamiltonian

$$
H=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m_{1}} \nabla_{1}^{2}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m_{2}} \nabla_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \omega^{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)^{2}+g \sigma_{1} \cdot \sigma_{2}
$$

with $g \ll \hbar \omega$.

Calculate $C_{n}(\infty)$ for the case

$$
f(t)= \begin{cases}0, & t<0 \quad \text { and } t>\tau \\ 1, & 0<t<\tau\end{cases}
$$

with $\frac{g \tau}{\hbar} \ll 1$ and $V_{2}$ very small. Work through first order in $V_{2}$ and specify clearly the quantum numbers for the states.
6061.c.Solution:
Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r} &=\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}, \\
\mathbf{R} &=\frac{m_{1} \mathbf{r}_{1}+m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \\
\mathbf{S} &=\mathbf{s}_{1}+\mathbf{s}_{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\sigma_{1}+\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the Hamiltonian of the system can be reduced to

$$
H=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \nabla_{R}^{2}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \nabla_{r}^{2}+\frac{\mu}{2} \omega^{2} r^{2}+2 g\left[S(S+1)-\frac{3}{2}\right]
$$

where $M=m_{1}+m_{2}, \mu=\frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}, S$ is the total spin.

Note that in the expression for $H$, the first term is due to the motion of the system as a whole, the second and third terms together are the Hamiltonian of a spinless isotropic harmonic oscillator, and the last term is due to the spins of the particles. Hence the energy of the system is

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{n S}=\frac{P^{2}}{2 M}+\left(n+\frac{3}{2}\right) \hbar \omega+2 g\left[S(S+1)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \\
n=0,1,2, \ldots
\end{gathered}
$$

For energy levels of the internal motion, we shall omit the first term on the right-hand side of the above. For the ground state of the internal motion, $n=0, S=0$ and

$$
E_{00}=\frac{3}{2} \hbar \omega-3 g .
$$

Write the wave function as $\psi_{0}=|0\rangle \alpha_{00}$. For the first excited state, we similarly have

$$
E_{01}=\frac{3}{2} \hbar \omega+g, \quad \psi_{1}=|0\rangle \alpha_{10}, \alpha_{1, \pm 1} .
$$

Note that $|0\rangle$ is the wave function of the harmonic oscillator ground state and $\alpha_{S M}$ is the coupled spin wave function.

Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
H_{0} &=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \nabla_{r}^{2}+\frac{\mu}{2} \omega^{2} r^{2}+2 g\left[S(S+1)-\frac{3}{2}\right], \\
H_{0}|n\rangle &=E_{n}|n\rangle \\
{\left[H_{0}+V(t)\right] \psi(t) } &=i \hbar \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Expanding $\psi(t)$

$$
|\psi(t)\rangle=\sum_{n} C_{n}(t) \exp \left(-i E_{n} t / \hbar\right)|n\rangle
$$

and substituting it in the last equation we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[H_{0}+V(t)\right] \sum_{n} C_{n} e^{-i \frac{E_{n} t}{n}}|n\rangle=} & i \hbar \sum_{n} \dot{C}_{n} e^{-i \frac{E_{n} t}{n}}|n\rangle \\
&+i \hbar \sum_{n} C_{n}\left(\frac{-i E_{n}}{\hbar}\right) e^{-i \frac{E_{n} t}{n}}|n\rangle .
\end{aligned}
$$

Multiplying both sides by $\langle m| e^{i \frac{E_{m} t}{\hbar}}$ and summing over $m$ we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{m} C_{m} E_{m}+\sum_{m} \sum_{n} C_{n} e^{i \frac{\left(E_{m}-E_{n}\right) t}{\hbar}}\langle m|V(t)| n\rangle \\
=i \hbar \sum_{m} \dot{C}_{m}+i \hbar \sum_{m} C_{m}\left(\frac{-i E_{m}}{\hbar}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

or

$$
i \hbar \dot{C}_{n}(t)=\sum_{m}\langle n|V(t)| m\rangle \exp \left[-i\left(E_{m}-E_{n}\right) t / \hbar\right] C_{m}(t)
$$

which is the required set of coupled equations. As

Denote the initial state by $\left|000 \alpha_{00}\right\rangle$, the final state by $\left|n l m \alpha_{S M}\right\rangle$.

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sigma_{1} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}=\sin \theta \cos \varphi \sigma_{1 x}+\sin \theta \sin \varphi \sigma_{1 y}+\cos \theta \sigma_{1 z} \\
\alpha_{00}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\alpha_{1} \beta_{2}-\beta_{1} \alpha_{2}\right) \\
\alpha_{11}=\alpha_{1} \alpha_{2}, \quad \alpha_{1,-1}=\beta_{1} \beta_{2} \\
\alpha_{10}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\alpha_{1} \beta_{2}+\alpha_{2} \beta_{1}\right) ; \\
\sigma_{1 x} \alpha_{1}=\beta_{1}, \quad \alpha_{1}=i \beta_{1}, \quad \sigma_{1 z} \alpha_{1}=\alpha_{1} ; \quad \sigma_{1 x} \beta_{1}=\alpha_{1}, \\
\sigma_{1 y} \beta_{1}=-i \alpha_{1}, \quad \sigma_{1 z} \beta_{1}=-\beta_{1} ;
\end{gathered}
$$

we have

$$
\sigma_{1} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}} \alpha_{00}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\sin \theta e^{i \varphi} \alpha_{1,-1}-\sin \theta e^{-i \varphi} \alpha_{11}+\sqrt{2} \cos \theta \alpha_{10}\right) .
$$

Therefore, as $Y_{11}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta e^{i \varphi}, Y_{1,-1}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{8 \pi}} \sin \theta e^{-i \varphi}, Y_{10}=$ $\sqrt{\frac{3}{4 \pi}} \cos \theta$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle n l m \alpha_{S M}\left|\sigma_{1} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}\right| \alpha_{00} 000\right\rangle=&\left\langle n l m \alpha_{S M}\right| \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{3}} Y_{11} \alpha_{1,-1} \\
&-\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{3}} Y_{1,-1} \alpha_{11}+\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{3}} Y_{10} \alpha_{10}|000\rangle \\
=& \sqrt{\frac{1}{3}} \delta_{n 0} \delta_{l 1} \delta_{S 1}\left(\delta_{m 0} \delta_{M 0}-\delta_{m 1} \delta_{M,-1}\right.\\
&\left.-\delta_{m 1} \delta_{M 1}\right) \equiv 0
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\ell=0$ for $n=0$. Thus to first order perturbation the first term $V_{1} f(t) \sigma_{1} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}$ in $V(t)$ makes no contribution to the transition. Consider next

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle n l m \alpha_{S M}\left|r \cos \theta \sigma_{1} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}\right| \alpha_{00} 000\right\rangle \\
=&\left\langle n l m \alpha_{S M}\right| r\left(-\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{15}} Y_{21} \alpha_{1,-1}-\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi}{15}} Y_{2,-1} \alpha_{11}\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{16 \pi}{5}} Y_{20} \alpha_{10}+\frac{1}{3} \alpha_{10}\right)|000\rangle \\
=& \lambda_{1} \delta_{l 2} \delta_{S 1}\left[\frac{2}{3 \sqrt{5}} \delta_{m 0} \delta_{M 0}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{15}} \delta_{m 1} \delta_{M,-1}\right.\\
&\left.-\frac{1}{\sqrt{15}} \delta_{m,-1} \delta_{M 1}\right]+\frac{1}{3} \lambda_{1} \delta_{l 0} \delta_{S 1} \delta_{m 0} \delta_{M 0},
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\lambda_{1}=\int_{0}^{\infty} R_{n l} \cdot R_{00} \cdot r^{3} d r=\int_{0}^{\infty} R_{n 2} R_{00} r^{3} d r .
$$

For the three-dimensional harmonic oscillator, $n=l+2 n_{r}=2\left(1+n_{r}\right)$ $=$ even. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{n}(\infty) &=\frac{1}{i \hbar} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{i \omega_{n 0} t}\left\langle n l m \alpha_{S M}|V(t)| 000 \alpha_{00}\right\rangle d t \\
&=\frac{1}{i \hbar} \int_{0}^{\tau} e^{i n \omega t} d t\left\langle n l m \alpha_{S M}\left|\left(V_{1}+V_{2} \frac{z}{L}\right) \sigma_{1} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}\right| 000 \alpha_{00}\right\rangle \\
&=\frac{1}{n \omega \hbar}\left(e^{i n \omega \tau}-1\right)\left\langle n l m \alpha_{S M}\left|\frac{V_{2}}{L} r \cos \theta \sigma_{1} \cdot \hat{x}\right| \alpha_{00} 000\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{2 k-1}(\infty)=& 0 \\
C_{2 k}(\infty)=& \frac{1}{2 k \hbar \omega}\left(e^{i 2 k \omega \tau}-1\right) \frac{V_{2}}{L} \lambda_{1} \\
& \times \delta_{S 1}\left[\frac{2}{3 \sqrt{5}} \delta_{m 0} \delta_{M 0}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{15}} \delta_{m, 1} \delta_{M,-1}\right.\\
&\left.-\frac{1}{\sqrt{15}} \delta_{m,-1} \delta_{M 1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $k=1,2, \ldots, l=2, \lambda_{1}=\int_{0}^{\infty} r^{3} R_{(2 k) 2} R_{00} d r$.

7002.a.Problem Statement:
Consider two identical linear oscillators with spring constant $k$. The interaction potential is given by $H=\varepsilon x_{1} x_{2}$, where $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ are oscillator variables.

Find the exact energy levels.
7002.a.Solution:
The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
H=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x_{2}^{2}+\varepsilon x_{1} x_{2},
$$

where $\omega^{2}=\frac{k}{m}$. Setting

$$
x_{1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right), \quad x_{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(y_{1}-y_{2}\right),
$$

we can write $H$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=&-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y_{1}^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial y_{2}^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}\left(m \omega^{2}+\varepsilon\right) y_{1}^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2}\left(m \omega^{2}-\varepsilon\right) y_{2}^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the system can be regarded as consisting two independent harmonic oscillations of coordinates $y_{1}, y_{2}$. Thus, the exact total energy levels are

$$
E_{n^{\prime} n}=\left(n^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \sqrt{\omega^{2}+\frac{\varepsilon}{m}}+\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \sqrt{\omega^{2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{m}},
$$

where $n^{\prime}, n=0,1,2,3, \ldots$.
7002.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

7003.b.Problem Statement: If $x e^{-\nu x^{2}}$ is a solution find $\nu$ and then give the energy $E_{1}$ and the expectation values for $\langle x\rangle,\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle,\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle,\langle p x\rangle$.
7003.b.Solution:
The Hamiltonian for a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator is

$$
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2} .
$$

The stationary Schrödinger equation is

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}\right) \psi(\mathbf{x})=E \psi(\mathbf{x})
$$

Substitution of $\psi=x e^{-\nu x^{2}}$ in the Schrödinger equation gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}(-2 \nu)\left(3-2 \nu x^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}\right] x e^{-\nu x^{2}}} \\
&\quad=\left[\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{m} \nu+\left(\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}-\frac{2 \hbar^{2} \nu^{2}}{m}\right) x^{2}\right] x e^{-\nu x^{2}} \\
&\quad=E_{1} x e^{-\nu x^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Equating the coefficients gives

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}-\frac{2 \hbar^{2} \nu^{2}}{m}=0 \\
E_{1}=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{m} \nu
\end{array}\right.
$$

whose solution is

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\nu=\frac{m \omega}{2 \hbar} \\
E_{1}=\frac{3}{2} \hbar \omega .
\end{array}\right.
$$

From the symmetry we know $\langle x\rangle=0$. The Virial theorem gives

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \hbar \omega .
$$

Therefore

$$
\left\langle p^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{3}{2} m \hbar \omega, \quad\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{3}{2} \frac{\hbar}{m \omega} .
$$

To find $\langle p x\rangle$ we first normalize the wave function:

$$
A^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2} e^{-2 \nu x^{2}} d x=1
$$

giving

$$
A^{2}=4 \nu \sqrt{\frac{2 \nu}{\pi}}
$$

Then consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle p x\rangle &=-\frac{\hbar}{i} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi \frac{d}{d x}(x \psi) d x \\
&=\frac{\hbar}{i} A^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x e^{-\nu x^{2}} \frac{d}{d x}\left(x^{2} e^{-\nu x^{2}}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{\hbar}{i} A^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} 2\left(x^{2}-\nu x^{4}\right) e^{-2 \nu x^{2}} d x \\
&=-\frac{i \hbar}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$
7003.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

7004.a.Problem Statement:
Consider two particles of masses $m_{1} \neq m_{2}$ interacting via the Hamilto$\operatorname{nian}$

$$
H=\frac{p_{1}^{2}}{2 m_{1}}+\frac{p_{2}^{2}}{2 m_{2}}+\frac{1}{2} m_{1} \omega^{2} x_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{2} \omega^{2} x_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2} .
$$

Find the exact solutions.
7004.a.Solution:
Let

$$
R=\left(m_{1} x_{1}+m_{2} x_{2}\right) /\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right), \quad r=x_{1}-x_{2} .
$$

We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{d x_{1}} &=\frac{\partial R}{\partial x_{1}} \frac{d}{d R}+\frac{\partial r}{\partial x_{1}} \frac{d}{d r} \\
&=\frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \frac{d}{d R}+\frac{d}{d r}
\end{aligned}
$$

and so

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x_{1}^{2}}=\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right)^{2} \frac{d^{2}}{d R^{2}}+2 \frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d r d R}+\frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}}
$$

and similarly

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d x_{2}^{2}}=\left(\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right)^{2} \frac{d^{2}}{d R^{2}}-2 \frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d R d r}+\frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}}
$$

We also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}^{2}=R^{2}+2 \frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} R r+\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}} r^{2}, \\
&x_{2}^{2}=R^{2}-2 \frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} R r+\frac{m_{1}^{2}}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}} r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=&-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)} \frac{d^{2}}{d R^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2} \frac{m_{1}+m_{2}}{m_{1} m_{2}} \frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}} \\
&+\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \omega^{2} R^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} \omega^{2} r^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K r^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let

$$
M=m_{1}+m_{2}, \quad \mu=\frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}} .
$$

The equation of motion becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{\left[\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{2 M} \frac{d^{2}}{d R^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} M \omega^{2} R^{2}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{d^{2}}{d r^{2}}+\frac{\mu}{2}\left(1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}\right) \omega^{2} r^{2}\right] \psi(R, r)} \\
&\quad=E \psi(R, r)
\end{aligned}
$$

It can be reduced to two independent oscillator equations with energy states and wave functions

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=E_{l m}=E_{l} &+E_{m}=\left(l+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega+\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega \sqrt{1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}} \\
\psi_{l m}(R, r)=& \psi_{l}(R) \psi_{m}(r)=N_{l} N_{m} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \alpha_{1}^{2} R^{2}\right] H_{l}\left(\alpha_{1} R\right) \\
& \times \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \alpha_{2}^{2} r^{2}\right] H_{m}\left(\alpha_{2} r\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{l} &=\left(\frac{\alpha_{1}}{\sqrt{\pi} 2^{l} l !}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad \alpha_{1}=\left(\frac{M \omega}{\hbar}\right)^{1 / 2}, \\
N_{m} &=\left(\frac{\alpha_{2}}{\sqrt{\pi} 2^{m} m !}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad \alpha_{2}=\left(\frac{\mu \omega}{\hbar}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(1+\frac{K}{\mu \omega^{2}}\right)^{1 / 4},
\end{aligned}
$$

and $H_{m}$ are Hermite polynomials.

7005.i.Problem Statement:
A potential has the form shown in Fig. 7.1, where $V$ is very large but finite.

If a particle is originally in one of the wells, give a formula for the order of magnitude of the rate at which it tunnels into the other. Do not attempt to calculate numerical factors of order unity.

(ii) Sketch the wave functions for the lowest two states.
(iii) If two identical bosons with a small repulsive force between them are placed in the wells, write down approximate wave functions for the lowest two states for each of the two cases where the effect of the inter-particle force is much less and much greater than the effect of the fact that $V$ is not infinite.

7005.i.Solution:
Denote the ground state by $\psi_{1}$ and the first excited state by $\psi_{2} . \psi_{1}$ is symmetric about the axis of symmetry of the potential well, $\psi_{2}$ is antisymmetric. Assume the particle is initially in the left semi-well and write the initial wave function as

$$
\Psi(x, 0)=\left(\psi_{1}+\psi_{2}\right) / \sqrt{2}
$$

(We can see that this is a good approximation from the diagram given in (ii)) Then

$$
\Psi(x, t)=\left[\psi_{1} e^{-i E_{1} t / \hbar}+\psi_{2} e^{-i E_{2} t / \hbar}\right] / \sqrt{2} .
$$

At time $t_{0}$ for which $e^{-i E_{1} t_{0} / \hbar} / e^{-i E_{2} t_{0} / \hbar}=-1$, we have

$$
\Psi\left(x, t_{0}\right)=C\left(\psi_{1}-\psi_{2}\right) / \sqrt{2}, \quad|C|^{2}=1 .
$$

At this moment the particle is in the other semi-well (i.e., with a large probability). As $-1=e^{i \pi}$, this happens at time

$$
t_{0}=\frac{\pi \hbar}{E_{2}-E_{1}}=\frac{\pi \hbar}{\Delta E} .
$$

For $V$ very large, it can be taken as infinite and

$$
E \approx \frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2} n^{2}}{2 m L^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
\Delta E \approx E_{2}-E_{1}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 m L^{2}}\left(2^{2}-1\right)=\frac{3 \pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{2 m L^{2}} .
$$

Hence the rate of tunneling per unit time is of the order

$$
\beta \sim \frac{1}{t_{0}}=\frac{3 \pi \hbar}{2 m L^{2}} .
$$

7007.Problem Statement:
Two identical bosons, each of mass $m$, move in the one-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential $V=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}$. They also interact with each other via the potential

$$
V_{\text {int }}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\alpha e^{-\beta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}},
$$

where $\beta$ is a positive parameter. Compute the ground state energy of the system to first order in the interaction strength parameter $\alpha$.

(Berkeley)
7007.Solution:
Being bosons the two particles can simultaneously stay in the ground state. Taking $V_{\text {int }}$ as perturbation, the unperturbed wave function of the ground state for the system is

$$
\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\phi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \phi_{0}\left(x_{2}\right)=\frac{\alpha_{0}}{\sqrt{\pi}} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2} \alpha_{0}^{2}\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\right)\right], \quad \alpha_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{\hbar}} .
$$

The perturbation energy to first order in $\alpha$ is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=\iint_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi_{0}^{*}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) V_{\text {int }}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \psi_{0}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) d x_{1} d x_{2} \\
&=\frac{\alpha_{0}^{2} \alpha}{\pi} \iint_{-\infty}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\alpha_{0}^{2}\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\right)-\beta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}\right] d x_{1} d x_{2} \\
&=\frac{\alpha_{0} \alpha}{\left(\alpha_{0}^{2}+2 \beta\right)^{1 / 2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where the integration has been facilitated by the transformation

$$
\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}=y_{1}, \quad \frac{x_{1}-x_{2}}{2}=y_{2} .
$$

The ground state energy of the system is therefore

$$
E=\hbar \omega+\frac{\alpha_{0} \alpha}{\left(\alpha_{0}^{2}+2 \beta\right)^{1 / 2}} \quad \text { with } \quad \alpha_{0}=\left(\frac{m \omega}{\hbar}\right)^{1 / 2} .
$$

7008.Problem Statement: A one-dimensional square well of infinite depth and $1 \AA$ width contains 3 electrons. The potential well is described by $V=0$ for $0 \leq x \leq 1 \AA$ and $V=+\infty$ for $x<0$ and $x>1 \AA$. For a temperature of $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, the average energy of the 3 electrons is $E=12.4 \mathrm{eV}$ in the approximation that one neglects the Coulomb interaction between electrons. In the same approximation and for $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, what is the average energy for 4 electrons in this potential well?
7008.Solution:
For a one-dimensional potential well the energy levels are given by

$$
E_{n}=E_{1} n^{2},
$$

where $E_{1}$ is the ground state energy and $n=1,2, \ldots$. Pauli's exclusion principle and the lowest energy principle require that two of the three electrons are in the energy level $E_{1}$ and the third one is in the energy level $E_{2}$. Thus $12 \cdot 4 \times 3=2 E_{1}+4 E_{1}$, giving $E_{1}=6 \cdot 2 \mathrm{eV}$. For the case of four electrons, two are in $E_{1}$ and the other two in $E_{2}$, and so the average energy is

(Note: the correct value of $E_{1}$ is

$$
E=\frac{1}{4}\left(2 E_{1}+2 E_{2}\right)=\frac{5}{2} E_{1}=15.5 \mathrm{eV} .
$$

7011.Problem Statement: A one-dimensional box of width $L$ contains two spinless particles each of mass $m$. The interaction between the particles is described by a potential energy $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$. Calculate the ground state energy to first order in $a$.
7011.Solution:
Neglecting the $\delta$-potential, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)= \begin{cases}0, & 0 \leq x_{1}, x_{2} \leq L \\
\infty, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases} \\
&H_{0}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x_{1}^{2}}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x_{2}^{2}}+V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the results for an infinitely deep potential well, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\psi_{n l}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\psi_{n}\left(x_{1}\right) \psi_{l}\left(x_{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{2}{L} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi}{L} x_{1}\right) \sin \left(\frac{l \pi}{L} x_{2}\right), \\
&E_{n l}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{2 m L^{2}}\left(n^{2}+l^{2}\right), \quad n, l=1,2, \cdots .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the ground state, $n=l=1$,

$$
E_{11}=\hbar^{2} \pi^{2} / m L^{2} .
$$

Now consider the $\delta$-potential as a perturbation

$$
\hat{H}^{\prime}=a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) .
$$

The correction to the ground state energy due to the perturbation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H}^{\prime} &=\langle 11|\hat{H}| 11\rangle \\
&=\int_{0}^{L} \int_{0}^{L} a \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{1}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{2}\right)\left(\frac{2}{L}\right)^{2} d x_{1} d x_{2} \\
&=a\left(\frac{2}{L}\right)^{2} \int_{0}^{L} \sin ^{4}\left(\frac{\pi}{L} x_{1}\right) d x_{1}=\frac{3 a}{2 L},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the ground state energy is

$$
E_{11}^{\prime}=E_{11}+\bar{H}^{\prime}=\frac{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m L^{2}}+\frac{3 a}{2 L} .
$$

7013.c.Problem Statement:
The first excited state of $\mathrm{Mg}$ has the configuration $(3 s, 3 p)$ for the valence electrons. In the LS-coupling limit, which values of $L$ and $S$ are possible? What is the form of the spatial part of their wave functions using the single-particle functions $\psi_{s}(\mathbf{r})$ and $\phi_{p}(\mathbf{r})$ ? Which will have the lowest energy, and Why?

(Berkeley)
7013.c.Solution:
$\psi(1,2)$ must satisfy the condition of antisymmetry for interchange of the two particles:

$$
\hat{P}_{12} \psi(1,2)=\psi(2,1)=-\psi(1,2) .
$$

In an atom, if there are two electrons having identical quantum numbers then $\psi(1,2)=\psi(2,1)$. The antisymmetry condition above then gives $\psi(1,2)=0$, implying that such a state does not exist.

The electron configuration $(3 s, 3 p)$ correspond to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&l_{1}=0, \quad l_{2}=1 \\
&s_{1}=s_{2}=1 / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{gathered}
L=1, \quad S=0,1 \\
\psi_{S}^{L}(1,2)=\phi_{S}^{L}(1,2) \chi_{S}(1,2)
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\phi_{0}^{1}(1,2) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)+\phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(1+\hat{P}_{12}\right) \phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \\
\phi_{1}^{1}(1,2) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(1-\hat{P}_{12}\right) \phi_{s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \phi_{p}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

The lowest energy state is $\Psi_{1}^{1}(1,2)$, i.e. the state of $S=1$. Because the spatial part of the state $S=1$ is antisymmetric for the interchange $1 \leftrightarrow 2$, the probability that the two electrons get close together is small, and so the Coulomb repulsive energy is small, resulting in a lower total energy.

7014.c.Problem Statement:
Two particles, each of mass $M$, are bound in a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential $V=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}$ and interact with each other through an attractive harmonic force $F_{12}=-K\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$. You may take $K$ to be small.

If the particles are identical and have spin $1 / 2$, what is the total spin of each of the states of (a)?
7014.c.Solution:
The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
\hat{H}=\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\right)+\frac{K}{2}\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Let $\xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right), \eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)$ and write $\hat{H}$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H} &=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \xi^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \eta^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k\left(\xi^{2}+\eta^{2}\right)+K \eta^{2} \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 M}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \xi^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \eta^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k \xi^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(k+2 K) \eta^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The system can be considered as consisting of two independent harmonic oscillators of angular frequencies $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ given by

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k+2 K}{M}} .
$$

The total energy is therefore

$$
E_{n m}=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{1}+\left(m+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega_{2}
$$

and the corresponding eigenstate is

$$
|n m\rangle=\psi_{n m}=\varphi_{n}^{(k)}(\xi) \varphi_{m}^{(k+2 K)}(\eta)
$$

where $n, m=0,1,2, \cdots$, and $\varphi_{n}^{(k)}$ is the $n$th eigenstate of a harmonic oscillator of spring constant $k$.

The energies of the three lowest states of the system are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{00}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right), \\
&E_{10}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right)+\hbar \omega_{1}, \\
&E_{01}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar\left(\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}\right)+\hbar \omega_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the particles are identical and spinless, the wave function must be symmetric with respect to the interchange of the two particles. Thus the states $|00\rangle,|10\rangle$ are allowed, while the state $|01\rangle$ is not allowed.

If the particles are identical with spin $1 / 2$, the total wave function, including both spatial and spin, must be antisymmetric with respect to an interchange of the two particles. As the spin function for total spin $S=0$ is antisymmetric and that for $S=1$ is symmetric, we have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
S=0 & \text { for }|00\rangle, \\
S=0 & \text { for }|10\rangle, \\
S=1 & \text { for }|01\rangle .
\end{array}
$$

7017.a.Problem Statement:
Show that the parity operator commutes with the orbital angular momentum operator. What is the parity quantum number of the spherical harmonic $Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)$ ?

(Berkeley)
7017.a.Solution:
Applying the parity operator $\hat{P}$ and the orbital angular momentum operator

$$
\mathbf{L}=\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p}
$$

to an arbitrary wave function $f(\mathbf{r})$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{P} \mathbf{L} f(\mathbf{r}) &=\hat{P}(\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p}) f(\mathbf{r})=(-\mathbf{r}) \times(-\mathbf{p}) f(-\mathbf{r}) \\
&=\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p} f(-\mathbf{r})=\mathbf{L} \hat{P} f(\mathbf{r})
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\hat{P}$ and $\mathbf{L}$ commute, i.e.,

$$
[\hat{P}, \mathrm{~L}]=0 \text {. }
$$

As

$$
\hat{P} Y_{l m}(\theta, \phi)=Y_{l m}(\pi-\theta, \pi+\phi)=(-1)^{l} Y_{l m}(\theta, \phi),
$$

the parity quantum number of $Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)$ is $(-1)^{l}$.

7018.a.Problem Statement:
Two particles of mass $m$ are placed in a rectangular box of sides $a>b$ $>c$ in the lowest energy state of the system compatible with the conditions below. The particles interact with each other according to the potential $V=A \delta\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)$. Using first order perturbation theory to calculate the energy of the system under the following conditions:

Particles not identical.
7018.a.Solution:
The unperturbed system can be treated as consisting of two separate single-particle systems and the wave function as a product of two singleparticle wave functions:

$$
\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) \psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) .
$$

The lowest energy state wave function is thus 

$$
\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{8}{a b c} \sin \frac{\pi x_{1}}{a} \sin \frac{\pi x_{2}}{a} \sin \frac{\pi y_{1}}{b} \sin \frac{\pi y_{2}}{b} \sin \frac{\pi z_{1}}{c} \sin \frac{\pi z_{2}}{c}, \\
\quad \text { for } 0<x_{i}<a, \quad 0<y_{i}<b, \quad 0<z_{i}<c, \quad(i=1,2) \\
0, \quad \text { otherwise },
\end{array}\right.
$$

corresponding to an energy

$$
E_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{m}\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right) .
$$

First order perturbation theory gives an energy correction

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E=& \int \psi_{0}^{*}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) A \delta\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right) \psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right) d^{3} r_{1} d^{3} r_{2} \\
=& \int A\left|\psi_{0}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{1}\right)\right|^{2} d^{3} r_{1}=\int_{0}^{c} \int_{0}^{b} \int_{0}^{a} A\left(\frac{8}{a b c}\right)^{2} \\
& \times\left(\sin \frac{\pi x_{1}}{a} \sin \frac{\pi y_{1}}{b} \sin \frac{\pi z_{1}}{c}\right)^{4} d x_{1} d y_{1} d z_{1}=\frac{27 A}{8 a b c}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
E^{\prime}=\frac{\hbar^{2} \pi^{2}}{m}\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{1}{b^{2}}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\right)+\frac{27 A}{8 a b c} .
$$

A porphyrin ring is a molecule which is present in chlorophyll, hemoglobin, and other important compounds. Some aspects of the physics of its molecular properties can be described by representing it as a onedimensional circular path of radius $r=4 \AA$, along which 18 electrons are constrained to move.

What is the lowest electronic excitation energy of the molecule? What is the corresponding wavelength (give a numerical value) at which the molecule can absorb radiation?

(Berkeley)
7019.c.Solution:
Denote the angular coordinate of an electron by $\theta$. The Schrödinger equation of an electron

has solution

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \theta^{2}} \psi(\theta)=E \psi(\theta)
$$

$$
\psi(\theta)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{i k \theta} .
$$

The single-valuedness of $\psi(\theta), \psi(\theta)=\psi(\theta+2 \pi)$, requires $k=0, \pm 1, \pm 2 \cdots$. The energy levels are given by 

$$
E=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} k^{2} .
$$

Let $0,1,2, \ldots$ denote the energy levels $E_{0}, E_{1}, E_{2}, \ldots$ respectively. In accordance with Pauli's exclusion principle, $E_{0}$ can accommodate two electrons of opposite spins, while $E_{k}, k \neq 0$, which is 2-fold degenerate with respect to $\pm|k|$, can accommodate four electrons. Thus the electron configuration of the ground state of the system is

$$
0^{2} 1^{4} 2^{4} 3^{4} 4^{4}
$$

The electron configuration of the first excited state is

$$
0^{2} 1^{4} 2^{4} 3^{4} 4^{3} 5^{1}
$$

The energy difference between $E_{4}$ and $E_{5}$ is

$$
\Delta E=E_{5}-E_{4}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}\left(5^{2}-4^{2}\right)=\frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}
$$

and the corresponding absorption wavelength is

$$
\lambda=\frac{c h}{\Delta E}=\frac{8 \pi^{2}}{9}\left(\frac{m c}{h}\right) r^{2}=\frac{8 \pi^{2}}{9} \times \frac{4^{2}}{0.0242}=5800 \AA
$$

where $\frac{h}{m c}=0.0242 \AA$ is the Compton wavelength of electron.

7021.Problem Statement:
What is the energy difference in $\mathrm{eV}$ between the two lowest rotational levels of the HD molecule? The $\mathrm{HD}$ (D is a deuteron) distance is $0.75 \AA$.

(Berkeley)
7021.Solution:
The rotational energy levels are given by

$$
E_{J}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} J(J+1) .
$$

Thus for the two lowest levels,

$$
\Delta E_{10}=\left.\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} J(J+1)\right|_{J=1}-\left.\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 I} J(J+1)\right|_{J=0}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{I} .
$$

As the mass $m_{D}$ of the deuteron is approximately twice that of the hydrogen nucleus $m_{p}$, we have

$$
I=\mu r^{2}=\frac{2 m_{p} \cdot m_{p}}{2 m_{p}+m_{p}} r^{2}=\frac{2}{3} m_{p} r^{2}
$$

and hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E_{10}=& \frac{\hbar^{2}}{\frac{2}{3} m_{P} r^{2}}=\frac{3}{2} \frac{(\hbar c)^{2}}{m_{p} c^{2}} \frac{1}{r^{2}}=\frac{1.5}{938 \times 10^{6}} \\
& \times\left(\frac{6.582 \times 10^{-16} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}{0.75 \times 10^{-8}}\right)^{2}=1.11 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{eV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

7026.a.Problem Statement:
Suppose you have solved the Schrödinger equation for the singlyionized helium atom and found a set of eigenfunctions $\psi_{N}(\mathbf{r})$.

(1) Write down a typical two-electron wave function, in terms of the $\phi$ 's and $\sigma$ 's, of definite spin. Do not choose the ground state.

(2) What is the total spin in your example?

(3) Demonstrate that your example is consistent with the Pauli exclusion principle.

(4) Demonstrate that your example is antisymmetric with respect to electron interchange.
7026.a.Solution:
(1) The Schrödinger equation for singly-charged He atom is the same as that for $\mathrm{H}$ atom with $e^{2} \rightarrow Z e^{2}$, where $Z$ is the charge of the He nucleus. Hence the wave functions for hydrogen-like ion are the same as those for $\mathrm{H}$ atom with the Bohr radius replaced:

$$
r_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{\mu e^{2}} \rightarrow a=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{\mu Z e^{2}},
$$

$\mu$ being the reduced mass of the system. For helium $Z=2$.

(2) As $\phi_{N}$ and $\sigma^{\pm}$belong to different spaces we can simply multiply them to form an eigenfunction of a definite spin.

7028.b.Solution:
Since $\mathbf{L}=\mathrm{l}_{1}+\mathrm{l}_{2}, L_{z}=l_{1 z}+l_{2 z}, L=1$ means that $l_{1}, l_{2}=0,1$ or 1,0 , i.e. one electron is in $1 s$ state, the other in $2 p$ state. For convenience, Dirac's bra-ket notation is used to represent the states. The symmetrized and antisymmetrized spatial wave functions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\psi_{1}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle+\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle-\left|2 p, m_{l}=1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{3}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle+\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle-\left|2 p, m_{l}=0\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{5}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle+\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) \\
\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(|1 s\rangle\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle-\left|2 p, m_{l}=-1\right\rangle|1 s\rangle\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the total wave functions to be antisymmetric, we must choose the products of the spin singlet state $\chi_{00}$ and the symmetric space wave functions $\left|\psi_{1}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{3}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{5}\right\rangle$, forming three singlet states $\left|\psi_{i}\right\rangle \chi_{00}(i=1,3,5)$; and the products of the spin triplet states $\chi_{11}$ and the antisymmetric space wave functions $\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle,\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle$, forming nine triplet states $\left|\psi_{i}\right\rangle \chi_{11}(i=2,4,6$, $m=0, \pm 1)$. To denote the twelve states in the coupling representation, we must combine the above antisymmetrized wave functions: The wave functions of the three singlet states are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{ }^{1} P_{1}: \quad\left|m_{J}=1\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{1}\right\rangle \chi_{00} \\
&\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{3}\right\rangle \chi_{00} \\
&\left|m_{J}=-1\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{5}\right\rangle \chi_{00} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The wave functions of the nine triplet states are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&{ }^{3} P_{2}: \quad\left|m_{J}=2\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{11}, \\
&\left|m_{J}=1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{10}+\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{6}}\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}+\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{10}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{6}}\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{11} \\
\left|m_{J}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}+\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{10}\right) \\
\left|m_{J}=-2\right\rangle=\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1} \\
{ }^{3} P_{1}: \quad\left|m_{J}=1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{10}-\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right) \\
\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}-\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right) \\
\left.\left|m_{J}=-1\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}-\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{10}\right) \\
{ }^{3} P_{0}:\left|m_{J}=0\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\left|\psi_{2}\right\rangle \chi_{1,-1}-\left|\psi_{4}\right\rangle \chi_{10}+\left|\psi_{6}\right\rangle \chi_{11}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

As the electron cloud of the $2 p$ orbits is mainly outside the electron cloud of the $1 s$ orbit, the value of $Z$ of the $|1 s\rangle$ wave function is 2 and that of the $|2 p\rangle$ wave function is 1 . The energy levels of a hydrogen-like atom is given by

$$
E=-\frac{m Z^{2} e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2} n^{2}} .
$$

Hence the energy of the $2 p$ states above the ground state is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=-\frac{m c^{2}}{2}\left(\frac{e^{2}}{\hbar c}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{2^{2}}-\frac{2^{2}}{1}\right) \\
&=\frac{0.51 \times 10^{6}}{2} \times\left(\frac{1}{137}\right)^{2} \times \frac{15}{4} \\
&=51 \mathrm{eV}
\end{aligned}
$$

The optimum $Z$ can be obtained from shielding effect calculations using the given wave functions.

7036.a.Problem Statement:
A molecule is made up of three identical atoms at the corners of an equilateral triangle as shown in Fig. 7.12. We consider its ion to be made by adding one electron with some amplitude on each site. Suppose the matrix element of the Hamiltonian for the electron on two adjacent sites $i$, $j$ is $\langle i|H| j\rangle=-a$ for $i \neq j$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-669.jpg?height=207&width=310&top_left_y=490&top_left_x=504)

Fig. $7.12$

Calculate the energy splittings.
7036.a.Solution:
Denote the basis vectors by $|1\rangle,|2\rangle,|3\rangle$ and let $\langle i|H| i\rangle=E_{0}, i=$ $1,2,3$. Then

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0} & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0} & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}
\end{array}\right)
$$

To diagonalize $H$, solve

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0}-\lambda & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0}-\lambda & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

The solution gives energy levels $E_{1,2}=E_{0}+a$ (two-fold degenerate) and $E_{3}=E_{0}-2 a$.

7036.b.Problem Statement:
A molecule is made up of three identical atoms at the corners of an equilateral triangle as shown in Fig. 7.12. We consider its ion to be made by adding one electron with some amplitude on each site. Suppose the matrix element of the Hamiltonian for the electron on two adjacent sites $i$, $j$ is $\langle i|H| j\rangle=-a$ for $i \neq j$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-669.jpg?height=207&width=310&top_left_y=490&top_left_x=504)

Fig. $7.12$

Suppose an electric field in the $z$ direction is applied, so that the potential energy for the electron on top is lowered by $b$ with $|b| \ll|a|$. Now calculate the levels.
7036.b.Solution:
Denote the basis vectors by $|1\rangle,|2\rangle,|3\rangle$ and let $\langle i|H| i\rangle=E_{0}, i=$ $1,2,3$. Then

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0} & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0} & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}
\end{array}\right)
$$

To diagonalize $H$, solve

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0}-\lambda & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0}-\lambda & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

The solution gives energy levels $E_{1,2}=E_{0}+a$ (two-fold degenerate) and $E_{3}=E_{0}-2 a$.The $H$ matrix is now

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0}-b & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0} & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Its diagonalization gives energy levels

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{1}=E_{0}+a \\
&E_{2}=E_{0}-\frac{a+b+\sqrt{(a-b)^{2}+8 a^{2}}}{2} \\
&E_{3}=E_{0}-\frac{a+b-\sqrt{(a-b)^{2}+8 a^{2}}}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

$E_{2}$ has the lowest energy and thus corresponds to the ground state, with wave function

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{0}=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)^{2}+2 a^{2}}}\left[\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)|1\rangle\right.\\
&+a|2\rangle+a|3\rangle] .
\end{aligned}
$$

7036.c.Problem Statement:
A molecule is made up of three identical atoms at the corners of an equilateral triangle as shown in Fig. 7.12. We consider its ion to be made by adding one electron with some amplitude on each site. Suppose the matrix element of the Hamiltonian for the electron on two adjacent sites $i$, $j$ is $\langle i|H| j\rangle=-a$ for $i \neq j$.

Fig. $7.12$

Suppose the electron is in the ground state. Suddenly the field is rotated by $120^{\circ}$ and points toward site 2 . Calculate the probability for the electron to remain in the ground state.
7036.c.Solution:
Denote the basis vectors by $|1\rangle,|2\rangle,|3\rangle$ and let $\langle i|H| i\rangle=E_{0}, i=$ $1,2,3$. Then

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0} & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0} & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}
\end{array}\right)
$$

To diagonalize $H$, solve

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0}-\lambda & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0}-\lambda & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

The solution gives energy levels $E_{1,2}=E_{0}+a$ (two-fold degenerate) and $E_{3}=E_{0}-2 a$.The $H$ matrix is now

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
E_{0}-b & -a & -a \\
-a & E_{0} & -a \\
-a & -a & E_{0}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Its diagonalization gives energy levels

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{1}=E_{0}+a \\
&E_{2}=E_{0}-\frac{a+b+\sqrt{(a-b)^{2}+8 a^{2}}}{2} \\
&E_{3}=E_{0}-\frac{a+b-\sqrt{(a-b)^{2}+8 a^{2}}}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

$E_{2}$ has the lowest energy and thus corresponds to the ground state, with wave function

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{0}=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)^{2}+2 a^{2}}}\left[\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)|1\rangle\right.\\
&+a|2\rangle+a|3\rangle] .
\end{aligned}
$$After the rotation of the field the system has the same configuration as before but the sites are renamed:

$$
1 \rightarrow 2,2 \rightarrow 3,3 \rightarrow 1 .
$$

Hence the new ground state is

$$
\psi_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)^{2}+2 a^{2}}}\left[a|1\rangle+\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)|2\rangle+a|3\rangle\right] .
$$

Hence the probability for the electron to remain in the ground state is

$$
\left|\left\langle\psi_{0}^{\prime} \mid \psi_{0}\right\rangle\right|^{2}=\left[\frac{2 a\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)+a^{2}}{\left(E_{0}-E_{2}-a\right)^{2}+2 a^{2}}\right]^{2} .
$$

8001.b.Problem Statement: If $f(x)=x e^{-x / \lambda}$ over the interval $0<x<\infty$, find the mean and most probable values of $x . f(x)$ is the probability density of $x$.
8001.b.Solution:
As $|x|<1$

$$
y-x y=1+x+x^{2}+x^{3}+\cdots=\frac{1}{(1-x)}
$$

or

$$
y=\frac{1}{(1-x)^{2}} .
$$

The mean value of $x$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{x} &=\int_{0}^{\infty} x f(x) d x / \int_{0}^{\infty} f(x) d x \\
&=\int_{0}^{\infty} x \cdot x e^{-x / \lambda} d x / \int_{0}^{\infty} x e^{-x / \lambda} d x \\
&=\lambda \frac{\Gamma(3)}{\Gamma(2)}=2 \lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

The probability density is an extremum when

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=e^{-x / \lambda}-\frac{1}{\lambda} x e^{-x / \lambda}=0,
$$

i.e. at $x=\lambda$ or $x \rightarrow \infty$. Note that $\lambda>0$ if $f(x)$ is to be finite in $0<x<\infty$. As

$$
f^{\prime \prime}(\lambda)=-\frac{1}{\lambda} e^{-1}<0, f(\lambda)=\lambda e^{-1}>\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x)=0
$$

the probability density is maximum at $x=\lambda$. Hence the most probable value of $x$ is $\lambda$.

\int_{c_{1}} \frac{d z}{4+z^{4}}=\int_{-\infty}^{0} \frac{d x}{4+x^{4}}+\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x}{4+x^{4}}=2 \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x}{4+x^{4}}
$$

we have

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x}{4+x^{4}}=\frac{\pi}{8} .
$$Let the eigenvalue be $E$ and the eigenvector be

$$
X=\left(\begin{array}{l}
x_{1} \\
x_{2} \\
x_{3}
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Then

$$
\left(\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 2 & 4 \\
2 & 3 & 0 \\
5 & 0 & 3
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
x_{1} \\
x_{2} \\
x_{3}
\end{array}\right)=E\left(\begin{array}{l}
x_{1} \\
x_{2} \\
x_{3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

For non-vanishing $X$, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
E-1 & -2 & -4 \\
-2 & E-3 & 0 \\
-5 & 0 & E-3
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

The solution is

$$
E_{1}=3, E_{2}=-3, E_{3}=7 .
$$

Substitution in the matrix equation gives the eigenvectors, which, after normalization, are

$$
X_{1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
0 \\
2 \\
-1
\end{array}\right)
$$

for $E=E_{1}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
&X_{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{65}}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-6 \\
2 \\
5
\end{array}\right) \\
&X_{3}=\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{5}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
4 \\
2 \\
5
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for $E=E_{2}, E_{3}$. Note that these eigenvectors are not orthogonal. Generally, only for a Hermition matrix are the eigenvectors corresponding to different eigenvalues orthogonal.

8004.e.Problem Statement:
Some short questions to warm you up.

What is the sign of the phase shift when a particle scatters from a weak short range attractive potential? Justify your answer.

(Berkeley)
8004.e.Solution:
If $L_{z}$ does not vary with time, $\left[H, L_{z}\right]=0$. What this means is that in a spherical coordinate system $H$ does not contain $\varphi$ explicity, i.e., $H$ is invariant in respect of rotation about the $z$-axis.
(However, $H$ may still contain $\frac{\partial}{\partial \varphi}$ explicitly).

The optical theorem states that the total cross section for elastic scattering $\sigma_{t}$ is given by

$$
\sigma_{t}=\frac{4 \pi}{k} \operatorname{Im} f(0)
$$

where $k$ is the wave number of the incident particle and $f(0)$ is the amplitude of the scattered wave in the forward direction.

In first Born approximation when $V(r)$ is real, which is usually the case, $f(\theta)$ is also real and gives a nonzero total cross section, the imaginary part of $f(\theta)$ appearing only in Born approximation of higher orders. Hence the optical theorem does not apply to Born approximation in the first order.

From the definition of electric quadrupole and the form of spherical harmonic functions, we know that particles of spin $s<1$ cannot have electric quadripole. This includes proton which has a spin of $\frac{1}{2}$.

When $V(r)$ falls off more rapidly than $\frac{1}{r}$, i.e. when the potential is short-ranged, the phase shift $\delta_{l}$ of the $l$ th partial wave is given by the asymptotic form

$$
\delta_{l} \sim-k \int_{0}^{\infty} V(r) j_{l}^{2}(k r) r^{2} d r
$$

where $j_{l}$ is the spherical Bessel function. Hence for attractive forces, $V(r)<$ 0 and so $\delta_{l}>0$.

8007.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves with zero angular momentum in a spherically symmetric attractive potential $V(r)$.

Write down the differential equation of radial motion, defining your radial wave function carefully and specifying the boundary conditions on it for bound states. What is the WKB eigenvalue condition for $s$-states in such a potential? (Be careful to incorporate in your one-dimensional WKB analysis the constraints of radial motion $(0<r<\infty)$.

(Berkeley)
8007.a.Solution:
The wave function of the particle can be written as the product of a radial part and an angular part, $\psi(\mathbf{r})=R(r) Y_{l m}(\theta, \varphi)$. Here $R(r)$ satisfies the equation 

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d}{d r}\right)+V(r)\right] R(r)=E R(r)
$$

in which $l=0$ for zero angular momentum has been incorporated. The boundary conditions for a bound state are $R(r)$ finite for $r \rightarrow 0, R(r) \rightarrow 0$ for $r \rightarrow \infty$.

Let $\chi(r)=R(r) / r$, the above becomes

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2} \chi}{d r^{2}}+V(r) \chi=E \chi, \quad(0<r<\infty)
$$

subject to the condition

$$
\chi(r) \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } \quad r \rightarrow 0 .
$$

Thus the problem becomes that of the one-dimensional motion of a particle in a potential $V(r)$ defined for $r>0$ only. The WKB eigenvalue condition for $s$-state is

$$
\oint \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d r=\left(n+\frac{3}{4}\right) h, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

8010.Problem Statement:
Singlet positronium decays by emitting two photons which are polarized at right angles with respect to each other. An experiment is performed with photon detectors behind polarization analyzers, as shown in Fig. 8.3. Each analyzer has a preferred axis such that light polarized in that direction is transmitted perfectly, while light polarized in the perpendicular direction is absorbed completely. The analyzer axes are at right angles with respect to each other. When many events are observed, what is the ratio of the number of events in which both detectors record a photon to the number in which only one detector records a photon?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-691.jpg?height=221&width=699&top_left_y=1184&top_left_x=317)

Fig. $8.3$
8010.Solution:
Suppose the positronium is initially at rest. Then the two photons will move in opposite directions to conserve momentum, and will reach the respective analyzers at the same time. Assume further that the detector solid angle is very smaller. Then the directions of those photons that reach the analyzers must be almost perpendicular to the latter. Hence the directions of polarization of these photons are parallel to the analyzers. Denote by $\theta$ the angle between one photon's direction of polarizationn and the direction of transmission of the analyzer reached by it. The probability that it can pass through the analyzer is $\cos ^{2} \theta$. Consider the second photon produced in the same decay. As it is polarized at right angles with respect to the first one, the angle between its direction of polarization and the direction of transmission of the second analyzer, which is oriented at right angles to that of the first analyzer, is also $\theta$. Hence the probability that, of the two detectors, only one records the passage of a photon is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{1} & \propto \Omega\left[\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right) d \theta+\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right) \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta\right] \\
&=\frac{\Omega}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Omega$ is the solid angle subtended by the detector, and the probability that both detectors record the passage of photons is

$$
P_{2} \propto \Omega\left[\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta\right]=\frac{3 \Omega}{8} .
$$

Hence the ratio of the number of events of both detectors recording to that of only one detector recording in a given time is

$$
\frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}=\frac{3}{8} \div \frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{2} \text {. }
$$

8011.a.Problem Statement:
A point source $Q$ emits coherent light isotropically at two frequencies $\omega$ and $\omega+\Delta \omega$ with equal power I joules/sec at each frequency. Two detectors $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{B}$ each with a (small) sensitive area $s$, capable of responding to individual photons are located at distances $l_{A}$ and $l_{B}$ from $Q$ as shown in Fig. 8.4. In the following take $\Delta \omega / \omega \ll 1$ and assume the experiment is carried out in vacuum.

Calculate the individual photon counting rates (photons/sec) at A and $B$ as functions of time. Consider time scales $\gg 1 / \omega$.

(CUS)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-693.jpg?height=392&width=343&top_left_y=386&top_left_x=487)

Fig. $8.4$
8011.a.Solution:
The wave function of a photon at $\mathrm{A}$ is

$$
\psi_{A}\left(l_{A}, t\right)=C_{1}\left[e^{i \omega\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right)}+e^{i(\omega+\Delta \omega)\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right)}\right],
$$

where $C_{1}$ is real and, hence, the probability of finding a proton at $\mathrm{A}$ in unit time is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{A} &=\psi_{1}^{*} \psi_{1} \\
&=C_{1}^{2}\left\{2+2 \cos \left[\Delta \omega\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right)\right]\right\} \\
&=4 C_{1}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{2}\left(l_{A} / c-t\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

If there is only a single frequency, $P_{A}=C_{1}^{2}$. As each photon has energy $\hbar \omega$, the number of photons arriving at A per second is

$$
\frac{s}{4 \pi l_{A}^{2}} \cdot \frac{I}{\hbar \omega} \text {. }
$$

Hence

$$
C^{2}=\frac{I s}{4 \pi l_{A}^{2} \hbar \omega},
$$

and

$$
P_{A}=\frac{I s}{\pi l_{A}^{2} \hbar \omega} \cos ^{2}\left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{2}\left(l_{A} / c-t\right)\right]
$$

Similarly we have

$$
P_{B}=4 C_{2}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{2}\left(l_{A} / c-t\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
C_{2}^{2}=\frac{I s}{4 \pi l_{B}^{2} \hbar \omega}
$$
