A point source $Q$ emits coherent light isotropically at two frequencies $\omega$ and $\omega+\Delta \omega$ with equal power I joules/sec at each frequency. If now the output pulses from $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{B}$ are put into a coincidence circuit of resolving time $\tau$, what is the time-averaged coincidence counting rate? Assume that $\tau \ll 1 / \Delta \omega$ and recall that a coincidence circuit will produce an output pulse if the two input pulses arrive within a time $\tau$ of each other.

(CUS)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-693.jpg?height=392&width=343&top_left_y=386&top_left_x=487)

Fig. $8.4$
8011.b.Solution:
The wave function of a photon at $\mathrm{A}$ is

$$
\psi_{A}\left(l_{A}, t\right)=C_{1}\left[e^{i \omega\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right)}+e^{i(\omega+\Delta \omega)\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right)}\right],
$$

where $C_{1}$ is real and, hence, the probability of finding a proton at $\mathrm{A}$ in unit time is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{A} &=\psi_{1}^{*} \psi_{1} \\
&=C_{1}^{2}\left\{2+2 \cos \left[\Delta \omega\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right)\right]\right\} \\
&=4 C_{1}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{2}\left(l_{A} / c-t\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

If there is only a single frequency, $P_{A}=C_{1}^{2}$. As each photon has energy $\hbar \omega$, the number of photons arriving at A per second is

$$
\frac{s}{4 \pi l_{A}^{2}} \cdot \frac{I}{\hbar \omega} \text {. }
$$

Hence

$$
C^{2}=\frac{I s}{4 \pi l_{A}^{2} \hbar \omega},
$$

and

$$
P_{A}=\frac{I s}{\pi l_{A}^{2} \hbar \omega} \cos ^{2}\left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{2}\left(l_{A} / c-t\right)\right]
$$

Similarly we have

$$
P_{B}=4 C_{2}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{2}\left(l_{A} / c-t\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
C_{2}^{2}=\frac{I s}{4 \pi l_{B}^{2} \hbar \omega}
$$In a coincidence of resolving time $\tau$, the time-averaged coincidence counting rate

$$
\begin{aligned}
P=& \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T} d t \int_{-\tau}^{\tau} P_{A}(t) P_{B}(t+x) d x \\
=& \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T} d t \int_{-\tau}^{\tau} 4 C^{4}\left[1+\cos \Delta \omega\left(l_{A} / c-t\right)\right] \\
& \times\left[1+\cos \Delta \omega\left(\frac{l_{B}}{c}-t-x\right)\right] d x \\
=& \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T} 4 C^{4} \cdot\left\{1+\cos \left[\left(l_{A} / c-t\right) \Delta \omega\right]\right\} \\
& \times\left\{2 \tau+2 \tau \cos \left[\Delta \omega\left(\frac{l_{B}}{c}-t\right)\right]\right\} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
C^{4}=\frac{I^{2} s^{2}}{16 \pi^{2} l_{B}^{2} l_{A}^{2} \hbar^{2} \omega^{2}}=C_{1}^{2} C_{2}^{2}
$$

as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\tau}^{\tau} \cos \left[\Delta \omega\left(l_{B} / c-t-x\right)\right] d x &=\frac{1}{\Delta \omega} 2 \sin (\tau \Delta \omega) \cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{B}}{c}-t\right) \Delta \omega\right] \\
& \approx 2 \tau \cos \left[\Delta \omega\left(l_{B} / c-t\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
P=& 8 \tau C^{4} \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T}\left\{1+\cos \left[\left(l_{A} / c-t\right) \Delta \omega\right]\right\} \\
& \times\left\{1+\cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{B}}{c}-t\right) \Delta \omega\right]\right\} d t \\
=& 8 \tau C^{4} \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T}\left\{1+\cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{B}}{c}-t\right) \Delta \omega\right]\right.\\
&\left.+\cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right) \Delta \omega\right]+\cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{A}}{c}-t\right) \Delta \omega\right] \cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{B}}{c}-t\right) \Delta \omega\right]\right\} d t \\
=& 8 \tau C^{4} \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T}\left\{1+\frac{1}{2} \cos \left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{c}\left(l_{A}-l_{B}\right)\right]\right.\\
&+\cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{A}+l_{B}}{2 c}-t\right) \Delta \omega\right] \cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{A}-l_{B}}{2 c}\right) \Delta \omega\right] \\
=& \frac{1}{2 \pi^{2} l_{B}^{2} l_{A}^{2} \hbar^{2} \omega^{2}}\left\{1+\frac{1}{2} \cos \left[\frac{\Delta \omega}{c}\left(l_{A}-l_{B}\right)\right]\right\} \\
&\left.+\frac{1}{2} \cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{A}+l_{B}}{c}-2 t\right) \Delta \omega\right]\right\} d t \\
=& 8 \tau C^{4} \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 T}\left\{2 T+\frac{2 T}{2} \cos \left[\left(\frac{l_{A}-l_{B}}{c}\right) \Delta \omega\right]\right\} \\
=& 8 \tau C^{4}\left\{1+\frac{1}{2} \cos \left[\frac{\Delta \omega\left(l_{A}-l_{B}\right)}{c}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

8012.Problem Statement:
A charged oscillating (nearly) classical system is losing energy by radiation. At energy $E$ it is radiating (and oscillating) at frequency $\nu(E)=$ $\alpha\left(E / E_{0}\right)^{-\beta}$, where $\alpha, \beta$ and $E_{0}$ are positive constants. Compute the quantum energy levels (of the system) $E_{n}$ for large $n$.

(Berkeley)
8012.Solution:
According to the Bohr correspondence principle: the quantum frequency approaches the classical frequency for $n \gg 1$, i.e. $\nu_{q u} \rightarrow \nu_{c l}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. As 

$$
\nu_{q u}=\tau \frac{\partial H}{\partial J},
$$

where $J=n h, \tau=n-m$, and $m, n \gg 1$. We have, with $\tau=1$,

$$
h \nu=\frac{d E}{d n}=h \alpha\left(E / E_{0}\right)^{-\beta},
$$

or

$$
E^{\beta} d E=h \alpha E_{0}^{\beta} d n .
$$

Integrating

$$
\int_{0}^{E_{n}} E^{\beta} d E=h \alpha E_{0}^{\beta} \int_{0}^{n} d n
$$

we have

$$
E_{n}=\left[h \alpha(\beta+1) n E_{0}^{\beta}\right]^{\frac{1}{1+\beta}} .
$$

8013.a.Problem Statement:
A spinless particle of mass $m$ and charge $q$ is constrained to move in a circle of radius $R$ as shown in Fig. 8.5. Find its allowed energy levels (up to a common additive constant) for each of the following cases:

The motion of the particle is nonrelativistic.

$(C U S)$
8013.a.Solution:
Let the momentum of the particle be $p$. The quantization condition

$$
p \cdot 2 \pi R=n h
$$

gives

$$
p=\frac{n \hbar}{R}
$$

and hence

$$
E=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\frac{n \hbar}{R}\right)^{2}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m R^{2}} n^{2}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
&n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots \\
&\text { (a) } \quad \text { R }
\end{aligned}
$$

There is a uniform magnetic field $B$ perpendicular to the plane of the circle.

8013.b.Solution:

$$
p \cdot 2 \pi R=n h
$$

gives

$$
p=\frac{n \hbar}{R}
$$

and hence

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-697.jpg?height=96&width=83&top_left_y=632&top_left_x=673)Take coordinates with origin at the center of the circle and the $z$ axis along the direction of $\mathbf{B}$. Then the vector potential at a point on the circle is

$$
\hat{H} \psi=E \psi
$$

where

$$

8015.Problem Statement: To find approximate eigenfunctions of the Hamiltonian $H$ we can use trial functions of the form $\psi=\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k} \phi_{k}$ in the variational method (where the $\phi_{k}$ are given functions, and the $a_{k}$ are parameters to be varied). Show that one gets $n$ solutions $\psi_{\alpha}$ with energies $\varepsilon_{\alpha}=\left\langle\psi_{\alpha}|H| \psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle /\left\langle\psi_{\alpha} \mid \psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle$, where $H$ is the Hamiltonian. We will order them so that $\varepsilon_{1} \leq \varepsilon_{2} \leq \varepsilon_{3} \cdots$. Show from the Hermitian properties of the Hamiltonian that the $\psi_{\alpha}$ either automatically have or can be chosen to have the properties $\left\langle\psi_{\alpha} \mid \psi_{\beta}\right\rangle=\delta_{\alpha \beta}$, $\left\langle\psi_{\alpha}|H| \psi_{\beta}\right\rangle=\varepsilon_{\alpha} \delta_{\alpha \beta}$. From the fact that one can certainly find a linear combination of $\psi_{1}$ and $\psi_{2}$ which is orthogonal to $\psi_{1}$, the exact ground state of $H$ with eigenvalue $E_{1}$, prove that $\varepsilon_{2} \geq E_{2}$, where $E_{2}$ is the exact energy of the first excited state.
8015.Solution:
Suppose $\left\{\phi_{k}\right\}$ is the set of linearly independent functions. We may assume that $\left\langle\phi_{i} \mid \phi_{j}\right\rangle=\delta_{i j}$, first using Schmidt's orthogonalization process if necessary. Then

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle}{\langle\psi \mid \psi\rangle}=\frac{\sum_{i, j}^{n} a_{i}^{*} a_{j} \lambda_{i j}}{\sum_{i, j}^{n} a_{i}^{*} a_{j} \delta_{i j}}=\sum_{i, j} x_{i}^{*} \lambda_{i j} x_{j}=X^{+} \hat{\lambda} X
$$

where

$$
x_{i}=\frac{a_{i}}{\sqrt{\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}\right|^{2}}}, \quad \lambda_{i j}=\left\langle\phi_{i}|H| \phi_{j}\right\rangle=\lambda_{j i}^{*}
$$

Note that

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|x_{i}\right|^{2}=1 \text {. }
$$

As $\hat{\lambda}$ is Hermitian, we can choose a rotational transformation $X=\hat{p} Y$, such that $\hat{\Lambda}=\hat{p}^{+} \hat{\lambda} \hat{p}=\hat{p}^{-1} \hat{\lambda} \hat{p}$ is a diagonal matrix with diagonal elements $\Lambda_{11} \leq \Lambda_{22} \leq \Lambda_{33}$. Then

$$
\bar{H}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \Lambda_{i i}\left|y_{i}\right|^{2}
$$

where $y_{i}$ satisfy $\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|y_{i}\right|^{2}=1$.

Applying the variational principle

$$
0=\delta\left[\bar{H}-\alpha\left(\sum_{i}\left|y_{i}\right|^{2}-1\right)\right]=\delta\left[\sum_{i}\left(\Lambda_{i i}-\alpha\right)\left|y_{i}\right|^{2}+\alpha\right]
$$

where $\alpha$ is the Lagrange multiplier, we get

$$
\sum_{i}\left(\Lambda_{i i}-\alpha\right)\left|y_{i}\right| \delta\left|y_{i}\right|=0
$$

or

$$
\left(\Lambda_{i i}-\alpha\right)\left|y_{i}\right|=0, \quad(i=1,2, \cdots)
$$

i.e., $\alpha=\Lambda_{i i}$ or $\left|y_{i}\right|=0$.

Hence the solutions of the variational equations are

$$
\alpha=\Lambda_{i i}, y_{j}^{(i)}=\delta_{j}^{i}=\delta_{i j}, \quad(i=1,2, \cdots, n) .
$$

Thus we get $n$ solutions $\psi_{a}$, the $\alpha$ th solution $y_{i}^{(\alpha)}=\delta_{i}^{(\alpha)}$ corresponding to energy

$$
\varepsilon_{\alpha}=\frac{\left\langle\psi_{\alpha}|H| \psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle}{\left\langle\psi_{\alpha} \mid \psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle}=\sum_{i} \Lambda_{i i}\left|y_{i}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2}=\Lambda_{\alpha \alpha}
$$

with $\varepsilon_{1} \leq \varepsilon_{2} \leq \varepsilon_{3} \ldots$.

For $\psi_{\alpha}=\psi_{\alpha}[X(Y)]$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\psi_{\alpha} \mid \psi_{\beta}\right\rangle &=\sum_{i} a_{i}^{(\alpha) *} a_{i}^{(\beta)} \\
&=\sqrt{\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2} \sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\beta)}\right|^{2}} \cdot \sum_{i} x_{i}^{(\alpha)^{*}} x_{i}^{(\beta)} \\
&=\sqrt{\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2} \sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\beta)}\right|^{2}} \cdot \sum_{i} y_{i}^{(\alpha)^{*}} y_{i}^{(\beta)}=\left[\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2}\right] \delta_{\alpha \beta}, \\
\left\langle\psi_{\alpha}|H| \psi_{\beta}\right\rangle &\left.=\sum_{i, j} a_{i}^{(\alpha) *} \lambda_{i j} a_{j}^{(\beta)}\right] \\
&=\sqrt{\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2} \sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\beta)}\right|^{2}} \cdot \sum_{i, j} x_{i}^{(\alpha)^{*}} \lambda_{i j} x_{j}^{(\beta)} \\
&=\sqrt{\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2} \sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\beta)}\right|^{2}} \cdot \sum_{i, j} y_{i}^{(\alpha)^{*}} \Lambda_{i j} y_{j}^{(\beta)} \\
& {\left[\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2}\right] \varepsilon_{\alpha} \delta_{\alpha \beta} \cdot }
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, by setting $\Psi_{\alpha}=\psi_{\alpha} / \sqrt{\sum_{j}\left|a_{j}^{(\alpha)}\right|^{2}}$, we have

$$
\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha} \mid \Psi_{\beta}\right\rangle=\delta_{\alpha \beta},\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha}|H| \Psi_{\beta}\right\rangle=\varepsilon_{\alpha} \delta_{\alpha \beta} .
$$

Let the exact wave functions of the ground state and the first excited state of $H$ be $\Phi_{1}$ and $\Phi_{2}$, their exact energies be $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ respectively. Then there must exist two numbers $\mu_{1}$ and $\mu_{2}$ such that $\Phi_{1}=\mu_{1} \Psi_{1}+\mu_{2} \Psi_{2}$, $\left|\mu_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|\mu_{2}\right|^{2}=1$. From the orthogonality of $\Phi_{1}$ and $\Phi_{2}$, we have $\Phi_{2}=$ $\mu_{2}^{*} \Psi_{1}-\mu_{1}^{*} \Psi_{2}$, and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{1}=\varepsilon_{1}\left|\mu_{1}\right|^{2}+\varepsilon_{2}\left|\mu_{2}\right|^{2}, \\
&E_{2}=\varepsilon_{1}\left|\mu_{2}\right|^{2}+\varepsilon_{2}\left|\mu_{1}\right|^{2}=\left(\varepsilon_{1}-\varepsilon_{2}\right)\left|\mu_{2}\right|^{2}+\varepsilon_{2} \leq \varepsilon_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

8016.Solution:
Using the trial function $\phi=A e^{-\lambda^{2} x^{2}}$, consider the integrals

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \phi^{*}(x) \phi(x) d x=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} A^{2} e^{-2 \lambda^{2} x^{2}} d x=A^{2} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2 \lambda^{2}}}=1 \\
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \phi^{*}(x) H \phi(x) d x=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} A^{2} e^{-\lambda^{2} x^{2}}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+b x^{4}\right) e^{-\lambda^{2} x^{2}} d x
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
=& A^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m}\left(2 \lambda^{4} x^{2}-\lambda^{2}\right)+b x^{4}\right] e^{-2 \lambda^{2} x^{2}} d x \\
=& A^{2}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m}\left(2 \lambda^{4} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{\left(2 \lambda^{2}\right)^{3}}}-\lambda^{2} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2 \lambda^{2}}}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+b \frac{3}{4} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{\left(2 \lambda^{2}\right)^{5}}}\right] \\
=& A^{2}\left[\frac{1}{2} \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}} \lambda+b \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{3}{16 \lambda^{5}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and obtain

$$
\langle H\rangle=\frac{\int \phi^{*} H \phi d x}{\int \phi^{*} \phi d x}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} \lambda^{2}+b \frac{3}{8 \lambda^{4}}\right) .
$$

As $\frac{1}{3}(a+b+c) \geq(a b c)^{1 / 3}$ for positive numbers $a, b, c$, we have

$$
\langle H\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\hbar^{2} \lambda^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{\hbar^{2} \lambda^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{3 b}{8 \lambda^{4}}\right) \geq \frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{\hbar^{4}}{4 m^{2}} \cdot \frac{3 b}{8}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} .
$$

Hence the best approximation for the energy of the ground state is

$$
\langle H\rangle_{\min }=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\left(\frac{b \hbar^{4}}{m^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}
$$

8017.b.Problem Statement:
Consider the energy levels of the potential $V=g|x|$.

With the simple trial function

$$
V=c \theta(x+a) \theta(a-x)\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right)
$$

compute (to the bitter end) a variational estimate of the ground state energy. Here $c, a$ are variable parameters, $\theta(x)=0$ for $x<0, \theta(x)=1$ for $x>0$.
8017.b.Solution:
The Schrödinger equation

$$
\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+g|x|\right) \psi(x)=E \psi(x)
$$

can be written as

$$
\left[\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}(E-g|x|)\right] \psi(x)=0 .
$$

As

$$
\left[\frac{m E}{\hbar^{2}}\right]=L^{-2},\left[\frac{m g}{\hbar^{2}}\right]=L^{-3}
$$

we have

$$
\left[\left(\frac{m E}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{3}\right]=\left[\left(\frac{m g}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

or

$$
[E]=\left[\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} g^{2}\right)^{1 / 3}\right]
$$

Hence the eigenvalue has the form

$$
E_{n}=\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} g^{2}\right)^{1 / 3} f(n)
$$

where $f(n)$ is a function of a positive integer $n$.

First normalize the trial wave function. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
1 &=\int \psi^{*}(x) \psi(x) d x=|c|^{2} \int\left[\theta(x+a) \theta(a-x)\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right)\right]^{2} d x \\
&=|c|^{2} \int_{-a}^{a}\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right)^{2} d x=\frac{2 a}{3}|c|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
|c|^{2}=\frac{3}{2 a} .
$$

Then calculate the average value of the Hamiltonian:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H} &=\int \psi^{*} H \psi d x \\
&=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x) \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi(x) d x+g \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x)|x| \psi(x) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{*}(x)|x| \psi(x) d x=&|c|^{2}\left\{-\int_{-a}^{0} x\left(1+\frac{x}{a}\right)^{2} d x+\int_{0}^{a} x\left(1-\frac{x}{a}\right)^{2} d x\right\} \\
=& a^{2}|c|^{2} / 6=a / 4 \\
\frac{d}{d x} \psi(x)=& c \delta(x+a) \theta(a-x)\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right) \\
&-c \theta(x+a) \delta(x-a)\left(1-\frac{|x|}{a}\right) \\
&+c \theta(x+a) \theta(x-a)\left(-\frac{|x|}{x} \frac{1}{a}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \psi^{\prime}(x) \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}} \psi(x) d x &=\left.\psi(x) \frac{d}{d x} \psi(x)\right|_{-\infty} ^{\infty}-\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{d \psi}{d x}\right)^{2} d x \\
&=-\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{d \psi}{d x}\right)^{2} d x \\
&=-|c|^{2} \int_{-a}^{a}\left(-\frac{|x|}{x a}\right)^{2} d x \\
&=-2|c|^{2} / a=-3 / a^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{2 m a^{2}}+\frac{a}{4} g .
$$

For its minimum value, let

$$
\frac{\delta \bar{H}}{\delta a}=-\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{m a^{3}}+\frac{g}{4}=0
$$

which gives

$$
a=\left(\frac{12 \hbar^{2}}{g m}\right)^{1 / 3} \text {. }
$$

Hence an estimate of the ground state energy is

$$
\bar{H}=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(\frac{g m}{12 \hbar^{2}}\right)^{2 / 3}+\frac{g}{4}\left(\frac{12 \hbar^{2}}{g m}\right)^{1 / 3}=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{3 \hbar^{2} g^{2}}{2 m}\right)^{1 / 3} .
$$

8018.Problem Statement:
(Use nonrelativistic methods to solve this problem.) Most mesons can be described as bound quark-antiquark states $(q \bar{q})$. Consider the case of a meson made of a $(q \bar{q})$ pair in an $s$-state. Let $m_{q}$ be the quark mass.

Assume the potential binding the $q$ to the $\bar{q}$ can be written as $V=$ $\frac{A}{r}+B r$ with $A<0$ and $B>0$. You are asked to find a reasonable approximation to the ground state energy of this system in terms of $A, B, m_{q}$ and $\hbar$. Unfortunately, for a class of trial functions appropriate to this problem, a cubic equation has to be solved. If this happens to you, and you do not want to spend your limited time trying to solve such a cubic equation, you may complete your solution for the case $A=0$ (without loss of credit). Please express your final answer in terms of a numerical constant, which you should explicitly evaluate, multiplying a function of $B, m_{q}$ and $\hbar$. (Berkeley)
8018.Solution:
Method I

Use for the trial function the wave function of a ground state hydrogen atom.

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r})=e^{-r / a}
$$

and calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{H}=&\langle\psi|H| \psi\rangle /\langle\psi \mid \psi\rangle \\
=& \int_{0}^{\infty} d r r^{2} e^{-r / a}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+A r^{-1}+B r\right] e^{-r / a} / \int_{0}^{\infty} d r r^{2} e^{-2 r / a} \\
=& \frac{3 B a}{2}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{a^{2}}+\frac{A}{a},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mu=\frac{m_{q}}{2}$ is the reduced mass of the $q \bar{q}$ system. Vary a to minimize $\bar{H}$ by letting $\frac{\delta \vec{H}}{\delta a}=0$, which gives

$$
\frac{3}{2} B a^{3}-A a-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{\mu}=0 .
$$

When $A=0$, the solution is $a=\left(\frac{2 \hbar^{2}}{3 B \mu}\right)^{1 / 3}$. Hence the estimated ground state energy is 

$$
E_{g}=\vec{H}=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{36 B^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{1 / 3}=2.48\left(\frac{B^{2} \hbar^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{1 / 3} .
$$

Method II

Another estimate of the energy of the ground state can be obtained from the uncertainty principle. Consider

$$
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2 \mu}+\frac{A}{r}+B r .
$$

As the principle requires

$$
p_{x} x \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}, p_{y} y \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}, p_{z} z \geq \frac{\hbar}{2},
$$

we take the equal sign for the ground state and obtain

$$
H=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 \mu x^{2}}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 \mu y^{2}}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 \mu z^{2}}+\frac{A}{r}+B r .
$$

To minimize $H$, let

$$
\frac{\partial H}{\partial x}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{-\hbar^{2}}{4 \mu x^{2}}-\frac{A x}{r^{3}}+\frac{B x}{r}=0 .
$$

As $H$ is symmetric with respect to $x, y, z$, when it reaches the optimal value, we have $x=y=z$, or $r=\sqrt{3} x$, and the above equation becomes

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 \mu x^{3}}-\frac{A}{3 \sqrt{3} x^{2}}+\frac{B}{\sqrt{3}}=0 .
$$

Letting $A=0$ we get

$$
x=3^{\frac{1}{6}}\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 \mu B}\right)^{1 / 3}, \quad \text { or } \quad r=\left(\frac{9 \hbar^{2}}{4 \mu B}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

Hence

$$
\vec{H}=\frac{3 \hbar^{2}}{8 \mu x^{2}}+B r=2\left(\frac{9}{2} \frac{\hbar^{2} B^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}=3.30\left(\frac{\hbar^{2} B^{2}}{m_{q}}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

8020.Problem Statement: A particle moves in an attractive central potential $V(r)=-g^{2} / r^{3 / 2}$. Use the variational principle to find an upper bound to the lowest $s$-state energy. Use a hydrogenic wave function as your trial function.
8020.Solution:
As the trial function we use the normalized ground state wave function of the hydrogen atom,

$$
\psi=\left(\frac{k^{3}}{8 \pi}\right)^{1 / 2} e^{-k r / 2}
$$

to calculate the energy. For an $s$-state, $l=0$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\vec{H}(k) &=\int \psi^{*} H \psi d \tau \\
&=\int \psi^{*}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)+V(r)\right] \psi d \tau \\
&=\frac{k^{3}}{8 \pi} \cdot 4 \pi \int_{0}^{+\infty} r^{2} e^{-k r / 2}\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{2} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)-\frac{g^{2}}{r^{3 / 2}}\right] e^{-k r / 2} d r \\
&=\frac{k^{3}}{2} \int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-k r}\left[-g^{2} r^{1 / 2}+\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} k r-\frac{k^{2} \hbar^{2}}{8 m} r^{2}\right] d r \\
&=\frac{k^{3}}{2}\left[\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m k}-\frac{\sqrt{\pi} g^{2}}{2 k^{3 / 2}}\right] \\
&=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 m} k^{2}-\frac{\sqrt{\pi} g^{2}}{4} k^{3 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\bar{H}$ to be a minimum, $\frac{\partial \bar{H}}{\partial k}=0$, i.e. $\frac{\hbar^{2}}{4 m} k-\frac{3 \sqrt{\pi}}{8} g^{2} k^{1 / 2}=0$, giving two solutions $k_{1}=0$,

$$
k_{2}^{1 / 2}=\frac{3 \sqrt{\pi} g^{2} m}{2 \hbar^{2}} .
$$

The first solution implies $\psi=0$ and is to be discarded. On the other hand, if $k_{2}^{1 / 2}=\frac{3 \sqrt{\pi} g^{2} m}{2 \hbar^{2}}, \bar{H}$ reaches a minium $-\frac{27 \pi^{2} g^{8} m^{3}}{128 \hbar^{6}}$. This is the upper bound to the lowest $s$-state energy.

8021.a.Problem Statement:
A system of spin-1 particles consists of an incoherent mixture of the following 3 pure spin states, each state being equally probable, i.e. one third of the particles are in state $\psi^{(1)}$, etc.

$$
\psi^{(1)}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(2)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(3)}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Find the polarization vector for each of these 3 pure states.

Reminder: for $J=1$,

$$
J_{x}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 1 & 0 \\
1 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{array}\right), J_{y}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -i & 0 \\
i & 0 & -i \\
0 & i & 0
\end{array}\right), J_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$
8021.a.Solution:
The polarization vector for a state $i$ is given by

$$
\mathbf{P}^{(i)}=\left\langle\psi^{(i)}|\mathbf{J}| \psi^{(i)}\right\rangle .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P_{x}^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1 & 0 \\1 & 0 & 1 \\0 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=0 \text {, } \\
& P_{y}^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & -i & 0 \\i & 0 & -i \\0 & i & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=0 \text {, } \\
& P_{z}^{(1)}=(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -1\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=1 \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

and so $\mathbf{P}^{(1)}=(0,0,1)$.

Similarly we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{P}^{(2)}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, 0,-\frac{1}{2}\right), \\
&\mathbf{P}^{(3)}=(0,0,-1) .
\end{aligned}
$$

0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Calculate the density matrix $\rho$ for the system and verify that $\operatorname{Tr} \rho=1$

Reminder: for $J=1$,

$$
J_{x}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 1 & 0 \\
1 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{array}\right), J_{y}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}

8021.c.Solution:
The polarization vector for a state $i$ is given by

$$
\mathbf{P}^{(i)}=\left\langle\psi^{(i)}|\mathbf{J}| \psi^{(i)}\right\rangle .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P_{x}^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1 & 0 \\1 & 0 & 1 \\0 & 1 & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=0 \text {, } \\
& P_{y}^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}0 & -i & 0 \\i & 0 & -i \\0 & i & 0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=0 \text {, } \\
& P_{z}^{(1)}=(1,0,0)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & 0 \\0 & 0 & -1\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\0 \\0\end{array}\right)=1 \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

and so $\mathbf{P}^{(1)}=(0,0,1)$.

Similarly we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{P}^{(2)}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, 0,-\frac{1}{2}\right), \\
&\mathbf{P}^{(3)}=(0,0,-1) .
\end{aligned}
$$For the incoherent mixture, $\mathbf{P}$ is the sum of the polarization vectors:

$$
\mathbf{P}=\frac{1}{3}\left[\mathbf{P}^{(1)}+\mathbf{P}^{(2)}+\mathbf{P}^{(3)}\right]=\frac{1}{6}(\sqrt{2}, 0,-1) .
$$In terms of the orthonormal vectors

$$
|1\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right),|2\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right),|3\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\psi^{(1)}\right\rangle &=|1\rangle,\left|\psi^{(2)}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|2\rangle+|3\rangle), \\
\left|\psi^{(3)}\right\rangle &=|3\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Generally a state can be expressed as

$$
\left|\psi^{(i)}\right\rangle=\sum_{n=1}^{3} C_{n}^{i}|n\rangle,
$$

where $i=1,2,3$. The density matrix is defined as

$$
\rho=\sum_{i} \omega^{(i)}\left|\psi^{(i)}\right\rangle\left\langle\psi^{(i)}\right|
$$

where $\omega^{(i)}$ is the probability that the system is in the pure state $\left|\psi^{(i)}\right\rangle$, or

$$
\rho_{m n}=\sum_{i} \omega^{i} C_{n}^{i *} C_{m}^{i}=\frac{1}{3} \sum_{i} C_{n}^{i *} C_{m}^{i}
$$

as $\omega^{(i)}=\frac{1}{3}$ for all $i$ in the present case. The matrix of the coefficients is

$$
C=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

and so

$$
\rho=\frac{1}{3} C^{+} C=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1}{3} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{6} \\
0 & \frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
\operatorname{Tr} \rho=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{2}=1 .
$$

8022.a.Problem Statement:
The deuteron is a bound state of a neutron and a proton in which the two spins are coupled with a resultant total angular momentum $S=1$. By absorbing a gamma ray of more than $2.2 \mathrm{MeV}$ the deuteron may disintegrate into a free neutron and a free proton.

Write a wave function for the final state in the reaction $\gamma+D \rightarrow n+p$ using plane waves and being sure to include properly the spin coordinates for the two particles. Assume that the interaction with the gamma ray is via electric dipole coupling.
(You may use the following definition of spin correlation: If a proton is detected with spin "up", what is the probability that the corresponding deuteron will also be detected with spin "up"?)

(Berkeley)
8022.a.Solution:
The ground state deuteron ${ }^{3} S_{1}$ has positive parity. The electric dipole transition requires a change of parity between the initial and final states. Hence the parity of the free $(n, p)$ system must have parity -1. Assume that the wave function of $(n, p)$ can be written as $\Psi(n, p) \sim$ $\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{n}, \mathbf{r}_{p}\right) \chi(n, p)$. For $\chi=\chi_{1}^{3}$, after the nucleons are interchanged the wave function becomes $\Psi(p, n)=(-1)^{l} \Psi(n, p)$. For $\chi=\chi_{0}^{1}$, after the nucleons are interchanged, the wave function becomes $\Psi(p, n)=(-1)^{l+1} \Psi(n, p)$. A fermion system must be antisymmetric with respect to interchange of any two particles, which means that for the former case, $l=1,3, \ldots$, and for the latter case, $l=0,2,4, \ldots$, and so the parities are $-1(l=$ odd $)$ and $+1(l=$ even $)$ respectively. Considering the requirement we see that only states with $\chi=\chi_{1}^{3}$, i.e. spin triplet states, are possible. Further, $S=1, L=1,3, \ldots$, and so $J=0,1,2, \ldots$. As the deuterons are unpolarized, its spin wave function has the same probability of being $\chi_{11}, \chi_{10}$ or $\chi_{1-1}$. Therefore, after the transition $(n, p)$ can be represented by the product of a plane wave and the average spin wave function:

$$
\Psi(n, p) \sim e^{i\left(\mathbf{k}_{n} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{n}+\mathbf{k}_{p} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{p}\right)} \cdot e^{-i\left(\omega_{n} t+\omega_{p} t\right)}(1 / \sqrt{3})\left(\chi_{11}+\chi_{10}+\chi_{1-1}\right) .
$$

8022.b.Problem Statement:
The deuteron is a bound state of a neutron and a proton in which the two spins are coupled with a resultant total angular momentum $S=1$. By absorbing a gamma ray of more than $2.2 \mathrm{MeV}$ the deuteron may disintegrate into a free neutron and a free proton.

Suppose the neutron and the proton are to be detected far apart from each other after the disintegration of the deuteron. Looking at this in the center-of-mass system, what correlations will be found in time and space, and in spin? Assume that the target consists of unpolarized deuterons.
(You may use the following definition of spin correlation: If a proton is detected with spin "up", what is the probability that the corresponding deuteron will also be detected with spin "up"?)

(Berkeley)
8022.b.Solution:
The ground state deuteron ${ }^{3} S_{1}$ has positive parity. The electric dipole transition requires a change of parity between the initial and final states. Hence the parity of the free $(n, p)$ system must have parity -1. Assume that the wave function of $(n, p)$ can be written as $\Psi(n, p) \sim$ $\psi\left(\mathbf{r}_{n}, \mathbf{r}_{p}\right) \chi(n, p)$. For $\chi=\chi_{1}^{3}$, after the nucleons are interchanged the wave function becomes $\Psi(p, n)=(-1)^{l} \Psi(n, p)$. For $\chi=\chi_{0}^{1}$, after the nucleons are interchanged, the wave function becomes $\Psi(p, n)=(-1)^{l+1} \Psi(n, p)$. A fermion system must be antisymmetric with respect to interchange of any two particles, which means that for the former case, $l=1,3, \ldots$, and for the latter case, $l=0,2,4, \ldots$, and so the parities are $-1(l=$ odd $)$ and $+1(l=$ even $)$ respectively. Considering the requirement we see that only states with $\chi=\chi_{1}^{3}$, i.e. spin triplet states, are possible. Further, $S=1, L=1,3, \ldots$, and so $J=0,1,2, \ldots$. As the deuterons are unpolarized, its spin wave function has the same probability of being $\chi_{11}, \chi_{10}$ or $\chi_{1-1}$. Therefore, after the transition $(n, p)$ can be represented by the product of a plane wave and the average spin wave function:

$$
\Psi(n, p) \sim e^{i\left(\mathbf{k}_{n} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{n}+\mathbf{k}_{p} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{p}\right)} \cdot e^{-i\left(\omega_{n} t+\omega_{p} t\right)}(1 / \sqrt{3})\left(\chi_{11}+\chi_{10}+\chi_{1-1}\right) .
$$The correlation of time and space is manifested in conservation of energy and conservation of momentum. In the center-of-mass coordinates, if the energy of the proton is measured to be $E_{p}$, the energy of the neutron is $E_{n}=E_{\mathrm{cm}}-E_{p}$; if the momentum of the proton is $\mathbf{p}$, the momentum of the neutron is $-\mathbf{p}$. Let $\alpha$ be the spin function for "up" spin, and $\beta$ be that for "down" spin. Then $\chi_{11}=\alpha(n) \alpha(p), \chi_{1-1}=\beta(n) \beta(p), \chi_{10}=$ $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[\alpha(n) \beta(p)+\alpha(p) \beta(n)]$, and the spin wave function is

$$
\chi(n, p)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\alpha(n)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \beta(n)\right] \alpha(p)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \alpha(n)+\beta(n)\right] \beta(p) .
$$

Thus, if the spin of $p$ is detected to be up, we have

$$
\chi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \alpha(n) \alpha(p)+\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \beta(n) \alpha(p)
$$

Hence the probability that the spin state of $n$ is also up is

$$
\frac{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}}{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{2}{3}
$$

8024.c.Problem Statement:
Consider a free electron near a boundary surface.

Examine the expression for $u(0, t)$ as a sum over $k$ as given in (a). What is the range of $\varepsilon_{k}$ which contribute significantly to $u(0, t)$ at the time when the influence of the boundary is felt by the electron?
8024.c.Solution:
The wave function $\phi_{k}(x)$ satisfies the Schrödinger equation of a free particle

$$
-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \nabla^{2} \phi_{k}(\mathbf{x})=\varepsilon_{k} \phi_{k}(\mathbf{x}) .
$$

Thus

$$
\nabla^{2} u(\mathbf{x}, t)=-\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}} \sum_{k} \varepsilon_{k} \phi_{k}^{*}(\mathbf{x}) \phi_{k}(0) \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

Since

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} u(\mathbf{x}, t)=-\frac{1}{\hbar} \sum_{k} \varepsilon_{k} \phi_{k}^{*}(\mathbf{x}) \phi_{k}(0) \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

$u(x, t)$ satisfies the following diffusion-type equation:

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} u(\mathbf{x}, t)=\frac{\hbar}{2 m} \nabla^{2} u(\mathbf{x}, t) .
$$

The corresponding diffusion coefficient is $\hbar / 2 m$.

Initially $u(x, 0)=\delta(x)$. When $t>0$, the function $u$ starts diffusing to both sides. The boundary will not be felt by the electron before a lapse of time.

Suppose the boundary is at $x=l$. The solution of the diffusion equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
u(\mathbf{x}, t)=& c \exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\right] \\
& \times\left\{\exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t} x^{2}\right]-\exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}(x-2 l)^{2}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

When there is no boundary (i.e., $l \rightarrow \infty$ ), the solution is

$$
u(\mathbf{x}, t)=c \exp \left[-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\right] \exp \left(-\frac{m}{2 \hbar t} x^{2}\right) .
$$

From the above two expressions, we see that only when $\frac{m}{2 \hbar t}(0-2 l)^{2} \sim 1$, i.e., at $t \sim 2 m l^{2} / \hbar$, will the electron start to feel the existence of the boundary.

Consider

$$
u(0, t)=\sum_{k}\left|\phi_{k}(0)\right|^{2} \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar}\right)
$$

Only states $\phi_{k}$ for which the energy $\varepsilon_{k}$ is such that $\frac{\varepsilon_{k} t}{\hbar} \lesssim 1$ will contribute significantly to $u(0, t)$. At the time $t \sim \frac{2 m l^{2}}{\hbar}$, we require $\varepsilon_{k} \leq \frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m l^{2}}$ for $\phi_{k}$ to make a significant contribution.

8026.Problem Statement:
In a crude picture, a metal is viewed as a system of free electrons enclosed in a well of potential difference $V_{0}$. Due to thermal agitations, electrons with sufficiently high energies will escape from the well. Find and discuss the emission current density for this model.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-723.jpg?height=251&width=511&top_left_y=491&top_left_x=411)

Fig. $8.7$
8026.Solution:
The system of free electrons can be considered as an electron gas of volume $V$ which obeys the Fermi statistics. At absolute temperature $T$ the number density of electrons with momenta between $\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{P}+d \mathbf{P}$, where $\mathbf{P}=\left(P_{x}, P_{y}, P_{z}\right)$, is

$$
\frac{d N}{V}=\frac{1}{V} \cdot \frac{d P_{x} d P_{y} d P_{z}}{e^{(\varepsilon-\mu) / k T}+1} \cdot \frac{2 V}{h^{3}}
$$

where the factor 2 is the degeneracy due to the electrons having two spin directions.

Consider the number of electrons, $j_{n}$, leaving $V$ in the $z$ direction per unit cross sectional area per unit time. Such electrons must have a speed

$$
v_{z}=\frac{P_{z}}{m} \geq \frac{1}{m} \sqrt{2 m V_{0}} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
j_{n}=& \int v_{z} \frac{d N}{V}=\frac{2}{m h^{3}} \int_{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}^{\infty} P_{z} d P_{z} \\
& \times \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{d P_{x} d P_{y}}{\exp \left\{\left[\frac{1}{2 m}\left(P_{x}^{2}+P_{y}^{2}+P_{z}^{2}\right)-\mu\right] / k T\right\}+1},
\end{aligned}
$$

or, by setting $P_{x}^{2}+P_{y}^{2}=P_{r}^{2}, d P_{x} d P_{y}=2 \pi P_{r} d P_{r}$, and neglecting the number 1 in the denominator,

$$
\begin{aligned}
j_{n} & \approx \frac{4 \pi}{m h^{3}} \int_{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}^{\infty} P_{z} d P_{z} \int_{0}^{\infty} \exp \left\{-\frac{1}{k T}\left[\frac{1}{2 m}\left(P_{z}^{2}+P_{r}^{2}\right)-\mu\right]\right\} P_{r} d P_{r} \\
&=\frac{4 \pi k T}{h^{3}} \int_{\sqrt{2 m V_{0}}}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{k T}\left(\frac{P_{z}}{2 m}-\mu\right)\right] P_{z} d P_{z} \\
&=\frac{4 \pi m k^{2} T^{2}}{h^{3}} e^{-\left(V_{0}-\mu\right) / k T} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The electric current density is then

$$
j_{e}=-e j_{n}=-\frac{4 \pi m e k^{2} T^{2}}{h^{3}} e^{-\left(V_{0}-\mu\right) / k T} .
$$

Note that in the above, to simplify the integration, we have assumed

$$
k T \ll \frac{1}{2 m} \cdot 2 m V_{0}-\mu=V_{0}-\mu .
$$

At $T=0$ the electron number density is

$$
n=\frac{2}{h^{3}} \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3} P_{0}^{3}=\frac{1}{3 \pi^{2} \hbar^{3}}\left(2 m \mu_{0}\right)^{3 / 2}
$$

where $P_{0}, \mu_{0}$, are the limiting momentum and energy. At ordinary temperatures we have

$$
\mu \approx \mu_{0}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(3 \pi^{2} n\right)^{2 / 3} .
$$

The quantity $V_{0}-\mu$ is the work function of the metal and the emission of electrons from incandescent cathodes is known as Richardson's effect.

8027.a.Problem Statement:
It is generally recognized that there are at least three different kinds of neutrinos. They can be distinguished by the reactions in which the neutrinos are created or absorbed. Let us call these three types of neutrino $
u_{e}, 
u_{\mu}$ and $
u_{	au}$. It has been speculated that each of the neutrinos has a small but finite rest mass, possibly different for each type. Let us suppose, for this exam question, that there is a small perturbing interaction between these neutrino types, in the absence of which all three types have the same nonzero rest mass $M_{0}$. Let the matrix element of this perturbation have the same real value $\hbar \omega_{1}$ between each pair of neutino types. Let it have zero expectation value in each of the states $
u_{e}, 
u_{\mu}$ and $
u_{	au}$.

A neutrino of type $
u_{e}$ is produced at rest at time zero. What is the probability, as a function of time, that the neutrino will be in each of the other two states?

(Berkeley)
8027.a.Solution:
In the representation of $\left|\nu_{e}\right\rangle,\left|\nu_{\mu}\right\rangle$ and $\left|\nu_{\tau}\right|$, the matrix of the Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{lll}
M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0}
\end{array}\right)
$$

The Schrödinger equation

$$
\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{\partial \Psi}{\partial t}+H \Psi=0
$$

where $\Psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}a_{1} \\ a_{2} \\ a_{3}\end{array}\right), a_{i}$ being the wave function for state $\nu_{i}$, has the matrix form

$$
i \hbar\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{a}_{1} \\
\dot{a}_{2} \\
\dot{a}_{3}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2} \\
a_{3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

with the initial condition

$$
a_{1}(0)=1, a_{2}(0)=a_{3}(0)=0 .
$$

The solution is

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}(t)=e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(\frac{2}{3} e^{i \omega_{1} t}+\frac{1}{3} e^{-i 2 \omega_{1} t}\right) \\
a_{2}(t)=\frac{1}{3} e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(e^{-2 \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right) \\
a_{3}(t)=\frac{1}{3} e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(e^{-2 \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence the probabilities of the neutrino being in states $\nu_{\mu}$ and $\nu_{\tau}$ are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
P\left(\nu_{\mu}\right)=\left|a_{2}(t)\right|^{2}=\frac{2}{9}\left(1-\cos 3 \omega_{1} t\right), \\
P\left(\nu_{\tau}\right)=\left|a_{3}(t)\right|^{2}=\frac{2}{9}\left(1-\cos 3 \omega_{1} t\right) .
\end{array}\right.
$$

8027.b.Problem Statement:
It is generally recognized that there are at least three different kinds of neutrinos. They can be distinguished by the reactions in which the neutrinos are created or absorbed. Let us call these three types of neutrino $
u_{e}, 
u_{\mu}$ and $
u_{	au}$. It has been speculated that each of the neutrinos has a small but finite rest mass, possibly different for each type. Let us suppose, for this exam question, that there is a small perturbing interaction between these neutrino types, in the absence of which all three types have the same nonzero rest mass $M_{0}$. Let the matrix element of this perturbation have the same real value $\hbar \omega_{1}$ between each pair of neutino types. Let it have zero expectation value in each of the states $
u_{e}, 
u_{\mu}$ and $
u_{	au}$.

[Can be answered independently of (a)] An experiment to detect these "neutrino oscillations" is being performed. The flight path of the neutrinos is 2000 meters. Their energy is $100 \mathrm{GeV}$. The sensitivity is such that the presence of $1 \%$ of neutrinos of one type different from that produced at the start of the flight path can be measured with confidence. Take $M_{0}$ to be 20 electron volts. What is the smallest value of $\hbar \omega_{1}$ that can be detected? How does this depend on $M_{0}$ ?

(Berkeley)
8027.b.Solution:
In the representation of $\left|\nu_{e}\right\rangle,\left|\nu_{\mu}\right\rangle$ and $\left|\nu_{\tau}\right|$, the matrix of the Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{lll}
M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0}
\end{array}\right)
$$

The Schrödinger equation

$$
\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{\partial \Psi}{\partial t}+H \Psi=0
$$

where $\Psi=\left(\begin{array}{l}a_{1} \\ a_{2} \\ a_{3}\end{array}\right), a_{i}$ being the wave function for state $\nu_{i}$, has the matrix form

$$
i \hbar\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{a}_{1} \\
\dot{a}_{2} \\
\dot{a}_{3}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} & M_{0}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2} \\
a_{3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

with the initial condition

$$
a_{1}(0)=1, a_{2}(0)=a_{3}(0)=0 .
$$

The solution is

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}(t)=e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(\frac{2}{3} e^{i \omega_{1} t}+\frac{1}{3} e^{-i 2 \omega_{1} t}\right) \\
a_{2}(t)=\frac{1}{3} e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(e^{-2 \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right) \\
a_{3}(t)=\frac{1}{3} e^{-i M_{0} t / \hbar}\left(e^{-2 \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence the probabilities of the neutrino being in states $\nu_{\mu}$ and $\nu_{\tau}$ are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
P\left(\nu_{\mu}\right)=\left|a_{2}(t)\right|^{2}=\frac{2}{9}\left(1-\cos 3 \omega_{1} t\right), \\
P\left(\nu_{\tau}\right)=\left|a_{3}(t)\right|^{2}=\frac{2}{9}\left(1-\cos 3 \omega_{1} t\right) .
\end{array}\right.
$$The time of flight of $\nu_{e}$ is $\Delta t=\frac{l}{v}$ in the laboratory time, or $\Delta \tau=$ $\Delta t \sqrt{1-\left(\frac{v}{c}\right)^{2}} \approx \frac{l}{c} \frac{M_{0}}{E}$, where $E$ is the total energy, in the rest frame of $\nu_{e}$. For $P\left(\nu_{\mu}\right) \geq 1 \%$, i.e.,

$$
\frac{2}{9}\left[1-\cos \left(3 \omega_{1} \Delta \tau\right)\right] \gtrsim 0.01
$$

we require

$$
\omega_{1} \geq \frac{\cos ^{-1} 0.955}{3 \Delta \tau}=\frac{0.301}{3 \Delta \tau}=\frac{0.1 c E}{l M_{0}},
$$

or

$$
\hbar \omega_{1} \geq \frac{0.1 \times 3 \times 10^{8} \times 100 \times 10^{9} \times 6.58 \times 10^{-16}}{2000 \times 20}=0.05 \mathrm{eV}
$$

8029.a.Problem Statement:
Consider an idealized (point charge) $\mathrm{Al}$ atom $(Z=13, A=27)$. If a negative lepton or meson is captured by this atom it rapidly cascades down to the lower $n$ states which are inside the electron shells. In the case of $\mu$-capture:

Compute the energy $E_{1}$ for the $\mu$ in the $n=1$ orbit; estimate also a mean radius. Neglect relativistic effects and nuclear motion.
8029.a.Solution:
We shall neglect the effects of the electrons outside the nucleus and consider only the motion of the $\mu$ in the Coulomb field of the $\mathrm{Al}$ nucleus. The energy levels of $\mu$ in a hydrogen-like atom of nuclear charge $Z$ (in the nonrelativistic approximation) are given by

$$
E_{n}=-\frac{m e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \frac{Z^{2}}{n^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} &=-\frac{m}{m_{e}} \frac{m_{e} e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} Z^{2}=-\frac{105}{0.51} \times 13.6 \times 13^{2} \mathrm{eV} \\
&=-0.4732 \mathrm{MeV}, \\
a &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{Z m e^{2}}=\frac{m_{e}}{Z m} \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m_{e} e^{2}}=\frac{0.5}{13 \times 105} \times 0.53 \AA \\
&=1.9 \times 10^{-4} \AA .
\end{aligned}
$$
8029.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

8029.b.Problem Statement:
Consider an idealized (point charge) $\mathrm{Al}$ atom $(Z=13, A=27)$. If a negative lepton or meson is captured by this atom it rapidly cascades down to the lower $n$ states which are inside the electron shells. In the case of $\mu$-capture:

Now compute a correction to $E_{1}$ to take into account the nuclear motion.
8029.b.Solution:
We shall neglect the effects of the electrons outside the nucleus and consider only the motion of the $\mu$ in the Coulomb field of the $\mathrm{Al}$ nucleus. The energy levels of $\mu$ in a hydrogen-like atom of nuclear charge $Z$ (in the nonrelativistic approximation) are given by

$$
E_{n}=-\frac{m e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \frac{Z^{2}}{n^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} &=-\frac{m}{m_{e}} \frac{m_{e} e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} Z^{2}=-\frac{105}{0.51} \times 13.6 \times 13^{2} \mathrm{eV} \\
&=-0.4732 \mathrm{MeV}, \\
a &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{Z m e^{2}}=\frac{m_{e}}{Z m} \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m_{e} e^{2}}=\frac{0.5}{13 \times 105} \times 0.53 \AA \\
&=1.9 \times 10^{-4} \AA .
\end{aligned}
$$To take into account the motion of the nucleus, we simply have to replace the mass $m$ of the meson with its reduced mass $\mu=\frac{M m}{M+m}, M$ being the nuclear mass. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1}^{\prime} &=\frac{\mu}{m} E_{1}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{m}{M}} E_{1}=\frac{-0.4732}{1+\frac{105}{27 \times 938}} \\
&=-0.471 \mathrm{MeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$
8029.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Quantum Mechanics

8029.c.Problem Statement:
Consider an idealized (point charge) $\mathrm{Al}$ atom $(Z=13, A=27)$. If a negative lepton or meson is captured by this atom it rapidly cascades down to the lower $n$ states which are inside the electron shells. In the case of $\mu$-capture:

Find a perturbation term to the Hamiltonian due to relativistic kinematics, ignoring spin. Estimate the resulting correction to $E_{1}$.
8029.c.Solution:
We shall neglect the effects of the electrons outside the nucleus and consider only the motion of the $\mu$ in the Coulomb field of the $\mathrm{Al}$ nucleus. The energy levels of $\mu$ in a hydrogen-like atom of nuclear charge $Z$ (in the nonrelativistic approximation) are given by

$$
E_{n}=-\frac{m e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} \frac{Z^{2}}{n^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} &=-\frac{m}{m_{e}} \frac{m_{e} e^{4}}{2 \hbar^{2}} Z^{2}=-\frac{105}{0.51} \times 13.6 \times 13^{2} \mathrm{eV} \\
&=-0.4732 \mathrm{MeV}, \\
a &=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{Z m e^{2}}=\frac{m_{e}}{Z m} \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m_{e} e^{2}}=\frac{0.5}{13 \times 105} \times 0.53 \AA \\
&=1.9 \times 10^{-4} \AA .
\end{aligned}
$$To take into account the motion of the nucleus, we simply have to replace the mass $m$ of the meson with its reduced mass $\mu=\frac{M m}{M+m}, M$ being the nuclear mass. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1}^{\prime} &=\frac{\mu}{m} E_{1}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{m}{M}} E_{1}=\frac{-0.4732}{1+\frac{105}{27 \times 938}} \\
&=-0.471 \mathrm{MeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$Taking into account the relativistic effects the muon kinetic energy is

$$
T=\sqrt{p^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}}-m c^{2}=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}-\frac{p^{4}}{8 m^{3} c^{2}}+\cdots .
$$

The relativistic correction introduces a perturbation Hamiltonian

$$
H=-\frac{p^{4}}{8 m^{3} c^{2}} .
$$

The energy correction $\Delta E$ for $E_{1}$ is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &=\left\langle 100\left|-\frac{p^{4}}{8 m^{3} c^{2}}\right| 100\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left\langle 100\left|\frac{p^{2}}{2 m} \cdot \frac{p^{2}}{2 m}\right| 100\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left\langle 100\left|\left(H+\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}\right)\left(H+\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}\right)\right| 100\right\rangle \\
&=-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left\langle 100\left|\left(E_{1}+\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}\right)^{2}\right| 100\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

For a rough estimate, take $r \approx a$. Then

$$
\Delta E \approx-\frac{1}{2 m c^{2}}\left(E_{1}+\frac{Z e^{2}}{a}\right)^{2}=-\frac{\left|E_{1}\right|^{2}}{2 m c^{2}}=\frac{-0.47^{2}}{2 \times 105}=1.06 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{MeV}
$$

8030.a.Problem Statement:
Low energy neutrons from a nuclear reactor have been used to test gravitationally induced quantum interference. In Fig. 8.9, neutrons incident from $\mathrm{A}$ can follow two paths of equal lengths, $\mathrm{ABCEF}$ and $\mathrm{ABDEF}$, and interfere after they recombine at $E$. The three parallel slabs which diffract the neutrons are cut from one single crystal. To change the effects of the gravitational potential energy, the system can be rotated about the line ABD. Suppose $\phi$ is the angle of this rotation $(\phi=0$ for the path ABCEF horizontal).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_03685658611a7d2dda3eg-731.jpg?height=274&width=631&top_left_y=1173&top_left_x=349)

Fig. $8.9$

Show that the phase difference at point $E$ due to the effect of gravity can be expressed as $\beta=q \sin \phi$, where $q=K \lambda S^{2} \sin 2 \theta, \lambda$ being the neutron wavelength and $K$ an appropriate constant which depends on neutron mass $m$, gravitational acceleration $g$, Planck's constant $\hbar$, and numerical factors. Determine the constant $K$. Assume here that the gravitational potential energy differencs are very small compared to the neutron kinetic energies.

Mass of neutron $=939 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}, \hbar c=1.97 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{MeV} \cdot \mathrm{cm}$.
8030.a.Solution:
The wave function of the incident neutrons can be taken as

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c e^{(i \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{r}-i E t) / \hbar}
$$

where $c$ is a constant. When they move along a certain orbit from $x=0$ to $x=l$ it becomes

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c \exp \left[\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{i}{\hbar} E t\right]
$$

Thus the phase is

$$
\varphi=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E t
$$

The neutrons are separated at point $B$ into two beams 1 and 2 , for which $\varphi_{B_{1}}=\varphi_{B_{2}}$.

The situations on lines $\mathrm{BC}$ and $\mathrm{DE}$ are same and so for the two neutron beams, $\Delta \varphi_{C B}=\Delta \varphi_{E D}$. On line $\mathrm{BD}$, we can set the gravitational potential $V=0, E=E_{0}$, and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{D B} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \cdot \frac{S}{v_{0}} \\
&=\frac{1}{\hbar}\left(\sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S-\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S\right)=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $v_{0}$ is the neutron velocity $\frac{1}{m} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}$.

On line CE, the gravitational potential is

$$
V=m g h=m g \cdot \overline{B E} \sin \theta \sin \phi, \quad \text { with } \overline{B E}=2 S \cos \theta
$$

i.e.,

$$
V=m g S \sin 2 \theta \sin \phi
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{E C} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m\left(E_{0}-V\right)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} t \\
&=\frac{S}{\hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \frac{S}{\sqrt{\frac{2\left(E_{0}-V\right)}{m}}} \\
&=S \frac{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}}{2 \hbar}\left(2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the phase difference of the two beams of neutrons at point $F$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta &=\Delta \varphi_{D B}-\Delta \varphi_{E C}=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left(1-2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left[1-2\left(1-\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)+\left(1+\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{3 V S}{4 \hbar E_{0}} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $V \ll E_{0}$. Thus

$$
\beta=q \sin \phi,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
q & \approx \frac{3}{2} \frac{m^{2} g}{\hbar \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} S^{2} \sin 2 \theta \\
&=K \lambda S^{2} \sin 2 \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda &=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{p}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} \\
K &=\frac{3}{4} \frac{m^{2} g}{\pi \hbar^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

8034.b.Problem Statement:
It can be shown that the probability for an on-shell charged particle with initial momentum $P$ to emit a virtual photon with momentum $q$ is proportional to the covariant tensor

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=A g_{\mu \nu}+B P_{\mu} P_{\nu}+C q_{\mu} q_{\nu}+D\left(q_{\mu} P_{\nu}+P_{\mu} q_{\nu}\right)
$$

where $A, B, C$ and $D$ are real Lorentz-invariant scalar functions of $q^{2}, q \cdot P$ and $P^{2}=m^{2}$.

Compute $W_{1}$ and $W_{2}$ for a Dirac particle of mass $m$ for which

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=\operatorname{Tr}\left[(P-\not q+m) \gamma_{\mu}(\mathbb{P}+m) \gamma_{\nu}\right] .
$$
8034.b.Solution:
Current conservation requires $q^{\mu} W_{\mu \nu}=0$, i.e.,

$$
A q_{\nu}+B(q \cdot P) P_{\nu}+C q^{2} q_{\nu}+D\left[q^{2} P_{\nu}+(q \cdot P) q_{\nu}\right]=0
$$

where $q \cdot P=q^{\mu} P_{\mu}, q_{\nu}=q^{\mu} g_{\mu \nu}$, etc. As $P_{\nu}, q_{\nu}$ are independent and $q^{2} \neq 0$, this gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
A+C q^{2}+D(q \cdot P) &=0 \\
B(q \cdot P)+D q^{2} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving for $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{D}$ and writing $A=W_{1}, B=W_{2}$, we have

$$
D=-W_{2} \frac{(q \cdot P)}{q^{2}}, \quad C=-\frac{W_{1}}{q^{2}}+\frac{W_{2}(q \cdot P)^{2}}{q^{4}} .
$$

Hence

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=W_{1}\left(g_{\mu \nu}-\frac{q_{\mu} q_{\nu}}{q^{2}}\right)+W_{2}\left(P_{\mu}-q_{\mu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right) \cdot\left(P_{\nu}-q_{\nu} \frac{q \cdot P}{q^{2}}\right) .
$$

We are given

$$
\begin{aligned}
W_{\mu \nu}=& \operatorname{Tr}\left[(\mathbb{P}-\not q+m) \gamma_{\mu}(\mathbb{P}+m) \gamma_{\nu}\right] \\
=& \operatorname{Tr}\left[\boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}+\boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}-\not q \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}\right.\\
&\left.-\not q \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}+m \gamma_{\mu} \boldsymbol{P} \gamma_{\nu}+m \gamma_{\mu} m \gamma_{\nu}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $P=P_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha}, \not q=q_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha}$. The Dirac matrices satisfy the anticommutation relation

$$
\left\{\gamma^{\mu}, \gamma^{\nu}\right\} \equiv \gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu}+\gamma^{\nu} \gamma^{\mu}=2 g^{\mu \nu}
$$

and so

$$
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu}\right)=4 g^{\mu \nu}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu_{1}} \gamma^{\mu_{2}} \cdots \gamma^{\mu_{n}}\right)=0 \text { for } n=\text { odd } \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\mu} \gamma^{\nu} \gamma^{\lambda} \gamma^{\sigma}\right)=4\left(g^{\mu \nu} g^{\lambda \sigma}-g^{\mu \lambda} g^{\nu \sigma}+g^{\mu \sigma} g^{\nu \lambda}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence in $W_{\mu \nu}$ the terms involving an odd number of $\gamma$ vanish. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Tr}\left(\mathbb{P} \gamma_{\mu} P \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=\operatorname{Tr}\left(P_{\alpha} \gamma^{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} \gamma^{\lambda} P_{\beta} \gamma^{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma} \gamma^{\sigma}\right) \\
&=P_{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} P_{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\alpha} \gamma^{\lambda} \gamma^{\beta} \gamma^{\sigma}\right) \\
&=4 P_{\alpha} g_{\mu \lambda} P_{\beta} g_{\nu \sigma}\left(g^{\alpha \lambda} g^{\beta \sigma}-g^{\alpha \beta} g^{\lambda \sigma}+g^{\alpha \sigma} g^{\lambda \beta}\right) \\
&=4\left(P_{\alpha} \delta_{\mu}^{\alpha} P_{\beta} \delta_{\nu}^{\beta}-P^{\beta} P_{\beta} \delta_{\mu}^{\sigma} g_{\nu \sigma}+P_{\alpha} g_{\nu}^{\alpha} P_{\beta} \delta_{\mu}^{\beta}\right) \\
&=4\left(P_{\mu} P_{\nu}-P^{2} g_{\mu \nu}+P_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right) \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(q \gamma_{\mu} P \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=4\left(h_{\mu} P_{\nu}-\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P} g_{\mu \nu}+g_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right) \\
\operatorname{Tr}\left(m^{2} \gamma_{\mu} \gamma_{\nu}\right) &=m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} g_{\nu \beta} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\gamma^{\alpha} \gamma^{\beta}\right) \\
&=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} g_{\nu \beta} g^{\alpha \beta}=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \alpha} \delta_{\nu}^{\alpha}=4 m^{2} g_{\mu \nu}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, as for an on-shell particle $P^{2} \approx m^{2}$, we have

$$
W_{\mu \nu}=4 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P} g_{\mu \nu}+8 P_{\mu} P_{\nu}-4\left(q_{\mu} P_{\nu}+q_{\nu} P_{\mu}\right)
$$

A comparison with the given expression for $W \mu \nu$ we find

$$
W_{1}=4 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P}, \quad W_{2}=8 .
$$

Note that for an on-shell charge emitting a virtual photon, initially $P^{2}=$ $m^{2}$, and finally $(\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{q})^{2}=P^{2}-2 \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{P}+q^{2}=m^{2}$, and so the two expressions for $W_{\mu \nu}$ are consistent.

8036.b.Problem Statement:
Proton and neutron may be regarded as two "isospin" states of a single particle, the nucleon. Denote proton by $|+\rangle$ and neutron by $|-\rangle$ and define the following operators: 

$$
t_{3}|\pm\rangle=\pm \frac{1}{2}|\pm\rangle, t_{\pm}|\mp\rangle=|\pm\rangle, t_{\mp}|\mp\rangle=0 .
$$

The operators $t_{1}=\frac{1}{2}\left(t_{+}+t_{-}\right), t_{2}=-\frac{i}{2}\left(t_{+}-t_{-}\right)$, and $t_{3}$ can be represented by one-half times the $2 \times 2$ Pauli matrices. Together they form a vector $t$ in isospin space.

In a simple model the Hamiltonian for a system of $N$ nucleons all in the same spatial state is the sum of three terms:

$$
H=N E_{0}+C_{1} \sum_{i>j} \mathrm{t}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{t}_{j}+C_{2} Q^{2}
$$

where $E_{0}, C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ are positive constants with $C_{1}>C_{2}, \mathbf{t}_{j}$ is the isospin of the $i$-th nucleon, and $Q$ is the total electric charge in units of $e$. The sum is over all pairs of nucleons.

In the rest of this problem it is essential to remember that neutrons and protons are spin-1/2 particles obeying Fermi statistics.

What are the energy eigenstates and eigenvalues of a 2-nucleon system? What is the total spin of each state?
8036.b.Solution:
As $\mathbf{T}^{2}=\left(\sum_{i} \mathbf{t}_{i}\right)^{2}$ has eigenvalue $T(T+1)$ and $\mathbf{t}_{i}^{2}$ has eigenvalue $\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2}+1\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i>j} \mathbf{t}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{t}_{j} &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbf{t}_{i}\right)^{2}-\sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbf{t}_{i}^{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2}\left[T(T+1)-\frac{3}{4} N\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

A system of identical spin- $\frac{1}{2}$ particles must have an antisymmetric total wave function. Hence a system of two nucleons has the following possible structures: Configuration

Isospin State

$$
\begin{array}{ccc}
(p p) & |+\rangle|+\rangle & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle-|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle \\
(n n) & |-\rangle|-\rangle & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle-|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle \\
(p n) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|+\rangle|-\rangle+|-\rangle|+\rangle) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle-|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle) \\
(p n) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|+\rangle|-\rangle-|-\rangle|+\rangle) & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|\alpha\rangle|\beta\rangle+|\beta\rangle|\alpha\rangle) \\
& & |\alpha\rangle|\alpha\rangle, \text { or }|\beta\rangle|\beta\rangle
\end{array}
$$

The corresponding eigenvalues are as follows.

\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
\hline Configuration & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{S}$ & $\mathrm{Q}$ & $\mathrm{E}$ \\
\hline$(p p)$ & 1 & 0 & 2 & $C_{1}+4 C_{2}$ \\
$(n n)$ & 1 & 0 & 0 & $C_{1}$ \\
$(p n)$ & 1 & 0 & 1 & $C_{1}+C_{2}$ \\
$(p n)$ & 0 & 1 & 1 & $C_{2}$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

In the above, $|\alpha\rangle,|\beta\rangle$ represent single-particle states with spin $+$ and spin - respectively, and $E$ is the energy above $\left(2 E_{0}-\frac{3}{4} C_{1}\right)$.

8037.a.Problem Statement:
A molecule in the form of an equilateral triangle can capture an extra electron. To a good approximation, this electron can go into one of three orthogonal states $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ localized near the corners of the triangle. To a better approximation, the energy eigenstates of the electron are linear combinations of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ determined by an effective Hamiltonian which has equal expectation values for $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ and equal matrix elements $V_{0}$ between each pair of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$.

What does the symmetry under a rotation through $2 \pi / 3$ imply about the coefficients of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ in the eigenstates of the effective Hamiltonian? There is also symmetry under interchange of $B$ and $C$; what additional information does this give about the eigenvalues of the effective Hamiltonian?
8037.a.Solution:
Under the rotation through $2 \pi / 3$, we have

$$
R \psi_{A}=a \psi_{B}, R \psi_{B}=a \psi_{C}, R \psi_{C}=a \psi_{A} .
$$

Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&R^{2} \psi_{A}=a R \psi_{B}=a^{2} \psi_{C}, \\
&R^{3} \psi_{A}=a^{2} R \psi_{C}=a^{3} \psi_{A},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $a^{3}=1$ and hence

$$
a=1, e^{\frac{i 2 \pi}{3}} \text { and } e^{\frac{i 4 \pi}{3}} .
$$

Suppose the eigenstate of the effective Hamiltonian is

$$
\psi=a_{1} \psi_{A}+a_{2} \psi_{B}+a_{3} \psi_{C} .
$$

Symmetry under the rotation through $\frac{2 \pi}{3}$ means that $R \psi=\psi$, i.e.

$$
a_{1} a \psi_{B}+a_{2} a \psi_{C}+a_{3} a \psi_{A}=a_{1} \psi_{A}+a_{2} \psi_{B}+a_{3} \psi_{C} .
$$

Then the orthogonality of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ requires

$$
a_{1} a=a_{2}, a_{2} a=a_{3}, a_{3} a=a_{1} .
$$

For $a=1$ letting $a_{1}=1$, for $a=\exp \left(i \frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)$ letting $a_{1}=1$, and for $a=$ $\exp \left(i \frac{4 \pi}{3}\right)$ letting $a_{2}=1$, we have the three combinations

$$
\psi^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(2)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
e^{i 2 \pi / 3} \\
e^{i 4 \pi / 3}
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(3)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i 4 \pi / 3} \\
1 \\
e^{i 4 \pi / 3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Let the equal expectation values of $H$ for the eigenstates $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ be zero, then the effective Hamiltonian can be represented by the matrix

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & V & V \\
V & 0 & V \\
V & V & 0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

As $H \psi^{(1)}=2 V \psi^{(1)}, H \psi^{(2)}=-V \psi^{(2)}, H \psi^{(3)}=-V \psi^{(3)}$, the energies corresponding to $\psi^{(1)}, \psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$ are $2 V,-V,-V$ repectively.

There is symmetry in the interchange of $B$ and $C$. Denote by $P$ the operator for the interchange of the two atoms. As $P$ does not commute with $R$, it cannot be represented by a diagonal matrix on the basis of $\psi^{(1)}, \psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$. However, $\psi^{(1)}$ is an eigenstate of $P$ and $\psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$ are degenerate states, though not eigenstates, of $P$. So $P$ imposes no condition on the eigenvalues of $H$.

8037.b.Problem Statement:
A molecule in the form of an equilateral triangle can capture an extra electron. To a good approximation, this electron can go into one of three orthogonal states $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ localized near the corners of the triangle. To a better approximation, the energy eigenstates of the electron are linear combinations of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ determined by an effective Hamiltonian which has equal expectation values for $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ and equal matrix elements $V_{0}$ between each pair of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$.

At time $t=0$ an electron is captured into the state $\psi_{A}$. Find the probability that it is in $\psi_{A}$ at time $t$.
8037.b.Solution:
Under the rotation through $2 \pi / 3$, we have

$$
R \psi_{A}=a \psi_{B}, R \psi_{B}=a \psi_{C}, R \psi_{C}=a \psi_{A} .
$$

Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&R^{2} \psi_{A}=a R \psi_{B}=a^{2} \psi_{C}, \\
&R^{3} \psi_{A}=a^{2} R \psi_{C}=a^{3} \psi_{A},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $a^{3}=1$ and hence

$$
a=1, e^{\frac{i 2 \pi}{3}} \text { and } e^{\frac{i 4 \pi}{3}} .
$$

Suppose the eigenstate of the effective Hamiltonian is

$$
\psi=a_{1} \psi_{A}+a_{2} \psi_{B}+a_{3} \psi_{C} .
$$

Symmetry under the rotation through $\frac{2 \pi}{3}$ means that $R \psi=\psi$, i.e.

$$
a_{1} a \psi_{B}+a_{2} a \psi_{C}+a_{3} a \psi_{A}=a_{1} \psi_{A}+a_{2} \psi_{B}+a_{3} \psi_{C} .
$$

Then the orthogonality of $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ requires

$$
a_{1} a=a_{2}, a_{2} a=a_{3}, a_{3} a=a_{1} .
$$

For $a=1$ letting $a_{1}=1$, for $a=\exp \left(i \frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)$ letting $a_{1}=1$, and for $a=$ $\exp \left(i \frac{4 \pi}{3}\right)$ letting $a_{2}=1$, we have the three combinations

$$
\psi^{(1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(2)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
e^{i 2 \pi / 3} \\
e^{i 4 \pi / 3}
\end{array}\right), \psi^{(3)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{-i 4 \pi / 3} \\
1 \\
e^{i 4 \pi / 3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Let the equal expectation values of $H$ for the eigenstates $\psi_{A}, \psi_{B}, \psi_{C}$ be zero, then the effective Hamiltonian can be represented by the matrix

$$
H=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & V & V \\
V & 0 & V \\
V & V & 0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

As $H \psi^{(1)}=2 V \psi^{(1)}, H \psi^{(2)}=-V \psi^{(2)}, H \psi^{(3)}=-V \psi^{(3)}$, the energies corresponding to $\psi^{(1)}, \psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$ are $2 V,-V,-V$ repectively.

There is symmetry in the interchange of $B$ and $C$. Denote by $P$ the operator for the interchange of the two atoms. As $P$ does not commute with $R$, it cannot be represented by a diagonal matrix on the basis of $\psi^{(1)}, \psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$. However, $\psi^{(1)}$ is an eigenstate of $P$ and $\psi^{(2)}, \psi^{(3)}$ are degenerate states, though not eigenstates, of $P$. So $P$ imposes no condition on the eigenvalues of $H$.At $t=0$, we can expand the wave function $\psi_{A}$ as

$$
\psi_{A}(0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\psi^{(1)}+\psi^{(2)}+e^{-i 2 \pi / 3} \psi^{(3)}\right]
$$

At a later time $t$ we have

$$
\psi_{A}(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[e^{-i 2 V t / \hbar} \psi^{(1)}+e^{+i V t / \hbar} \psi^{(2)}+e^{-i 2 \pi / 3} e^{+i V t / \hbar} \psi^{(3)}\right] .
$$

Hence the probability of an electron, initially in state $\psi_{A}$, being in state $\psi_{A}$ at time $t$ is
